IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Research on HIV and related infections has improved the treatment and prevention of disease, but much more needs to be done to control the epidemic. The proposed Clinical Trials Unit will join together the most active HIV clinical research sites in Baltimore, Maryland, Pune, and Chennai, India, to optimize patient-oriented research and to access key populations affected by this epidemic for participation in clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative G protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) are targeted by more than 30% of FDA approved drugs. Understanding the interactions between ligands, receptors, and transducers, including G proteins, GRKs, and b-arrestins, are important for drug developments. The acquisition of this proposed equipment will not only enhance our capacity of investigating the interactions between ligands, different conformational states of the A2AR receptor, and G proteins that are proposed in the parent award, but also expand our ability to study other GPCRs and their interactions with various molecules in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmids are engineered pieces of DNA that are used for biological research and for manufacturing biologic drugs and therapeutics. Despite the central importance of plasmids to biomedical research and development, the scientific community does not have a standardized, validated and secure infrastructure for associating the physical DNA molecules with the electronic records that describe them. We are proposing to develop a new digital certificate technology that will permanently label the DNA molecules themselves with an identifier that will connect them to standardized electronic documents describing their sequence, function, history, and other essential information allowing scientists to use them in a reproducible, safe, and secure manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Major gaps remain in our understanding of how the immune system recognizes and limits the growth of pathogens at the epithelial border and this proposal will provide new insights into how the CD40-CD40L interaction directs mucosal immunity to infection. The proposed studies leverage a newly tractable pathogen model that shows remarkable specificity to ECs and provides robust in vivo readouts of infection, control, and protection. The mechanisms discovered in the course of this program will be broadly relevant to the study of diseases of the intestinal tract of infectious, inflammatory and malignant etiology where CD40L has been implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative AVIVA Chatbot 2.0 integration for enhanced communication is a supplement of a parent U01 which focuses on increasing HPV screening access among WLWH. It aims to train, evaluate, and integrate a customized large language models (LLMs)-based question-answering generative AI engine into an existing AI chatbot that is designed to respond to questions, and clear doubts of WLWH about cervical cancer screening (CCS) in three HIV clinics in Nigeria, as a measure to improve CCS access. The generative AI has human-level creativity ability to generate ideas on a possible wide range of questions based on learnings from previously collected data and its integration enables a chatbot to cater to inherent variability and linguistic variations in the way chatbot end users ask the same questions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which infects immunocompromised people, can communicate among its own populations using a signaling system called quorum sensing. We seek to understand how quorum sensing evolves over time and influences interactions with other microbes, with the idea that these studies will eventually lead to potential new treatments for bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative After metastasis to the lungs, breast cancer cells are exposed to unique forces and matrix proteins that are not present at the primary tumor. My previous findings indicate that cyclic stretching, mimicking breathing dynamics within a 3D model of the early metastatic niche, can drive tumor cells into a state of growth arrest without widespread cell death. Because stromal cells are the key contributor of matrix composition and architecture, my goal is to evaluate the unique fibroblast subtypes conditioned by breast cancer cells at different stages of the metastatic cascade and characterize how the tissue changes they produce alter the metastatic progression of disseminated breast cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The supplemental implementation science training and data collection activities proposed will leverage the Quit4Life+ (5U01CA261624-03) and HIVAM (D43TW009759) projects’ research teams (e.g. research trainees, interviewers, field supervisors, data/records managers) and existing study partners (e.g. district officers, clinical supervisors, clinicians, nurses, counselors) to build implementation science capacity and better evaluate cancer-related interventions and services within local, regional, and national health systems. By adapting and piloting an implementation assessment tool, we aim to assess the effectiveness and feasibility of cancer prevention and care interventions for people living with HIV in Uganda and Zambia. This project will have important implications for policymakers, community leaders, and healthcare workers and ultimately guide future implementation science studies and interventions designed to strengthen cancer health service delivery throughout the African region and in other LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer is a significant health issue in Mexico and screening participation rates are low particularly among women experiencing access barriers. The IMSS Maquiladora HPV Screening Program aimed to address this by offering self-sampling kits to under-screened women in maquiladoras, however, there were wide variations in program use and effectiveness highlighting the need to understand implementation barriers. Our research seeks to identify these barriers, explore patient and provider perspectives, and design strategies to enhance program adoption, implementation, effectiveness, and maintenance ultimately contributing to improved cervical cancer control in Mexico.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of these studies is to determine whether tau accumulation in serotonin neurons causes affective and sleep disturbances, leading to chronic sleep deprivation and hyperexcitability in serotonin neurons and accelerating the spread of tau pathology to the entorhinal cortex. The resulting loss of 5-HT input to the EC also enhances excitability of EC neurons that project to the hippocampus, promoting spread to this region and precipitating cognitive decline. Ultimately, this investigation may identify neural substrates underlying the early non-cognitive symptoms of AD which could lead to better treatments for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed P51 supplement will meet an urgent need to upgrade ABSL2 macaque holding space to support HIV/AIDS related research. Over the last decade several ABSL2 buildings and rooms have been removed from service and taken offline at SNPRC due to failing HVAC systems. This supplement will provide HVAC upgrades to eight ABSL2 rooms to bring them back into service to support rhesus macaque holding at SNPRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TCF20-associated neurodevelopmental disorder (TAND) is a devastating neurological disease caused by mutations in a high-risk autism gene TCF20, yet the disease pathogenesis and reversibility remain elusive. I have recently found that TCF20 regulates key neuronal gene expression in mouse models and therefore propose to dissect the molecular, neuronal, and temporal function of TCF20 during brain development, particularly focusing on its role in activity-dependent signaling pathways. This study will reveal the neuronal and molecular pathogenesis of TAND, determine the critical developmental window for therapeutic intervention, and shed light on how activity-dependent signaling regulates brain development under healthy and disease conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Maintenance of ER protein homeostasis (proteostasis) is a fine balancing act between protein synthesis, folding and degradation. Mis-regulation of any one of these processes leads to perturbed ER proteostasis and activation of the unfolded protein response (UPR). ER stress and UPR activation is a major contributor to many human diseases. Here we investigate mechanisms that prevent protein mis-folding in the ER with a focus on how protein synthesis is regulated at the ER.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compounds capable of promoting neuroplasticity, such as ketamine and serotonergic psychedelics, have enormous potential for treating neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases characterized by cortical atrophy, but their hallucinogenic effects limit their clinical scalability. Recently, our group discovered that it is possible to engineer non-hallucinogenic analogs of psychedelics capable of promoting neuroplasticity after a single administration and producing sustained therapeutic effects across disease indications. The research described here seeks to establish new synthetic strategies for accessing plasticity-promoting compounds as well as methods for evaluating their efficacy, safety, and mechanisms of action—information that will ultimately lead to the development of new treatments for diseases such as depression, posttraumatic stress disorder, substance use disorder, Alzheimer’s disease, and Parkinson’s disease, among others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness in the world. This project aims to develop a mobile software application to enhance trachoma monitoring activities by allowing eye photography and integration of visual acuity and refractive error assessment. The mobile application will be field-tested and validated in diverse settings in Peru to ensure broad generalizability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in the human brain following early blindness have been widely documented, but our understanding of the mechanisms underlying this remarkable neuroplasticity is very limited. My goal is to examine the anatomical, neural, and computational constraints that allows blind individuals to meet the extraordinary challenge of learning to navigate and interact with the environment using remaining senses. This will not only facilitate the development of targeted rehabilitation programs for blind individuals, but will also help us understand the processes underlying acquisition of specialized skills (including reading and arithmetic) during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Peroxisomes participate in lipid metabolism and scavenging of reactive oxygen species in almost all nucleated cells and play critical roles in most major organs, liver, heart and pancreas, and in brain where they are especially important in maintaining the myelin sheath around axons, and synthesis of ether lipids in neurons and glia. Aging, and CNS diseases show loss of the balance of oxidative stress and lipid metabolism mediated by changes in peroxisomal proteins, of which ABCD3, the subject of this proposal, is one of the most abundant and important for import of fatty-acids, bile salt and ether lipid precursors. We seek an atomic level basis for the function and changes in associations of ABCD3 from aging and Alzheimer’s model cell lines using cryo electron microscopy and electron tomography.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Intracellular membrane trafficking that mediates the delivery of secretory and endocytic cargo proteins and lipids is critical for a range of cellular functions, including protein secretion, post-translational modifications, signaling, cell polarization, and cell maintenance. Defects in membrane trafficking can underlie or exacerbate many human diseases, including cancer, diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, cystic fibrosis, Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome, and congenital disorders of glycosylation. In this project, we will uncover the molecular basis for protein-protein interactions and regulations of key components of the Golgi trafficking machinery and create a novel cellular model to study congenital disorders of glycosylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) is the leading cause of hospitalization in older adults and represents an enormous public health burden. Despite the contributions of countless studies, national campaigns, and financial incentives, high rates of rehospitalization continue to put enormous strain on the U.S. healthcare system and on those suffering from the disease. We propose to integrate the strengths of life course theory, data, and methods to examine the longitudinal patterns and predictors of hospitalization in older adults diagnosed with HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because preschool-age irritability that persists into school-age predicts lifespan mental disorder and poorer functional outcomes, identifying the neural mechanisms by which children persist vs. remit in irritability is paramount to intervene in the earliest phase of the clinical cascade. Our overall goal is to identify reward- and inhibition-related neural pathways that characterize persistence vs. remission of early childhood irritability and may be targets for future novel preventive efforts. Our project is significant because it will pave the way for precision medicine for irritability: providing the right treatment (based on neural mechanisms) to the right people (children who will persist in irritability), at the right time (preschool age, before irritability problems worsen).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: The patient-clinician interaction is central to most therapies and is supported by key interpersonal mechanisms of action, though the neural underpinnings of this effect are mostly unknown. As previous research has implicated brain-to-brain concordance of the temporoparietal junction, a region known to be intimately linked with theory of mind processing, we will use hyperscanning functional MRI to evaluate the impact of targeted theory of mind training in fibromyalgia patients on brain-to-brain concordance and how such training can synergistically couple with acupuncture therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: The looming crisis of antibiotic resistance and thus the inability to treat common infections is reaching a tipping point making development of new antibiotics imperative. This supplemental proposal will facilitate the further development of a new class of antibiotics that we have termed GmPcides, which are bactericidal against a wide range of Gram-positive pathogens. This supplement will identify the essential targets of GmPcide-induced cell death in MRSA as well as virulence determinants that are affected by GmPcide treatment in the murine skin and soft tissue infection model, supplementing the ongoing studies in the parent grant to identify viable lead compounds for clinical development.      !   !   !

PHR: Project Narrative Aging is associated with deficits in trust-related decision making, contributing to the growing public health problem of elder fraud. This project will (i) characterize basic neurocognitive processes in learning to trust in aging; and (ii) determine if trust-related decision making can be optimized via neurofeedback training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nonsense Mediated mRNA Decay (NMD) degrades both aberrant transcripts and “normal” transcripts with other specific features, impacting around 10% of the transcriptome. This project will investigate the biological roles and molecular functions of UPF3, a disease-linked core NMD factor, in both human cells and zebrafish development. Taken together, this study will help us understand how UPF3-activated NMD and transcriptional regulation is modulated, and elucidate connections between mRNA decay and transcriptional regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) are promising for treating many challenging diseases, but they are difficult to produce due to rapid aging and loss of therapeutic functions during expansion. This proposal aims to develop an AI-based method to design drugs that delay MSC aging by controlling their biochemical signaling. Upon completion, this project will enable reproducible production of highly potent MSCs and advance our fundamental understanding of aging signaling in these cells.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Statistical and mathematical methods for the study of infectious diseases and for discovery and evaluation of interventions have become increasingly important. The Summer Institute in Statistics and Modeling in Infectious Diseases (SISMID) provides necessary and innovative training in statistical and mathematical modeling to students, postdoctoral fellows, and professionals. This research education program enables them to formulate research questions, analyze data, design studies, and model dynamics and evolution of infectious diseases including emerging infectious diseases relevant to important public health and biomedical research questions.

PHR: Project Narrative Age-related neurodegenerative diseases like glaucoma have no cure and are a significant public health burden. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative  People who inject drugs (PWID) experience disproportionate risk of being infected with SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, yet due to stigma, fear of mistreatment, and other factors, PWID are far less likely to be vaccinated compared to other populations. In response, we propose to continue our collaboration with a prominent community based organization serving African American and Latino PWID. Our project will explore baseline hesitancy to vaccinate among PWID, identify barriers to vaccination, and then develop and evaluate messaging designed to increase COVID-19 vaccination among our target population of PWID through a clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)—which affects 1-4% of adults—is a severe mental illness that causes people to eat an insufficient volume or variety of food and puts them at risk for nutritional deficiencies, low weight, psychiatric comorbidity, and suicidality. This multidisciplinary study offers an important opportunity to examine how underlying abnormalities in endocrine signalling and neural circuitry contribute to phenotypic presentations in adults. This innovative project has significant potential to reduce the public health burden of ARFID by informing pathophysiology and identifying mechanistic treatment targets hormonal agonist/antagonist medications and for brain stimulation therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Given the rising burden of obesity, diabetes, and heart disease in the community, new approaches are needed to maintain blood vessel health from the impact of cardiometabolic traits. The proposed research investigates the impact of cardiometabolic diseases on health of the blood vessel lining cells, endothelial cells, by measuring stress markers and gene expression pathways. Our results will clarify how cardiometabolic diseases result in different patterns of endothelial cell gene expression and may identify novel molecular underpinnings of cardiovascular risk that will have important preventive and therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Tight regulation of coenzyme A (CoA), a cofactor that plays a key role in energy metabolism, is essential to maintain normal organ function and is achieved by balancing its synthesis and degradation. CoA degradation is a poorly characterized process and the research proposed herein will determine the importance of two CoA- degrading enzymes, NUDT19 and NUDT8, in the regulation of the CoA pools and CoA-dependent metabolic pathways within peroxisomes and mitochondria, respectively. This knowledge will establish the potential of targeting CoA-degrading enzymes to manipulate specific subcellular CoA pools and correct deranged metabolic processes with more selectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To establish a productive infection, HIV-1 must enter the cell, copy its RNA genome into DNA, enter the nucleus, and integrate into the host cell DNA. Studies in this Project will uncover currently unknown aspects of these different processes in molecular detail, providing a foundation for the identification and development of new anti-viral targets. We will also characterize how the potent new HIV-1 inhibitor, lenacapavir, binds the viral capsid and inhibits nuclear entry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Human Pumilio proteins, PUM1 and PUM2, are essential proteins that control the flow of genetic information from genes to proteins. Defects in their function lead to neurological diseases including seizures, intellectual disability, and neurodegeneration. This proposal seeks to comprehensively understand their regulatory function and identify the genes they control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the virus eventually wins in the absence of sustained antiretroviral treatment (ART), humans have an array of innate immune responses that help to limit HIV-1 replication, particularly during viral transmission and when the virus rebounds upon removal of ART. These observations imply that it might be possible to devise effective new antiviral therapeutic strategies if we better understood how innate immune factors sense and inhibit viral replication, and can learn better how to manipulate and harness these responses. The primary goal of this Project is therefore to gain such insights into innate immune factors that act at early steps in the HIV life cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wolbachia bacteria are the most common endosymbionts in nature. Vector-control groups are attempting to establish pathogen-blocking Wolbachia strains in mosquito populations to reduce the transmission of human diseases, particularly dengue and Zika. This research will identify and evaluate the mechanisms that govern the spread and maintenance of Wolbachia in host populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This administrative supplement will fund the central pharmacy and urine drug screening activities reassigned to Lead Investigators at Yale University and not previously supported in the original funded application described as follows. The emergency department (ED) provides an opportunity to care for patients with opioid use disorder (OUD) and initiate treatment 24 hours, 365 days a year. This project will test two dosing strategies of buprenorphine, standard ED dosing versus a high dose accelerated induction process, in engaging patients with ongoing addiction treatment while evaluating treatment engagement, craving, withdrawal symptoms and use of illicit drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite evidence-based clinical guidelines that recommend the use of VTE risk-stratification tools to identify ambulatory patients with cancer at high-risk of VTE who may benefit from VTE prevention with prophylactic anticoagulation, our preliminary data suggest that both risk assessment and primary prophylaxis are substantially underused. This study will use implementation science principles to develop, test, and evaluate an implementation strategy to increase the use of VTE risk assessment and, for high-risk patients, primary thromboprophylaxis. The long-term goal of the proposed research is to reduce VTE and improve outcomes for ambulatory patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This research will increase knowledge about the regulation of gene expression, which underlies virtually every aspect of human health. By improving understanding of RNA polymerase, which is an established target for effective antibiotics, the work will aid in the quest for new antibiotics that can keep humankind a step ahead of microbial pathogens. The research also will elucidate complex connections between RNA synthesis by RNA polymerase, chromatin structure, RNA maturation, and RNA translation that are key to understanding the function of microbial communities in promoting both human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies from the last several years have highlighted the importance of long noncoding RNAs in human development, health, and diseases such as cancer and atherosclerosis, but the mechanisms by which RNAs effect epigenetic change remain largely unknown. X-chromosome inactivation serves as an excellent model to study RNA regulation because this process is controlled by a series of RNA-based switches. Our proposed research will dissect mechanisms of RNA regulation by investigating its role in chromosome pairing, gene silencing, and imprinting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The liver is now recognized as an immunological organ with unique immunological properties; the liver’s immune response is tightly controlled and leads to immune tolerance to microbial and metabolic stimuli. Here, we have identified that high-fat high-sugar diet (HFS) and gut microbiota interaction generates a spectrum of dietary and microbial components and outcome metabolites that induce inappropriate hepatic immune activation and inflammation, contributing to the development of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) from simple steatosis to the advanced form of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). We propose to dissect the underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms to advance our understanding of the role of the Diet-Gut-Liver axis in hepatic immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The goal of this training grant is to prepare the next generation of scientists who will conduct high quality research and make new discoveries in biomedical sciences. The research focus of students who train in our program is to understand fundamental mechanisms in signaling and cellular regulation, an area which is key to the discovery of new therapeutic treatments for human diseases such as cancer, diabetes, inflammation, heart disease, immunological and neurological disorders, and birth defects, and forms a foundation for modern research in biology and medicine. The purpose of this INCLUDE supplement application to the existing parent T32 program is to enhance the robust environment for training graduate students in scientific areas that are relevant to alterations observed in Down syndrome and its co-occurring conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lupus is one of the top 10 leading causes of non-accidental death in adolescent females. Children and adolescents with lupus develop early blood vessel injury that significantly increases their risk of early heart attacks and strokes in adulthood. We currently do not know how to monitor or prevent these changes in childhood-onset lupus, which is more severe and confers greater cumulative tissue damage than adult-onset lupus. The proposed project seeks to determine whether blood pressure patterns and blood vessel function can be used to evaluate vascular health in children with lupus, and to assess whether medications used to prevent heart disease in other conditions may be beneficial in adolescents and young adults with lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria undergo constant surveillance, integrating a variety of signals into a cohesive feedback program that coordinates with the nucleus to ensure prompt homeostatic rebalancing critical for optimal mitochondrial function and cellular health. My lab has been instrumental in studying mitochondrial surveillance, with a particular focus on the ESRE network and its interactions with other protective mechanisms. Identifying the relationship between mitochondrial damage and changes in lipid homeostasis, propagation of the ESRE-activating signal to the nucleus, and how changes in RNA metabolism are coordinated to ensure a prompt response will help identify methods to promote improved health across the human lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Exposure to air pollution during pregnancy is a leading environmental hazard of concern, with exposure during the prenatal period linked to postnatal health effects ranging from respiratory, cardiometabolic, and neurodevelopmental outcomes. As the organ that shapes the gestational experience of the developing fetus, the placenta is a pivotal, yet understudied, resource to provide critical insight into the toxicological responses to prenatal air pollution exposure. This study will evaluate the cellular and extracellular vesicle profiles of placental miRNA in response to traffic-related air pollutant exposure in a trophoblast cell culture model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Rosengart, Matthew R PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our group seeks to understand why and how some patients, even after being ‘healed’ and discharged from the hospital, continue to suffer poor health and a high rate of long-term death. Our characterization of how the mitochondrion restructures itself as an adaptive mechanism to mitigate the acute insult and ‘learn’ so as to protect the cell against any future environmental threat may provide a biological explanation for the elevated long-term death experienced by our patients. Together our results will provide foundational knowledge to support the development of innovative diagnostic tools and novel biologic therapeutics that compliment contemporary sepsis care to improve survival. In doing so we will address one of the most pressing needs in the care of septic patients. Project Narrative Page 7

PHR: Project Narrative The development of versatile and practical methods for organic synthesis is critical to the discovery and manufacture of molecular structures relevant to understanding biological mechanisms and treating human disease. In this proposal, we will pursue the design of new reactions and elucidation of fundamental reactivity principles in the areas of Ni-catalyzed cross coupling and phosphoranyl radical catalysis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A vaccine that will be effective in preventing HIV infection and also control virus replication once the virus has taken hold, will require a dual barrier. The first one at the mucosal portal of entry for the virus to prevent or at least minimize the ability of the virus to create a beachhead and two at the systemic level where generalized immune responses are able to control virus that has succeeded in overcoming the first barrier. Our vaccine strategy targets renewable vaginal epidermal stem cells as a permanent source of antigen production which proliferate and elaborate the vaccine antigen along the phases of the reproductive cycle, providing repeated bouts of vaccine antigen presentation as the cells mature and cycle, leading to induction of humoral and cellular immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: The looming crisis of antibiotic resistance and thus the inability to treat common infections is reaching a tipping point making development of new antibiotics imperative. Our parent U 19 grant has aimed to identify new targets that can be exploited to develop antibiotic-sparing therapies. This supplement proposal will explore the folding mechanism of the FimD usher, a key component of the type I chaperone usher pathway (CUP) pilus system that is critical for human cystitis, by the β-barrel Assembly Machinery (BAM). Furthermore, outcomes from this proposal will provide insight into key steps that can be exploited and targeted for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative (parent award) Inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptors (IP3Rs) are calcium channels that are ubiquitously expressed in all eukaryotic cells and play important roles in regulation of a broad range of physiological processes in humans. Dysfunctions in IP3Rs are associated to numerous human diseases, including neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and Huntington’s diseases, stroke, and cancer, and therefore these channels are important drug targets. The proposed studies aim to understand the detailed structure and fundamental mechanisms governing IP3R channel function and to elucidate how they are perturbed in disease states that will aid in search for novel therapies to treat disorders related with abnormal cell calcium homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This supplement requests funds to upgrade the computer infrastructure of the Scalable Informatics for Biomedical Imaging Studies (SIBIS), which is used by the National Consortium on Alcohol and Neurodevelopment in Adolescence (NCANDA) study for data acquisition, management, quality control, harmonization, analysis, and distribution to the public. The goal of NCANDA is to follow youth who have and have not engaged in hazardous drinking to determine alcohol's influence on the brain, cognition, emotion, and life activities in emerging adulthood when young men and women are establishing themselves in careers, relationships, and independent living. Upgrading the over 10-year-old computer infrastructure of SIBIS will enable us to maintain its high level of software security and fulfil the computational and storage needs of NCANDA so that NCANDA can continue with thoroughly tracking its participants, whose longitudinal data are critical to better understand how heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence impacts this period of life and adult functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is responsible for uptake of molecules from the plasma membrane and surrounding environment, and therefore is crucial for determining how a cell will interact with its surroundings. Actin assembly near the plasma membrane generates forces that are harnessed for a variety of cellular processes including clathrin- mediated endocytosis. Mechanistic understanding of clathrin-mediated endocytosis and actin assembly are crucial to understanding normal cell physiology and a variety of pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goal of the Durham Center of Innovation to Accelerate Discovery and Practice Transformation (ADAPT) is to enhance the Veterans Health Administration's (VHA) ability to continually improve health care and optimize Veteran wellbeing and independence. ADAPT will lead innovative research on promoting and sustaining healthy lifestyles, improving access through virtual care, and optimizing Veteran function and independence. Working closely with VA and non-VA partners, ADAPT investigators will apply and advance state-of-the-art methods, translate research findings into meaningful practice change, and train the next generation of VA researchers. ADAPT will play a vital role in helping VHA meet the challenges of providing timely, coordinated, consistently high-quality care to more than 9 million Veterans each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The specific types and amounts of metabolite molecules present in biological systems, such as blood, serum, and tissues, provide critical information about health and disease. Metabolomics is a top-down approach, which involves identification and quantitation of metabolites in complex biological mixtures. The proposed research program aims at developing new metabolomics technologies, which are based on nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy as well as in combination with cheminformatics and with mass spectrometry, to analyze a wide range of biological mixtures more comprehensively, accurately, and efficiently and to apply these tools and make them available to the scientific community, including via public web servers and databases, with synergistic benefits also for protein science.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Non-Communicable Diseases are an emerging global pandemic with disproportionately higher rates in developing countries. Uganda with a large rural based population, requires development and implementation of evidence-based interventions to address real-life problems and provide sustainable solutions. The proposed Building capacity for Implementation Science research in Non-Communicable Diseases (BImS-NCDs)” training hub at MUST, will provide leadership, best practices, research support, mentoring and training in epidemiological, prevention, and implementation science approaches in NCDs across the lifespan to the partner institutions in rural Uganda.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular pluripotency in the germline is maintained through processes within cytoplasmic assemblies called germ granules. The parent grant seeks to understand the function of individual germ-granule proteins, the purpose and conditions of their assembly, and their capacity for cellular reprogramming. This administrative supplement replaces an aging ultralow temperature freezer that is used to house the live strains and reagents needed for the studies outlined in the parent grant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Youth from low socioeconomic groups are at a systematic disadvantage in the provision of diabetes care, particularly diabetes technology which is associated with improvement in diabetes-specific outcomes. Thus, we urgently need studies to understand and ameliorate the persistent worsening of disparities of diabetes management and outcomes in youth from low socioeconomic backgrounds. This proposed research will (1) improve representation of diverse youth in the literature, (2) address the gap in knowledge of barriers and promoters in publicly insured youth, and (3) identify and address factors of worsening disparity in diabetes technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. 15-Prostaglandin dehydrogenase (15-PGDH) degrades prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), a signaling molecule that promotes tissue repair and regeneration in multiple tissues. Therefore, inhibitors of 15-PGDH elevate PGE2 levels in tissue and may represent therapeutics for diseases characterized by ulceration or tissue damage. Here, we will use structure-based methods to design inhibitors of 15-prostaglandin dehydrogenase, determine the cell types that express and respond to 15-PGDH, and decipher the cytokine network that regulates tissue repair in response to PGE2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite Venezuelans being among the fastest-growing migrant groups in the US and Colombia, there is limited knowledge on the interplay between key strengths, behavioral health outcomes, and well-being among this population during resettlement and over time. The proposed study aims to identify and compare key elements vis-à-vis thriving, flourishing, and behavioral health of Venezuelan crisis migrants in the US to those who relocated in Colombia. Findings from this diversity supplement will inform evidence-based policy efforts as well as the development of innovative and culturally relevant responses to future crisis migrations and the promotion of crisis migrants’ well-being.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research program is relevant to public health because it encompasses the development and characterization of the highly specific monoclonal antibody inhibitors for disease-related proteases. These proteases are pivotal in the pathogenesis of many disorders including cancer, neuropathic pain, obesity, stroke, and viral infections. Highly specific monoclonal antibody inhibitors will accelerate research directed to a better understanding of basic pathology of these diseases and lead to the development of therapeutic interventions targeting these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although Black Americans are twice as likely to have Alzheimer’s disease than White Americans, little is known about the impact of social and societal determinants of health on neurocognitive integrity of the medial temporal hippocampal memory and prefrontal-executive systems, the primary brain systems impacted in Alzheimer’s disease. The objective of this application is to investigate the impact of interpersonal and institutional/structural racism on neurocognitive integrity of these brain systems in Black adults aged 65 years and older and to examine cardiovascular disease risk as an underlying biological mechanism. Addressing this knowledge gap is critical for developing new health policies and biobehavioral and social interventions for healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To explain the enigmatic endemicity of typhoid fever in the small Pacific island nation of Samoa since at least the 1960s, despite steady improvements in water and sanitation, we hypothesize that a unique strain of S. Typhi entered Samoa decades ago and expanded into the dominant circulating strain, and asymptomatic chronic gallbladder carriers of the strain serve as an effective long-term reservoir and source of infection. Through our close collaboration with the Samoa Ministry of Health, the “Samoa Typhoid Fever Surveillance Initiative,” we propose a series of comparative genomic and geospatial analyses integrating whole genome sequence data of Salmonella Typhi isolates from Samoa with clinical and household epidemiologic data to determine the population structure, evolutionary origins, and local patterns of transmission including the relative role of asymptomatic chronic carriers of Salmonella Typhi. Where previous large scale phylogenetic studies of Salmonella Typhi have demonstrated the feasibility and public health utility of our experimental approaches, none have focused on Samoa nor been implemented as part of an accelerated and coordinated national typhoid control program; therefore, our results will not only contribute a Polynesian perspective to the field of Salmonella Typhi genomics, but also present new information on endemic typhoid fever to assist the Samoa Ministry of Health and our international collaborators in public health decisions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Transformations that allow for the rapid introduction of complexity have become increasingly important in the areas of drug discovery, agriculture, and materials science. The objective of this proposal is to develop new methods and strategies to convert aromatic compounds into complex small molecules that are highly desirable but not readily accessible. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Much of the extreme Native American cancer disparities are due to cancer types where early screening and access to healthcare have the largest impact, suggesting that these disparities could be mitigated with a stronger Native American healthcare workforce and infrastructure, and yet, the most underrepresented population in science and medicine are Native Americans. In response, we provide an intensive 8 week summer course that serves as a primer for cancer research, along with curriculum development and outreach activities that will directly impact >76 participants, annually, and indirectly impact thousands of underserved students, teachers, families and community members, over five years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Mg2+ is essential for wide range of cellular processes including the imposition of membrane shape and stability, neutralization and stabilization of nucleic acids and nucleotides, channel modulation, enzyme secretion from acinar cells, and serves as a cofactor for cytosolic and mitochondrial metabolic enzymes. Although cellular Mg2+ dynamics is accomplished via numerous Mg2+ transport machineries, the molecular identity of these Mg2+ flux mechanisms have not been fully elucidated. In the MIRA program, we will identify ligands and channels and elucidate Mg2+-dependent metabolic signals that would establish the Mg2+ flux compendium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Phosphatidic acid is a lipid signaling molecule whose aberrant production or accumulation can lead to many diseases, including several types of cancer, neurodegeneration, and susceptibility to infection. This proposal seeks to develop and apply cutting-edge toolsets to understand how cells regulate the production and metabolism of phosphatidic acid to maintain physiological processes that depend on it without tipping the balance away from homeostasis to favor pathological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Chemical changes to our genetic information that do not change the underlying DNA sequence itself are referred to as “epigenetic” changes, and are increasingly being recognized to be altered in a wide range of lung diseases. How these epigenetic alterations contribute to the onset or progression of these diseases, and whether we can modify the epigenome to treat lung diseases remains largely unknown. This proposal will define how the SWI/SNF complex establishes patterns of chromatin accessibility (a type of epigenetic change) during development of the lung epithelium, and how these same patterns are modified by the SWI/SNF complex following repair after lung injury in the adult.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chemical genetics is powerfully enabling for biological discovery and therapeutics development. We propose to leverage breakthroughs in precision genome-editing technologies and multi-omics to transform chemical genetic approaches, allowing us to illuminate small molecule mechanism and endogenous protein structure-function at scale and in high resolution. By applying these innovative approaches to critical and diverse protein targets, we expect to advance our fundamental understanding of drug mechanism of action and protein complex structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Protein allostery is a fundamental phenomenon in which ligand binding at one site affects substrate activity or ligand binding at a second, distal site of the protein. Allostery is a primary mode of regulation for enzymes and other proteins that drive signal transduction and metabolism, and it is now being used in some drug development efforts, even though the mechanisms of allostery are not well understood. The work in this project will characterize dynamics and allosteric communication pathways for the homodimeric enzymes chorismate mutase and thymidylate synthase, and for engineered optogenetic conformational switch proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome (IC/BPS) affects millions of Americans, and current treatment options are ineffective for many patients. This project aims to determine the role of angiotensin signaling in developing and maintaining disease symptoms of IC/BPS using animal models. These results could open up new FDA- approved treatments with widely available and safe angiotensin inhibitors, substantially impacting patients’ quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Stem cells are special cells that replicate many times over to give rise to all the tissues of the body in an embryo, replenish the tissues of the body over the life of an organism, and make the sperm and egg cells that go on to make the next generation. I study the relationship between stem cells and their supportive niche cells in a microscopic worm called C. elegans, which has many of the same cellular features as humans. I propose to follow up on my recent discovery that the niche and associated cells grow dramatically to support the stem cells, encourage their proliferation, and help them make sperm and eggs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed supplement is relevant to the INCLUDE project, in which the parent grant focuses on adults with Down Syndrome (DS), specifically, associations between hearing status, auditory function, cognition, language and brain imaging through functional and structural approaches. This supplement aims to collect pilot data in children with DS, as there is a paucity of auditory studies in this population, with known incidence of hearing loss in infants and children with being much higher than in the general population. This supplement will provide pilot data in children with DS, establishing feasibility for a new parent R01 on auditory function and its association with cognition, language and brain structure and function in children with DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Enhancer regulatory elements play essential roles in development and cell function through gene regulation, and dysregulation of enhancers contributes to various human diseases. The objective of our parental R35 program is to investigate the regulations of enhancer dynamics and assembly in response to signaling and their functional importance. To understand the functional attributes of different enhancer components, we require support from this supplemental equipment grant to purchase a user-friendly cell analyzer with a high- throughput sampler for our planned CRISPR screen experiments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The type 1 secretion system (T1SS) widely exists in many Gram-negative bacterial pathogens and secretes a variety of toxins which contribute to their virulence. This interdisciplinary study exploits single particle cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM), biochemical and in vivo approaches to dissect the structures and mechanisms of the T1SS. The study will provide a new basis for developing future therapeutic interventions against a range of bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: This study centers cell movements called convergent extension which are controlled by a set of proteins called the planar cell polarity (PCP) proteins. These experiments will be significant because convergent extension is essential for neural tube closure and limb morphogenesis, and failure of these movements results in a human birth defects such as neural tube defects and skeletal dysplasia. Thus, experiments proposed here will shed new light on mechanisms underlying human congenital anomalies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The Houston Health Services Research & Development (HSR&D) Center for Innovations in Quality, Effectiveness and Safety (IQuESt) has been continuously funded by HSR&D since 1990, providing strong scientific leadership and institutional infrastructure dedicated to a model of embedded health system research. We have a nearly 20-year tradition of conducting research in partnership with the health care delivery system and responding to its needs, making us pioneers in the execution of the learning health care system model in VHA. The IQuESt mission, “Improving health and well-being through innovations in health care delivery”, conveys our commitment to transformative and innovative research that is aligned with VHA national priorities. IQuESt is ideally poised to contribute to making care more accessible, safer, and more patient-centered with innovative research, rapid implementation of evidence, novel methodologies, solid partnerships, stakeholder engagement, career development of scientists, and infrastructure to promote the learning health care system in VHA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The mission of the Center for Care Delivery and Outcomes Research (CCDOR) is to develop and evaluate interventions and implementation strategies that improve health care delivery, Veteran engagement in health care, and Veterans' health and functioning in their communities. CCDOR's vision is to elevate the quality, consistency and equity of health care and outcomes for all Veterans through innovative health services and implementation research. CCDOR is a vibrant health services research center of 26 core investigators leading research in Trauma Recovery (Priority 1) and Chronic Pain and Opioid Harms Reduction (Priority 2), as well as conducting and promoting research in additional areas including cancer prevention and control, health aging, and other timely topics. CCDOR has deep and strong partnerships with VA Program Offices, including the Office of Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, the National Center for PTSD, and National Pain Management. These and other partnerships ensure the value and impact of Center research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation for Complex Chronic Healthcare (CINCCH) is a HSR&D COIN based at Hines VA Hospital. CINCCH's mission is to conduct research to optimize coordination and contextualization of healthcare delivery and improve outcomes for Veterans with high priority neurologic conditions, disseminate and implement best evidence, and train future researchers. We utilize innovative direct observation methods to collect data that compliments other forms of data to assess quality and patient experiences. CINCCH collaborates with several VA Operations Partners and is affiliated with three universities in the Chicago area. In addition, we have established a Veterans Engagement Panel that provides feedback on grant proposals and dissemination activities. Our COIN's vision is to create the evidence and implement the findings to support and guide VA in providing the best care in the right place at the right time.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The VA HSR&D Center for the Study of Healthcare Innovation, Implementation & Policy (CSHIIP) has had a fundamental role in the ongoing transformation of VA health care, through critical examination of multilevel determinants of variations in VA care, development and testing of innovative healthcare delivery models that improve the effectiveness and value of VA care, and impact on VA practice and policy through implementation and spread of evidence-based practice. Our work is anchored in a longstanding history of high-impact research through career development, support, and engagement of a multidisciplinary cadre of investigators, leveraging extensive partnerships that have infused our mission, vision, and values with a deep understanding of VA priorities. These partnerships and priorities have guided our strategic planning, enabling us to build a portfolio of highly responsive research in key focused (primary care, women’s health, high-risk/high-need groups) and emerging areas (complementary/integrative health, specialty care, and emergency management).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This application proposes the continuation of a Center of Innovation (COIN), called the Pain Research, Informatics, Multimorbidities, and Education (PRIME) Center. The COIN builds on the successes of our existing PRIME Center at VA Connecticut Healthcare System. The goals of the PRIME Center are to conduct research to improve care for all Veterans with a specific focus on pain management and women's health. The Center also fosters innovative research in emerging areas like suicide prevention and CHOICE care. Through a Veteran Engagement Group, the Center strives to be Veteran-centric. Investigators provide research mentoring to train the next generation of VA health services researchers. To achieve its goals, the PRIME Center is supported by partnerships with VHA Patient Care Services and Operations leaders, especially the Pain Management Program and Women's Health Services, as well as a large number of cross-COIN and other VHA medical center collaborations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Veterans Health Administration (VA) provides care for individuals who are more likely to be racial and ethnic minorities, older, and poorer than the general population. Although VA provides a health care safety net, disparities in health and health care exist for many vulnerable Veteran populations and are associated with increased risks of disability, illness, and death. In addition to individual, provider, and health system factors, disparities may originate outside of the health care system and involve personal behaviors and social and community influences. As a health system committed to delivering high-quality, equitable care to all Veterans, VA must identify vulnerable populations, understand the root causes of disparities, and assess interventions to eliminate them. The Center for Health Equity Research and Promotion's mission is to advance the quality and equity of health and health care for vulnerable Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Access and Delivery Research and Evaluation (CADRE) is seeking to renew its Center of Innovation (COIN) funding to advance research and improve access for Veterans. We aim to build upon our existing expertise, established operational partnerships, and long-term research objectives through prioritizing five overarching goals that align with our focused areas of research and emerging priorities. GOAL 1: Improve access to high quality care for rural Veterans through innovative applications of telehealth in specialty care, community care, and dual use. GOAL 2: Develop and evaluate interventions targeting the multidrug-resistant organism crisis. GOAL 3: Expand efforts in developing innovative health services research in three additional areas: (1) women’s health, (2) epidemic opioid use and substance use disorders, and (3) cardiovascular outcomes. GOAL 4: Continue the Center’s success in supporting mentored career development. GOAL 5: Promote Veteran engagement with recognition that Veterans are experts on Veteran experience.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation (COIN) for Veteran-Centered and Value-Driven Care has had outstanding productivity and impact on Veteran healthcare and well-being through the application of the National Academy of Medicine's learning health system. In the past 3 years, our 47 investigators generated ~$47 million in operating revenue, published 583 manuscripts, and led 113 projects across our research, implementation science, operational projects/program evaluations and training programs. Our dual-site Center will continue to address our two focus areas: 1) promote Veteran-centered care to improve patient experiences across VA healthcare and community settings and 2) advanced value-driven care by providing Veterans the highest quality care at the lowest financial burden. Building on our prior success, we will continue to partner with operational leaders and our Veteran Engagement Board to innovate new research, implementation science, and operational programs as well as train the next generation of outstanding research leaders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Given Veterans' increasing choices about where and how they receive care, successful coordination of care will require improving effective communication among a variety of individuals and entities, as well as improved management and use of health information. This project supports the Center for Health Information and Communication, of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Research & Development Service. The Center's mission is to improve Veterans' health care through innovative research on health information, technology, and communication. The Center's vision is to improve Veterans' health through innovative applications of health information and health information systems that serve the population-based and interpersonal needs of patients and health professionals. The Center will generate knowledge about the impact of the Department's investment in health information technology, and will determine how systems-based and interpersonal communication of health information can improve delivery and outcomes of care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teen drivers who have committed a traffic violation are at increased risk for crashes, injuries, and deaths. Through partnership with the local Juvenile Traffic Court, this randomized controlled trial will assess the effectiveness of an innovative in-vehicle driving feedback technology, with and without parent training, on reducing risky driving events, unsafe driving behaviors, and recidivism among high-risk teen drivers, which correlates with NICHD’s mission to prioritize research on teen driver safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to improve the long-term physical and psychosocial outcomes of adolescents with chronic musculoskeletal pain (CMP) in order to reduce healthcare utilization and mitigate the psychosocial sequelae of ongoing chronic pain in this vulnerable patient population. The goal of the proposed research is to examine the impact of a resilience coaching program adapted for adolescent chronic musculoskeletal pain in a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT). Achievement of the study aims has the potential to be a significant contribution to building and fostering resilience among adolescents with chronic musculoskeletal pain, as the proposed research will inform a future multicenter RCT of the resilience coaching program and thereby augment current interdisciplinary management of adolescent CMP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will facilitate and vertically advance the development of critically needed medical countermeasures against chemicals induced skin injuries. The proposed mechanistic studies will facilitate understanding the dynamics of the key processes involved in the chemicals induced injuries that will have an enormous impact on our capabilities to design countermeasure strategies and test them directly on human skin using our novel model system. This whole process will shorten the time for developing countermeasure and increase the chances of success in clinical translation Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH/NIAID/Chemicals Countermeasure Program’s mission to develop new countermeasures and add them to the national stockpile.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Healthcare Organization and Implementation Research has a mission to conduct organizationally-partnered, and Veteran-partnered research in order to develop, implement, and evaluate evidence-based and innovative practices that improve Veterans Health Administration (VA) healthcare. Our priority goals are: (1) to advance the field of HSR by sustaining, developing, and growing our existing, scientific focus areas, and growing our evolving and emerging scientific areas; (2) to enrich VA's cadre of world-class HSR investigators, by supporting training and education across the career spectrum; and (3) to grow and support innovation in order to maintain VA at the cutting edge of HSR and adapt to meet VA's ever- changing needs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Mental Healthcare & Outcomes Research (CeMHOR) is an HSR&D Center of Innovation whose mission is to optimize health and well-being of Veterans through innovative research to improve access to and engagement in evidence-based care for mental health and substance use disorders and prevent suicide. CeMHOR accomplishes its mission by partnering directly with Veterans, clinical leaders, and front-line providers to develop feasible and effective interventions to address top VA and national priorities. CeMHOR expertise in implementation science leads to widespread uptake of these interventions. CeMHOR investigators are also experts in rural health and community engagement. CeMHOR research will apply this expertise to include Veterans who are not receiving VA care, as well as those who use VA services but do not fully engage in needed care. In addition to two focus areas, mental health care access/engagement and suicide prevention, investigators conduct research to address opioid misuse and abuse and advance implementation science.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Informatics, Decision-Enhancement, and Analytic Sciences (IDEAS) Center of Innovation will conduct research to advance scientific discovery, implement novel interventions, promote cross-center collaboration, increase research capacity, and engage operational partners to improve Veteran health. Our research will focus on the public health threat of antibiotic resistance, on mitigating health risks in Veterans during periods of vulnerability, and on improving medication safety as the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) transitions to a new electronic health record. Across all of these areas, we study methods to promote the adoption of research findings into clinical practice. In the process, we train the next generation of outstanding VA health services researchers. Veteran and stakeholder engagement is a topmost priority for our Center. All of our research is highly collaborative and integrated with clinical programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly two thirds of new cancer patients fail treatment due to resistance that is not fully understood. Aperture Bio’s single cell proteomics platform can provide rapid single-cell molecular analyses to enable improvements over current diagnostics, ultimately improving patient treatment options and outcomes. This project further develops and validates the proprietary technology in addition to producing new, proprietary analytical software to create a comprehensive tumor T cell panel, with the ultimate goal of ensuring that every lab can employ single cell methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic, low-grade inflammation is a contributing factor to most diseases associated with aging. However, the molecular and cellular mechanisms that regulate chronic inflammation are still being deciphered. We will determine how specific regulatory microRNAs function to control age-dependent inflammatory status through their regulation of T cell metabolism, recruitment of inflammatory myeloid cells, and control of senescence-associated secretory phenotypes, and our work will identify novel therapeutic targets to treat this harmful condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Targeted therapies have revolutionized patient care for a wide range of cancers, but are fundamentally limited by acquired resistance mutations. Current technologies used in industry to evaluate the mutational landscapes of next generation targeted therapies are incomplete, limited in sensitivity, and retrospective. This project proposes to develop and commercialize deep mutational scanning with duplex sequencing (DMS-DS), the most comprehensive and accurate platform available for measuring the mutational landscape of investigational targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Morphogenesis, the biological process that causes cells or tissues to attain their characteristic shape, is highly conserved throughout phylogeny, is fundamental to development and wound healing and can best be investigated through precise, high-resolution documentation in both time and space. We use powerful genetic and biophysical approaches to investigate cell sheet morphogenesis in the simple system, Drosophila melanogaster and request here upgrades to our > 20 year old microscope instrumentation that is out of date and badly underperforming. Our studies are designed to identify new genes that regulate and drive cell sheet movements and investigate the molecular basis for how these genes c0ntribute to morphogenesis – we provide important insights into the basic biological mechanisms that go awry in human pathologies such as cardia bifida, spina bifida, cleft palate and wound-induced, epithelial lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This work will bolster our understanding of epicardial-myocardial signaling and the role of the extracellular matrix in modulating cell behavior in the developing heart. The clinical relevance of this work lies in the application of epicardial cells to enhance the pump function of a perfusable, chambered, human cardiac tissue model that will be ideal to study the impact of cardiac disease and therapeutics on pressure-volume dynamics, stroke work, and ejection fraction. In the future, this living, human muscle pump generated in a dish might be used to restore cardiac function in patients with heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High-risk molecular mutations in the epigenetic regulators ASXL1 and EZH2 co-occur frequently with JAK2V617F activating mutations in myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) and portend risk of fibrotic progression, shortened duration of response to targeted JAK inhibitor therapy, and increased rate of leukemic transformation. We hypothesize ASXL1/EZH2 mutations cooperate with JAK2V617F to enhance clonal fitness/outgrowth of mutant hematopoietic stem cells and pro-fibrotic inflammatory signaling pathways to impart resistance to JAK inhibitors and promote fibrotic alterations in the bone marrow niche. Our work aims to utilize an optimized inducible and reversible Jak2V617F mutant mouse model, a large cohort of banked MPN patient samples, and an array of in vivo and genomic/epigenomic techniques to understand how epigenetic alterations contribute to clonal/fibrosis evolution in MPNs with the goal of translating our findings into novel therapeutic avenues for MPN patients with high-risk epigenetic alterations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the original MIRA award R35GM118141 is to develop a program aiming to understand the biogenesis of mitochondrial membranes. Disorders arising from impaired mitochondrial OXPHOS function or mitochondrial gene expression, including protein synthesis, result in a variety of pathologies including encephalomyopathies and cardiomyopathies. Identifying and characterizing factors required for OXPHOS enzyme assembly, mitoribosome biogenesis and translation, and the pathways in which they act is a prerequisite towards understanding the molecular basis of these disorders. This proposal is for the purchase of the Amersham ImageQuant 800 biomolecular imager. This system is ideal for chemiluminescence, fluorescence, and colorimetric imaging of a wide variety of samples, including gels, membrane blots, multiwell plates, and petri dishes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop a cold triggered local anesthesia that allows patients to adjust the degree of pain relief according to their changing needs and conditions. With a single perineural injection or site infiltration, the patient can determine the onset of anesthesia, can trigger anesthesia multiple times to mimic the frequent administration of conventional local anesthetics, and can trigger anesthesia for the duration of post-operative pain state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During recovery of consciousness after general anesthesia, common clinical problems occur such as delirium and delayed awakening. There are no available treatments for these problems because the mechanisms underlying recovery of consciousness after general anesthesia are unknown. The goals of this MIRA proposal are to understand how cognition recovers after general anesthesia in rodents, and to test whether recovery of cognition may be accelerated by activating specific neural circuits involved in memory, attention, and arousal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal describes research to study how ribosomes are assembled in yeast and Hela cells, and how ribosome biogenesis is interconnected with the structure and function of the nucleolus, the cellular compartment where ribosomes are made. As the ribonucleoprotein machines that catalyze protein synthesis in all cells, ribosomes are essential for and closely linked to the growth, proliferation, and adaptation of cells. Consequently, dysregulation of ribosome synthesis or nucleolar structure results in cancers, anemias, neurodegenerative diseases, and a variety of developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative While behavioral treatments for chronic pain are effective on average, some people benefit greatly from treatment while others benefit very little, and the same person may respond much more to one type of treatment than another. This project aims to better understand the patient factors that could be used to identify – before treatment –who will benefit the most from each of three different chronic pain treatments: cognitive behavioral therapy, Hypnotic Cognitive Therapy, and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy. The knowledge gained from this research will provide an essential platform for developing algorithms to effectively match patients with chronic pain to treatments that are most likely to be benficial for them.

PHR: Contact PD/PI: Myong, Sua PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to investigate the role of transcriptionally generated G-quadruplex (G4), R-loop and DNA supercoiling in transcription and translation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of individuals with clinical Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is rapidly increasing worldwide due to aging of the population, but current cognitive measures lack sufficient sensitivity and specificity to detect subtle decline within the preclinical phase. There is a critical need for tools that are sensitive to AD neuropathology during the preclinical phase that are low-cost, high-access, and fast to administer that can be used across educationally, linguistically, and culturally diverse older individuals. The goal of this project is to identify metrics for semantic impairment in diverse individuals that correlate with AD neuropathology and predict clinical decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian clocks provide an accurate internal representation of local time under a range of diﬀerent physiological temperatures and cellular energy levels. However, the molecular mechanisms by which clocks compensate for such variations remain experimentally unresolved in any organism. Thus, the overall goal of this application is to ﬁll these fundamentally important knowledge gaps and thereby signiﬁcantly advance the ﬁeld of chronobiology with a lasting impact.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Leakage of the tricuspid valve, located between the right atrium and right ventricle, is extremely common and can significantly impact patients' health. PHR: Project Narrative Anti-cancer drugs and environmental chemicals elevate irreversible protein trapping in DNA, inducing a DNA damage response and mutagenesis if not repaired properly. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A major NIMH goal for early psychosis treatment is to “prevent deterioration and disability among individuals suffering from psychotic illness”, however, rates of Social Security Administration disability (SSAD) enrollment remain high. Enrollment in SSI/DI may provide benefits (including cash assistance, access to Medicaid/Medicare and other social entitlements), but may detrimentally affect vocational aspirations and employment; these tradeoffs are even more pressing following the economic shocks of the COVID-19 crisis and heightened attention to racial. The goal of this project is to investigate factors influencing decisions to apply for and/or enroll in SSI/DI, the implications of these decisions, and the longitudinal relationships between SSI/DI and career development, and then use this information to develop systematic strategies for improving services, supporting client decision making and optimizing outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The acidic gastric compartment promotes efficient nitration of dietary conjugated fatty acid when consumed with nitrite and nitrate-rich foods (e.g., leafy vegetables), forming nitrated fatty acids that exert protective and anti-inflammatory actions. We recently defined nitrated conjugated linolenic acid as a major nitro fatty acid species in humans and propose to study their mechanism of formation and signaling actions. This will provide dietary approaches to metabolic and inflammatory diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Noncoding RNAs are major players in the programming of gene expression in development and disease.
