IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Obesity is a pervasive disorder linked to serious medical complications and reaching epidemic proportions in the United States. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of thrombospondin-3/a2d-1 signaling in the ventromedial hypothalamus facilitating feeding control and glucose and lipid metabolism in a body-weight independent manner. These investigations will inform new avenues for the treatment of obesity-associated metabolic disorders and mechanisms underlying metabolic dysfunction in individuals treated with gabapentinoid drugs, known to inhibit a2d-1 function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our lab focuses on the structural and functional studies of human proteases that degrade amyloidogenic peptides, e.g. amyloid beta and insulin, peptides associated with Alzheimer disease and diabetes, respectively. We use integrative structural approaches to better understand the molecular basis of substrate recognition and regulation of human insulin degrading enzyme (IDE) and other amyloid peptide degrading enzymes such as neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme. The success of our studies will allow us to selectively modulate the degradation of amyloid β and glucose regulating hormones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE (PROJECT NARRATIVE)  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it provides detailed insight into the fundamental mechanism of mitochondrial fission, an essential process in cellular homeostasis. Consequently, mitochondrial division is misregulated in several diseases, leading to organelle dysfunction and eventually cell death. Therefore, the proposed research aims dissect the regulatory mechanisms that govern organelle division and the physiologic changes associated with altered mitochondrial morphology to identify novel therapeutic targets and inform future studies that advance disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Experiments to devise new methods to synthesize cyclic peroxides will enable new approaches to prepare this family of potential drugs and explore how they are active as anti-cancer agents. Studies of the reactions involved in organic synthesis and carbohydrate chemistry will help medicinal chemists use such reactions to make biologically active compounds with greater control of three-dimensional structure. These studies are relevant to human health because they could lead to new ways of making medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Glucocorticoids regulate genetic programs in all tissues to control inflammation, metabolism, and differentiation as a primary stress response hormone, but synthetic glucocorticoids can achieve tissue- selective effects through unknown mechanisms. The goal of this project is to understand how differences in the chemical structure of the synthetic glucocorticoids alters the shape of the receptor to differentially control stress responses across tissues, and in doing so develop glucocorticoids for treatment of colitis with improved skeletomuscular on target side-effects

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Martell project narrative (2-3 sentences) Technologies that enable the identification of which proteins reside in specific locations inside cells are critical for elucidating biological processes and disease states, including neurodegeneration, pathogenic infection, and cancer. One promising strategy to achieve this goal is proximity labeling (PL), but in order to enhance the sensitivity and specificity of proximal protein detection, improved PL catalysts are needed. We propose that hybrid biological-abiotic PL catalysts developed in our laboratory will enhance both sensitivity and specificity in spatially- resolved proteomic mapping, and we are employing these catalysts in neurons to benchmark their performance against existing methods and establish their broad utility as research tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Carbohydrate binding proteins (CBPs) are a broad category of proteins involved in diverse biological processes that either guard against disease or that promote it. These proteins are involved in cancer, infectious disease, immunity, autoimmunity, diabetes, and fibrosis, to name a few. This project will develop technologies that enable rapid discovery of CBP inhibitors, which would enable us to treat disease and to untangle the complex web of CBP functions that are currently poorly understood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) is a cancer-causing human retrovirus that infects about 15-20 million individuals worldwide. While virus particle assembly at cell-cell contacts are required for efficient virus transmission (both within and between individuals), many fundamental aspects involved in this critical mode of virus spread are poorly understood, including the nature of virus spread and particle morphology of released particles. Development of experimental workflows to enable new cutting-edge technologies will improve understanding of this distinct mode of virus transmission, which has broad relevance to other viruses capable of spread via cell-cell contacts – including transmission events

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance: All life requires some form of nitrogen to function, and although the atmosphere is comprised of roughly 78% of dinitrogen (N2), it is biologically unavailable without reduction by nitrogenase enzymes, which convert unreactive N2 to a biologically-available form for uptake. The intimate details of this critical (and difficult) transformation are not understood, and although biological studies on the enzyme have demonstrated a critical role of cooperative interactions by nearby amino acid residues and a multi-metallic enzyme core, we do not know the intimate molecular details. This project aims to develop a molecular level understanding of these cooperative effects on substrate activation, which in addition to contributing important mechanistic details that govern nitrogenase function, may also translate into new catalyst development for organic and inorganic transformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: High-risk medications for anesthesia, sedation and pain are frequently prescribed and administered by dentists to children and have resulted in serious unintended consequences, but unique challenges with prescribing high-risk medications to pediatric dental patients are not well understood. Understanding patterns of dental prescribing and factors associated with adverse safety outcomes can inform training models and interventions to improve evidence-based practice, ultimately decreasing risks of serious adverse events and mortality among children. Thus, this project is relevant to the NICHD high research priority to improve systems of care which can mitigate medical errors and advance child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reactive species from lipid peroxidation generated under disease conditions damage DNA and form etheno lesions, which are strongly cytotoxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic. This project will characterize the repair of these etheno adducts by enzymes across two distinct pathways: base excision repair and direct reversal repair. Results will identify the differential repair fingerprints of such lesions and inform future translational studies that capitalize on these repair mechanisms to protect against genomic instability.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of emerging viral diseases result from the zoonotic transmission of pathogen from animals to humans. While the innate immune system plays a critical role in limiting cross-species transmissions, cellular determinants mediating this effect have yet to be fully described. This study aims to identify and characterize novel cellular factors responsible for limiting viral replication in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Trauma and surgical sepsis frequently lead to death and/or persistent critical illness, however there are no targeted therapies to improve outcomes. With advances in technologies, we can now measure changes in gene and protein expression in thousands of cells at the single cell level and at the same time measure levels of thousands of biomolecules in the circulation. We will continue to apply these technologies to the study of trauma and sepsis to identify predictive biomarkers and identify novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance: Mammalian cells use biological zip codes to transport mRNAs, which encode the information for the synthesis of proteins, to specific locations in the cell, so that proteins are made in their appropriate location. This RNA localization process is critical to early development, learning and memory, and at the level of the individual cell, to the secretion of hormones and neurotransmitters as well the cell surface localization of proteins functioning in signaling and cell-cell communication. The findings from this study are expected to reveal new mechanisms of RNA localization and identify conserved pathways that may be dysregulated in diseases of development, metabolism, and ageing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Wnt signaling is a rapidly evolving and important field of investigation and new regulators involved in this cascade are continuously being identified. Our study focuses on developing a mechanistic understanding of PTPRF-mediated regulation of Wnt signaling and intestinal stem cell function. Results from our studies will help identify new therapeutic strategies for treating Wnt-driven diseases by using PTPRF as a target.

PHR: Molecular mechanisms of intersecting human telomeric functions Narrative Telomeres are structures found at the ends of our chromosomes that are instrumental in ensuring the integrity of our genomes. This proposal aims to understand at a molecular level how human telomeres help maintain chromosome ends in different biological contexts, including in cancer cells, stem cells, and cells undergoing meiosis. These studies will enhance our knowledge of how telomeres uphold genome integrity and help develop strategies to counter telomere dysregulation in human diseases like cancer and infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Vimentin intermediate filaments are a key regulator of mammalian cell shape, mechanical integrity, and motility, but remain poorly understood for groups of cells embedded within 3D extracellular matrix. Here, we investigate the role of vimentin in cellular deformability, matrix adhesion, and multicellular coordination during directed migration. These fundamental studies will enable new insights into the structure and function of vimentin during physiological processes, as well as its dysregulation in pathologic states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Unanticipated adverse drug reactions remain a major cause for restricted access to new medications and post marketing withdrawals of new drugs. Adverse drug reactions are often caused by reactive metabolic species that form covalent adducts with proteins but the identitiy and extent of protein adducts formed is often difficult to predict or prevent. This project will establish novel proteomics tools that can be used to evaluate mechanisms of adverse drug reactions and that can be incorporated into drug development workflows for early identification of drug protein adducts.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The highly conserved bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signaling pathway plays critical roles in a variety of developmental and homeostatic processes. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE P. aeruginosa is a principal pathogen in cystic fibrosis and hospital-acquired infections; its pathogenicity is linked to biofilm formation. Here we aim to further the research of our current RO1 and deeper characterize a pathway for biofilm regulation in P. aeruginosa. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of new pathways that regulate biofilm growth will provide new targets for preventive and therapeutic interventions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This program is discovering catalytic reactions that selectively perform the atomistic change of C(sp3)–H to C–O, C–N, and C–C in complex molecules, which has been demonstrated to alter their biological function and efficacy as therapeutics. Using these reactions, we are pioneering the area of late-stage functionalization where atomistic changes are made directly on drugs and natural products, circumventing lengthy, individual de novo syntheses, which present a significant technological challenge to drug discovery. To broaden the application of late-stage functionalization, we are inventing catalysts that have a higher tolerance for pre-existing reactive functionality and effect novel site-selectivity; control over three-dimensional outcomes; and C(sp3)–H cross- couplings with O- , N- , and C-containing complex fragments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RESEARCH STRATEGY 1) The parental grant abstract (R35GM136379)  Fungal pathogens infect humans, animals, and plants and cause severe consequences on global human health and crop production. Communication between hosts and pathogens is essential for host defense and pathogen virulence, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Previous studies in my lab discovered that some non-coding regulatory small RNAs (sRNAs) from fungal pathogens, such as Botrytis cinerea, which causes grey mold disease on more than 1000 plant species, can be transported into host plant cells and suppress host immunity genes, a mechanism called “Cross-Kingdom RNAi”. Recently, we discovered that such sRNA communication is bi-directional. Plant hosts have also developed the ability to deliver sRNAs, mainly using extracellular vesicles, to fungal cells and induce cross-kingdom RNAi of fungal virulence-related genes. Such sRNA communication was also observed between mammals and parasites. Despite more studies across diverse systems demonstrating that mobile sRNAs are key regulatory molecules in host and pathogen interactions, the field of cross-kingdom/cross-species RNA communication is still in its infancy. This proposal is designed for the use of the plant Arabidopsis and the fungal pathogen Botrytis as a model system to address the outstanding questions in this field. These questions include how host cells control sRNA transport upon infection, how specific classes of small RNAs are sorted into extracellular vesicles, how fungal cells deliver sRNAs into host cells, what are the mechanisms of RNA and vesicle uptake in the host cells and fungal cells, and whether other classes of RNAs such as mRNAs and long non-coding RNAs associate with extracellular vesicles and move between host and fungal cells as well as how they function in the counter party, etc.. A combination of genetics, genomics, biochemical and molecular biology approaches will be used. This project is expected to provide unprecedented insight into the underlying mechanisms of cross-kingdom/cross- species RNA communications, which will ultimately help develop innovative and eco- friendly disease control strategies such as RNA-based fungicides or antifungal drugs. 2) Scientific justification Request for a Blizzard NU-99828JG -86°C Ultralow Freezer The PI requests fund to purchase a Blizzard NU-99828JG -86°C Ultralow Freezer (with necessary racks) from NuAire, Inc., which will replace our 20-year-old broken -80C freezer. The old -80C freezer was unstable for the last two years, and the temperature could only go down to -50 to -40C. It was completely broken recently, which caused serious problems for the research in the lab. This instrument is essential for this project and for a molecular biology lab. It will enable us to store all the plant leaves and cultured fungal and bacterial samples, extracellular vesicles isolated from plants, fungi and bacteria, isolated small RNAs and mRNAs, all the bacterial and fungal strains etc..

PROJECT_TITLE: Cross-kingdom RNA communications between plant and fungal pathogens

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The project seeks to gain a quantitative understanding of how human stem cell organoids, which have been validated against fetal tissue using single cell and in situ sequencing, respond to and process signals to axially elongate, and how the stem cells in the elongating tailbud are maintained to sustain this elongation. To achieve this goal, the reproducible embryonic stem cell organoid system will be studied using a combination of microscopy, single cell sequencing, statistical inference, mathematical modeling, and molecular biology. In the longer term, a quantitative understanding of how the embryo sustains axial elongation will help better understand the mechanisms of developmental defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proteins are long chains that must fold into specific three-dimensional structures to carry out their functions, which include digesting nutrients, making muscles contract, and enabling communication of neurons in the brain, among many others. Like long strands of yarn quickly become entangled if not organized into balls, proteins that fail to fold into their functional structures promptly tend to clump together into aggregates, which can be detrimental to cellular and organismal function and is associated with neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. Our mechanistic studies will clarify how proteins fold into their functional structures and avoid aggregation, providing fundamental insights into disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative This study will support the Center to Accelerate Population Research in Alzheimer’ (CAPRA) overarching goal to stimulate new, innovative, and high-quality population ADRD research and to increase accessibility of these resources for a broad spectrum of ADRD investigators. To support this goal, this supplement includes utilization of the NIA Data LINKAGE program to develop new Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) datasets linked to claims data in the Health & Retirement Study (HRS), the National Health and Aging Trends Study (NHATS), and through nursing home assessment data via the Minimum Dataset (MDS). Additionally, this study will test the rigor of a validated claims-based ADRD identification algorithm when applied across differently sampled national datasets where services are linked to claims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to discover new principles for selective catalysis, and to apply those principles to the discovery of valuable organic reactions. The fruit of this effort will be new classes of small- molecule, chiral organic catalysts engineered to induce rate acceleration and stereoselectivity in a wide range of challenging transformations through networks of attractive non-covalent interactions. These catalysts form the basis for conceptually novel and efficient methods for the synthesis of chiral organic compounds of known or potential utility in public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The Hsp70/Hsp110 molecular chaperones play multiple essential roles in maintaining cellular protein homeostasis, a fundamental cellular process that is inevitably linked to many human diseases including fungal infections. In this proposal, we aim to understand the basic molecular mechanism of Hsp110s in the Hsp70/Hsp110 chaperone machinery in maintaining protein homeostasis using a unique chemical tool that we recently identified, and thereby provide crucial insights on how to target them for treating fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative It has become feasible for small research groups to sequence individual genomes and for larger groups to sequence tens of thousands of individuals. The parent proposal created a multi-institutional, cross disciplinary team to discover and validate disease causing splicing mutations in patients. This supplement will greatly extend our ability to develop more realistic models of splice site recognition as long read sequencing helps account for all the splicing decisions and crosstalk that occur in the processing of each pre-mRNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Single-particle cryo-EM, a method of molecular structure research pioneered in the PI's lab, has been further developed with the inclusion of time-resolved techniques to allow capture and structure determination of short- lived states. A combination of standard and time-resolved techniques will be applied to elucidate processes in protein biosynthesis with fundamental significance to public health. In addition, a novel method of data analysis aiming at characterization of the dynamic behavior of molecules will be applied to large datasets of important membrane-associated molecules: rotary ATPase and Cystic fibrosis trans-membrane conductance regulator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Protein-protein and protein-RNA interactions are vital for numerous biological processes, from cellular signaling to gene regulation, and their misregulation has been associated with a variety of diseases. The proposed research describes approaches for developing synthetic protein mimics for targeting chosen biomolecular complexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to perform the first investigation of non-invasive, non-thermal, mechanical high-intensity focused ultrasound (histotripsy) ablation using an ultra-high rate treatment method with ultrasound- and robotic-guidance to rapidly, precisely, and completely ablate entire soft tissue sarcomas (STS). Canine STS share biologic similarities with human STS, and clinical research in pet dogs with STS offers a unique opportunity to accelerate treatment advances for humans, while also improving treatments for canine STS. The results of this study are expected to transform histotripsy practice through efficient ablation of large tumors and open up new pathways for its rational deployment in other cancers that will uniformly improve canine and human health.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The Endosomal Sorting Complex Required for Transport (ESCRT) machinery is known for its fundamental roles in remodeling cellular membranes to enable membrane protein degradation, HIV budding, and cell division. The work in this proposal builds on and extends our discovery that ESCRTs also stabilize and repair membranes throughout the endolysosomal network. Insight into how this machinery maintains compartmental membrane integrity has important implications for understanding inflammatory responses, pathogen invasion, and mechanisms underlying necrotic cell death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Meprin metalloproteases have been implicated in the pathophysiology of chronic kidney injury induced by diabetes and neurodegenerative disease (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease). The proposed parent project will determine; (1) how single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the meprin genes impact interaction between the meprin enzymes and their substrates, (2) how cleavage of meprin substrates influence signaling pathways involved in disease progression, and (3) the potential use of meprins and meprin cleavage products in early diagnosis of tissue injury. This knowledge is important in developing therapeutic targets and diagnostic tools for diseases such as chronic kidney injury and Alzheimer’s disease. The requested funding for purchase of a high-resolution fluorescent microscope will facilitate microscopic analysis of kidney and brain tissue and acquisition of publication quality images.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Regulation of the cellular signaling pathways that control the actin cytoskeleton is essential in development and homeostasis. This application focuses on the LIM domain kinases, enzymes which are key regulators of the actin cytoskeleton, and their upstream kinases, the MRCKs. We aim to delineate the atomic-level mechanism of LIMK and MRCK control, to understand how the dual specificity kinases can phosphorylate a range of substrates, and how the LIMKs are recruited to the MRCKs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human GABAB receptor and human calcium-sensing receptor are dimeric G protein-coupled receptors that mediate key biological phenomena including neurotransmission and Ca2+ homeostasis. Here we address the fundamental questions of how these receptors are activated by extracellular stimuli and how their functions are regulated. Defects in the signaling activities of these receptors are associated with disorders of the brain, bone and mineral metabolism, and our work will inform about the disease mechanisms and assist the design of novel therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Heritable changes that can last for multiple generations without changing DNA sequence have been reported in many organisms, including humans. By focusing on the regulatory architectures that promote or prevent gene silencing in the nematode C. elegans, we will gain broadly applicable insights regardless of the molecules that mediate similar regulatory interactions in other systems. These insights will improve the diagnosis and treatment of hereditary diseases, especially those with an epigenetic origin in previous generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The central objective of this proposal is to develop a technological platform that harnesses light energy and biocatalysis to synthesize molecules of significant relevance to human life. We envision doing this by establishing cyanobacterial endosymbionts within yeasts cells, such that the endosymbiotic cyanobacteria provide ATP and assimilated carbon (generated from photosynthesis) to the yeast cells, which utilize it to produce biologically important natural products. The above endosymbiotic platform will allow us to couple the remarkable biosynthetic and biocatalytic potential of yeast to the photosynthetic ability of cyanobacteria to develop a sustainable and simple bioproduction platform to produce key precursors of FDA approved compounds, Artemisinin and Taxol.

PHR: NARRATIVE Bacterial genes acquired through horizontal transfer are silenced by small histone-like proteins and by the transcription termination factor Rho. In this project, we will investigate mechanisms by which Escherichia coli cell envelope biogenesis genes are silenced and activated by RfaH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity-associated non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is now the primary cause of liver cancer and the driver of the increase in this lethal disease. While certain gut bacteria have been implicated in NAFLD or NAFLD-induced liver fibrosis, longitudinal studies are needed to provide evidence for the temporal relationship. We will identify the kinds of gut bacteria and their metabolic pathways that are associated with increase in liver fat, more extensive liver stiffness, and increase in blood biomarker-based liver fibrosis over time in a prospective multiethnic study of underrepresented Asian Americans and Native Hawaiians, and Whites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Project Narrative DNA damage arising from oxidative stress promotes multiple human diseases, and the primary cellular defense against this oxidative DNA damage is the multi-protein base excision repair (BER) pathway. The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand the molecular mechanisms of each BER factor both individually and within larger multi-protein/DNA complexes using naked duplex DNA and nucleosomes. We will employ elegant biophysical approaches to elucidate inherent BER complexities, while providing both a foundation for interpreting the biological response and the subsequent development of rational therapeutic treatments towards enhancing human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA molecules play fundamental roles in transmitting and regulating genetic information in all living systems, including disease-causing bacteria, RNA viruses like HIV and SARS-CoV-2, tumor cells, and our own brains and bodies. New potentially life-saving therapies and vaccines that target or repurpose these RNAs are being hindered by our imperfect understanding of how RNAs fold into intricate 3D structures. Our research addresses these gaps through computational tools, most recently through deep learning neural networks. Training predictive models and making inferences with these neural networks requires heavy use of graphics processing units (GPU), at a scale that could not be envisioned at the time of our original proposal but now appears necessary for us to carry out the proposed research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Pyroptosis is a highly inflammatory form of cell death mediated by the gasdermin family members, and is implicated in infections and autoimmune or autoinflammatory disorders. This proposal will leverage our expertise in structural and biochemical studies of gasdermins and inflammatory caspases to investigate the post- translational regulation of gasdermins by proteases, ubiquitin ligases, palmitoyltransferases, and other enzymes. Better understanding of the mechanisms of gasdermin regulation is highly significant, which may stimulate the development of novel therapeutics that target pyroptosis and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The properly regulated expression of protein-coding genes transcribed by RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) is essential for normal growth and development; disturbances in this regulation are hallmarks of cancer and other diseases. Both the transcription cycle of RNAPII and the cell division cycle are governed by the opposing actions of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) and protein phosphatases, which have emerged as potential targets in cancer therapy. Comprehensive models of how CDKs and phosphatases work together during the transcription cycle, and how this coordination is disrupted in cancer cells, are needed both to deepen understanding of normal gene regulation and to guide efforts to target the RNAPII machinery therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Narrative Protein allostery is a fundamental phenomenon in which ligand binding at one site affects substrate activity or ligand binding at a second, distal site of the protein. Allostery is a primary mode of regulation for enzymes and other proteins that drive signal transduction and metabolism, and it is now being used in some drug development efforts, even though the mechanisms of allostery are not well understood. The work in this project will characterize dynamics and allosteric communication pathways for the homodimeric enzymes chorismate mutase and thymidylate synthase, and for engineered optogenetic conformational switch proteins.

PHR: Project Narrative A number of viruses like hepatitis B virus (HPB), herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1) and Thogoto virus (THOV) target the general transcription factor TFIIB to regulate expression of viral-specific genes during pathogenicity. PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Project Narrative Due to the lack of model systems, it has been difficult to study complex gene-environment interactions in Parkinson's disease. Using a combination of Drosophila genetics and patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells, we can develop a model that can be utilized to identify and study the mechanisms of interaction among GWAS candidate genes, environmental factors, and α-synuclein. This K99/R00 proposal aims to characterize a novel interaction among LRRK2, rotenone, and α-synuclein, study the mechanism of the interaction, and subsequently validate this novel multiplex system, which can be used to study these previously unknown interactions among environmental and genetic factors and is a step towards personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative from the Parent Award Potassium channels are membrane proteins that catalyze the transfer of K+ ions down an electrochemical gradient with high efficiency and selectivity. Understanding of voltage-dependent K+ channel structure and function relates directly to health and disease. Their function has been associated with such basic cellular functions as the regulation of electrical activity, signal transduction and osmotic balance. K+ channels are members of the voltage-dependent channel superfamily, which include explicitly voltage-activated channels (Na+, Ca2+, and a large number of K+ channels), as well as voltage-independent channels (i.e., the inward rectifiers and the cyclic nucleotide activated channels). The sub-family of non-domain swapped K+ channels include a great deal of functional diversity, including depolarization activated (EAG, hERG), hyperpolarization-activated (KAT1, HCN), and dual voltage and Ca2+ activation (BK). In higher organisms, dysfunctions associated to these channels may lead to uncontrolled periods of electrical hyperexcitability, like epileptic episodes and cardiac arrhythmias. Not surprisingly, voltage-dependent channels are also the target of many therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative for the SEAL (Stopping Eczema and ALlergy) Study Food allergy (FA) is an Epidemic among children throughout the world. The overall objective of our current SEAL (Stopping Eczema and Allergy) study is to prevent allergy by enhancing the skin barrier with proactive skin care utilizing the combination of skin emollient early in life with topical anti-inflammatory agents as required to decrease epicutaneous allergen sensitization and FA. The effectiveness of this prevention strategy will be monitored by novel measures of skin barrier function and the emergence of protective immune responses in infants and young children benefiting from our novel preventative approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Log2Lose is a clinical trial that seeks to evaluate whether people lose more weight when they receive small financial incentives for weekly weight loss or diet logging. Study software collects and analyzes weight data from a cellular-connected scale and dietary data from a smartphone dietary application (‘app’). Algorithms analyze these data to determine if participants meet the criteria to receive an incentive. Participants receive a text message about whether they earned an incentive, and, if so, receive payment on a debit card.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metal–protein interactions are essential for the function of at least one-third to one-half of all proteins in cells. The incorrect binding of a metal to a protein, however, can lead to harmful effects on the cell, including toxicity. This proposal requests resources for the purchase of liquid chromatography instrumentation for protein purification to support NIH-funded research in an R01 grant (GM145035- 01A1) to identify the protein targets of metal stress and elucidate molecular mechanisms that lead to toxicity. The outcomes will advance our understanding of how proteins across the proteome respond to exposure to excess levels of biologically relevant Zn and Cu, with important implications for developing pharmacological agents to leverage metal stress against microbial pathogens and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eukaryotes sense nutrients via the TARGET OF RAPAMYCIN (TOR) signaling hub to coordinate healthy growth and development; because of its central role in biology, dysregulation of TOR signaling causes or contributes to a broad range of human diseases, including cancers, age-related health decline, and metabolic disorders. Developing focused therapeutics that target disease-causing TOR signaling pathways without hampering healthy TOR-dependent growth and development will require a deep mechanistic and evolutionary understanding of the TOR signaling network. This project will take an innovative approach by elucidating how TOR senses amino acids in plant cells through an aminoacyl tRNA synthetase, illuminating how tRNA synthetases gain noncanonical roles in cells and contributing fresh perspective to ongoing debates about the relative roles and contributions of proposed mammalian amino acid sensors for TOR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Title: Investigating and improving performance of polygenic scores for cardiometabolic traits in Samoan adults Project Period: 2024-09-01 – 2026-08-31 The clinical utility of polygenic scores (PGSs) in individuals of Pacific Islander ancestry is unknown due to a paucity of Pacific Islanders participating in studies of PGSs. Therefore, the primary focus of this supplement is to provide the first ever examination of existing and development of PGSs of cardiometabolic traits in Pacific Islanders. This project will provide the first ever characterization of the portability of existing PGSs for Polynesian populations which will inform clinical interpretation of these PGSs among individuals with Polynesian ancestry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: *The current equipment supplement request will not modify the original scope of funded research. Chemical damage to DNA is a major source of replication stress that can induce genome instability and drive the progression of cancer and ageing. This proposal investigates the mechanisms that enable the cellular DNA replication machinery to tolerate and repair DNA damage. Insights generated by this work may therefore inform the development of interventions that modulate replication stress to treat cancer and genetic diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Section  A combined chemical and genetics-based approach is being developed for the discovery of highly domain selective bromodomain inhibitor molecules for the epigenetic proteins BRD4 and BPTF. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to determine the molecular requirements for healthy skeletal muscle function, in order to pave the way for discovery and design of more effective therapies for muscle disease and weakness. Our work will answer crucial questions about how the protein myosin-binding protein C (MyBP-C), a cause of distal arthrogryposis, functions in skeletal muscle, using reporter probes to visualize dynamic protein structures in contracting muscle cells. This research will greatly improve the human health prospects for understanding disease by determining effects of disease mutations and developing tools that can be used to discover novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Of the many examples of cellular trans-differentiation and reprogramming in the research literature, very few if any efficiently generate new cells that exhibit terminal differentiation suitable for cellular therapeutics and disease modeling. In the past funding periods of my two grants that converge into this R35 application, our laboratory has found that genes residing in particular varieties of chromosomal condensation, known as H3K9me3-heterochromatin, are refractory to activation during trans-differentiation and reprogramming. The present application uses a research environment for diversity, equity, and inclusion to bring together diverse technologies and cellular systems to understand how gene regulatory proteins overcome the heterochromatin barrier and to apply the information to create more differentiated cells for therapeutics and disease modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Islet transplantation replaces the lost insulin-producing pancreatic islet beta cells due to type 1 diabetes. However, this therapy is not widely used because of its variable efficacy and the requirement for life-long immunosuppression that can lead to a whole host of problems. We will tackle these issues using genetic engineering to help islet to withstand the stress of transplantation and resist immune attacks. The goal is to develop strategy for highly efficient islet transplantation without the need of immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to provide high-quality survivorship care to the rapidly growing population of adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors. The new National Standards for Cancer Survivorship Care provide a robust framework for developing and assessing survivorship care programs across and within U.S. healthcare systems. We will leverage our existing large contemporary cohort of AYA cancer survivors cared for within Kaiser Permanente to: 1) Examine the availability of the new National Standards within KP; 2) Assess referral to and utilization of recommended National Standards within our KP AYA cancer survivor cohort; the proposed work will be a supplement to our current program grant (P01CA233432).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of the parent grant is to dissect the evolution of the multi-protein, multi-functional protein complexes formed by Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4). TLR4 is an important driver for inflammation in both healthy and pathological contexts. It evolved the ability to form complexes with a wide variety of protein partners. The equipment supplement will be used to acquire instrumentation that will allow us to directly study the assembly of these complexes and thus better understand their biochemistry and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project examines the phytochromes, a superfamily of photoreceptors that can detect to a broad range of colors and can transmit that information to the cell to control many aspects of biology. Plant phytochromes are a major stumbling block in improving agricultural yield by mediating the shade avoidance response caused by competition for light among neighboring plants, while their bacterial relatives have proven a valuable source of imaging reagents for biomedical research and of photosensory reagents for synthetic control of cellular processes with light. Work under this project will provide new insight into color tuning, the usage of light energy, the integration of light with signals such as temperature and pH, and the transmission of information within these photoreceptors and to the rest of the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic medicine seeks to improve clinical outcomes and public health, and identification of clinically actionable inherited genetic conditions before symptoms manifest can enable physicians to intervene earlier and achieve these goals. The newborn screening program exemplifies this paradigm but is limited to a narrow subset of conditions relevant at birth, thereby missing the opportunity to identify many other similarly actionable conditions. Given the many challenges associated with clinical whole genome sequencing in the newborn period, we propose to expand the scope of genomic screening by offering parents targeted sequencing of their children at distinct time-points during development, to discover actionable genetic conditions when that information would have the greatest relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the support of our current award, we are investigating microscale mechanisms through which cells generate force and change shape during polarization and motility, particularly through confined spaces in tissue. Accomplishing these goals requires high-resolution and long-term live-cell imaging capabilities, and our laboratory's live-cell imaging system is nearly 20 years old and beginning to fail. We therefore request funding to support purchase of a brand new, state-of-the art optical imaging system that will greatly enhance our ability to execute and even transcend our originally proposed studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults diagnosed with sarcopenia (e.g., loss of muscle mass, strength, and function) or frailty, are typically prescribed at-home resistance-based exercises to maintain and enhance physical function. Such prescriptions rely on self-report patient compliance to confirm whether the exercises are conducted and whether their exercise fidelity is sufficient to promote functional recovery. Herein, we propose to optimize the BandPass system, a Bluetooth-enabled resistance exercise band, patient app, clinician dashboard, and a cloud-based infrastructure that automatically senses the continuous force exerted during exercises to enable remote monitoring, compliance checking, and exercise classification while helping to overcome the current gaps of clinically tailored home exercise programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall X-ray crystallography, solution scattering and X-ray footprinting are critical tools in the study of biological systems. They provide information that has been a prerequisite to understanding the fundamentals of life. They are also methods that have proved themselves to be central to the development of new therapeutics for human disease. The overarching goal of this proposal is to provide an integrated synchrotron Resource that makes mature technologies available to a broad research community. This will lead to more insightful biological interpretation and better drugs to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will systematically explore epistatic interactions that drive evolution of antibiotic resistance with the ultimate goal of developing novel antibiotics and antibiotic treatment strategies that select against resistance. Towards this goal, we will study molecular evolution of the dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) enzyme in Escherichia coli under antibiotic selection, and engineer mutant-specific competitive and allosteric DHFR inhibitors that can select against resistance-conferring DHFR mutations. Finally, we will develop and synthesize a novel class of molecules that we named “-lactamase traps” (or BLTs) to select against -lactamase genes in Gram-negative bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Oxygen metabolism is mediated by several metalloenzymes, and one of the most complicated and least understood of these is the oxygen-evolving complex in photosystem II containing a manganese-calcium cluster, which is the only enzyme in nature that is capable of oxidizing H2O to O2. This proposal is directed towards using the newly available ultra-fast X-ray free electron laser, to take snapshots of the geometric and electronic structural changes of photosystem II and its metal center, in real time under physiological conditions, to understand the mechanism of water oxidation and oxygen evolution, and extending our studies to the study of other related Fe/Mn/Ni containing metalloenzymes of importance.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Many transcription factors perform diﬀerent functions in diﬀerent cell types throughout animal development and dysregulation of this process can lead to human pathologies such as developmental disorders and cancer. This project will explore how cell type-speciﬁc protein-protein interactions allow the Drosophila Hox transcription factor Ultrabithorax (Ubx) to perform distinct chromatin remodeling activities in diﬀerent cell types. The proposed studies will provide insight into how a single transcription factor functions to specify multiple cell types throughout animal development.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Trauma-related nightmares in Veterans are associated with poor clinical outcomes, greater substance use, and increased risk of suicide. In spite of an urgent need to reduce the burden of trauma-related nightmares, the underlying physiological changes accompanying their occurrence are poorly understood, and there are no clear evidence-based recommendations for their treatment. Limitations of current assessment procedures represent a barrier to improved care. In-laboratory sleep studies infrequently capture nightmares, limiting our knowledge of phenotypic markers and their response to treatment. This CDA-2 addresses these limitations by using extended, in-home sleep monitoring to capture physiological parameters associated with nightmare reports in Veterans, and assessing how these physiological features are altered throughout a cognitive- behavioral nightmare treatment. Results from this CDA-2 will increase understanding of trauma-related nightmare pathophysiology, and advance strategies for personalizing symptom management in Veterans.

PHR: Project Narrative: This project seeks to describe the basic principles that govern maternal RNA recognition and regulation in early development. Analysis of how post-transcriptional regulatory mechanisms, and more broadly how maternally supplied proteins and mRNAs, contribute to cell fate specification events in early development will ultimately lead to a better understanding of how developmental processes fail in disease. This project focuses on regulation mediated by the 3’UTR of maternal RNAs, and includes a variety of experiments to establish which regulatory events are most important for reproductive health, and how regulation works at a mechanistic level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The efforts of my research program have been directed at probing the actions of membrane receptors and their G protein signaling partners that influence cell growth, differentiation, and development. These studies have culminated in a series of exciting new discoveries that describe how these signal transduction pathways are linked to the assembly of multi-protein complexes that regulate the metabolic activities of cells and the biogenesis of extracellular vesicles, important in embryonic stem cell function, differentiation, cellular senescence and aging, and infectious disease. By probing the signaling mechanisms that regulate these metabolic complexes and the biogenesis and function of extracellular vesicles, together with elucidating their structural features, we expect to gain new insights into the critical roles they play in a broad spectrum of biology and disease, as well as highlight new targets and strategies for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness throughout the world, and there are currently no options for restoration of vision in persons with blindness caused by this disease. Here we propose a series of novel strategies to advance the audacious goal of replacing retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), the output nerve cells of the eye, which form the optic nerve and are damaged in glaucoma. We will systematically test a series of manipulations to enhance the survival and integration of human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived RGCs in the glaucomatous retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The proposed studies focus on small extracellular vesicles secreted by wound macrophages in sites of injury that regulate stromal cells by suppressing the inflammation phase to promote re- epithelialization. We hypothesize that a mechanistic understanding of how small extracellular vesicles are formed, what contents are biologically active, and which cells uptake these vesicles is critical for the over-arching goal of developing extracellular vesicles that have therapeutic potential by promoting the resolution of inflammation and wound closure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Transgender women are among the groups in the United States at highest risk for HIV, as well as hazardous substance misuse, due in part to elevations in three interrelated areas underpinned by stigma and lack of gender affirmation: internalized stigma, psychological distress, and healthcare avoidance. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), which has been shown to reduce internalized stigma, psychological distress, and improve treatment engagement, may thus improve substance misuse and HIV risk. By employing a user-centered design approach to adapt, design, and test a peer-delivered gender affirming ACT intervention to improve substance misuse and HIV risk in transgender women, this K99/R00 proposal answers a compelling need for sustainable delivery of evidence-based programming in transgender-serving community-based organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Using Bionano’s optical mapping technology we are taking a novel approach to understand the structure and organization of the 22q11.2 region deleted in 22q11.2DS and duplicated in 22q11.2 duplications, significant pediatric disorders. We will examine the prevalence and role of various inversion polymorphisms and copy number variants as risk factors for these and other genomic disorders of 22q11.2 in several populations (CEU, African and African Americans) including parent/ affected child trios of 22q11DS subjects. In order to continue carrying out this proposed research we need to purchase a Generation 2 Saphyr System from Bionano Genomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to develop new transition metal-catalyzed methods that are general, user-friendly, and have a significant impact on the field of organic synthesis, particularly in pharmaceutical research. Our current work is focused on palladium and copper-catalyzed coupling methods for the formation of carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds. We specialize in creating highly functionalized molecules reliably and our techniques are widely adopted in academia and industry for synthesizing complex compounds. Our research heavily relies on analytical instruments, notably the GCMS. The GCMS plays a pivotal role in analyzing reaction mixtures, monitoring progress and elucidating mechanisms. Our current GCMS system has become outdated and in need of extensive repairs, necessitating a replacement. A new GCMS system will enhance the efficiency and reliability of our research, facilitating our work in the development of new reaction methodology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Longstanding neuroscience evidence is consistent that olfactory, other sensory, sensorimotor, and motor impairments often precede cognitive impairments in AD, thereby presenting an alternative strategy for detection of people at risk of progressive cognitive decline. The small business, Evon Medics created a prototype called EMRAST (Evon Medics Rapid Smell Test for AD), to perform culture- and language- independent smell tests for AD screening. This project will further product development to allow the: (1) incorporation of physiological monitoring and motor processing sensors and a sniff magnitude test, which we recently showed to signal an irreversible phase of AD progression when impaired; (2) development of machine learning/Artificial Intelligence algorithms to compute the EMRAST metrics into prediction of AD; (3) optimization of size, cost reductions, test functionality, durability, and hardware complexity for large-scale manufacturing; (4) demonstration of clinical validity in large samples; and (5) advancement of regulatory pathway to lead to adoption of optimized EMRAST (i.e., EMRAST-Extended) for clinical and community screening and prediction of AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Exon Junction Complex (EJC) and Nonsense-Mediated mRNA Decay (NMD) components lie at the heart of a eukaryotic mRNA surveillance mechanism that monitors ribosomes during translation to suppress genetic errors and regulate normal gene expression. To answer the long-standing question of how these mRNA surveillance machineries engage with the ribosome, we have identified mutations that arrest the key NMD components on the ribosomes. The Biocomp gradient fractionation system requested here will be used to purify these ribosome-associated surveillance complexes to determine their genome-wide locations and protein composition, thereby advancing the project proposed in the parent grant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this supplement project is to use a 3D ex vivo ovarian follicle culture model to study the female reproductive toxicity and molecular mechanisms of real-world surface river water organic matter extracts. These studies are critically important to reveal novel insight into chemical mixtures-induced ovarian toxicity and prioritize chemicals of high ovotoxicity concern and for further risk assessment for protecting women’s reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: DNA recombination is essential for chromosome stability, for antibody diversification, for gene targeting that has broad application in the medical field, and is highly relevant to many human disorders, cancer, and aging. This project will address fundamental questions about the mechanism and control of recombination, focusing on the formation of the initial recombination intermediate, single-stranded DNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chromatin replication is a complex cellular process that requires multiple regulatory mechanisms to maintain genomic and epigenomic stability. The histone H3.1-TSK/TONSL pathway plays a major role in resolving stalled or broken replication forks via homologous recombination. We will further characterize the role of H3.1- TSK/TONSL in regulating DNA repair and genome stability, and define new functions for this conserved pathway during replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Mitochondrial permeability transition is stress-induced damage to the mitochondrial inner membrane that disrupts mitochondrial function and leads to cell death. Our proposal aims to investigate molecular mechanisms underlying permeability transition. This knowledge will help to understand one of the central pathological events that cause damage during the stroke and heart attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative Little is known on the regulatory pathways mediating transgenerational epigenetic inheritance. Our results provide genetic evidence for a novel pathway in mice that regulates high fat diet response in the next generation and that is governed by the E3 ligase Rlim in paternal testicular Sertoli cells. Investigating this Sertoli cell --> sperm --> offspring pathway, our research will uncover novel epigenetic mechanisms and establish our conditional Rlim KO mice as a new paradigm for transgenerational epigenetic regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) is essential to maintain genome integrity and to guard against cancer in humans. We will use the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae model system to address the mechanisms of DSB repair; specifically, we will determine how repair proteins interacts with chromatin remodeling complexes to process DSB ends, and define the roles of the Mre11 complex and nucleosome assembly factors in repair of collapsed replication forks. In the long term we believe that mechanisms under investigation in this proposal will provide new insight and fundamental knowledge for understanding disease caused by genomic instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE DNA nanostructures have promise in biomedical applications such as biosensing, drug delivery and bioimaging, but the field faces several challenges for it to be used in practical applications. In addressing these challenges, I propose to develop robust, multifunctional drug delivery platform for treating multisystemic diseases and design self-assembled 3D DNA crystals as scaffolds for X-ray structure determination using the new technique of Serial Femtosecond X-ray Crystallography. In the long-term, I envision that our modular, platform technology using DNA nanostructures can be adopted by other labs for different disease treatments and drug screening and to obtain crystallographic information of hard-to-crystallize molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This longitudinal observational study examines multiple levels of Structural Racism and Discrimination (SRD) including individual (both intrapersonal and interpersonal), neighborhood, institutional, and societal/policy and their associations with mental, physical, and behavioral health outcomes across the life course. Innovative mixed-methods (e.g., ecological momentary assessment, geographic information system data, community- based participatory approaches, biomarkers) are being used at two sites (Minnesota, Georgia), across two time points 18 months apart, with families from racially/ethnically and socioeconomically diverse households (n=927). Study findings will identify targets for intervening at multiple SRD levels to promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Halide-containing nucleosides and nucleotides represent an important family of synthetic drugs for anticancer and antiviral treatments, thus it is essential to develop novel and effective synthetic strategies to expand halogenated nucleoside/nucleotide compound library for drug discovery. Radical halogenation via carbon- hydrogen bond activation catalyzed by iron and 2-oxoglutarate (Fe/2OG) dependent enzymes represents an attractive strategy to install carbon-halide bonds in a regio- and stereo-specific fashion. In this projects, two newly discovered Fe/2OG enzymes that catalyze radical halogenation to generate halide-containing nucleotide natural products and amino acids will be mechanistically investigated, the obtained mechanistic insights will be further deployed to develop these enzymes into biosynthetic platform to access new halide-containing nucleotide/nucelosides.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Roles of ribonucleic acids (RNAs) for diverse functions in cellular processes continue to be discovered, calling for sophisticated approaches to investigate these central molecules in living cells. The requested FLIM upgrade of an existing confocal microscope will allow us to advance these research goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The goal of the project that this supplement supports is to use engineered extracellular matrix environments leveraging structural and mechanical control over the extracellular matrix to examine the mechanisms by which cells respond to multiple directional migration cues. Cell migration plays an important role in many physiological and pathological processes such as wound healing, development and cancer invasion. Frequently migration is not simply random, but directed towards targets through recognition of aligned extracellular matrix fibers or gradients in stiffness, generating contact guidance and durotaxis, respectively. In many biological contexts these cues are presented simultaneously, forcing cells to integrate this information. For instance, gradients of stiffness and aligned collagen are generated within the wound bed to direct dermal fibroblast migration. Similar fiber structures and gradients stimulate cancer cell migration out of the tumor microenvironment and normal cells including stromal and immune cells towards the tumor microenvironment. While there is a firm understanding of how cells respond to individual directional cues, virtually nothing is known about how cells integrate multiple cues and make migrational decisions based on that integration. Furthermore, there is a hypothesis that contact guidance and durotaxis are overlapping directional cell migration mechanisms, but this has not been rigorously tested. Mechanistic understanding of multi-cue directional migration will require a refined understanding of how the F-actin and microtubule networks operates. Indeed, some evidence suggests that contact guidance and durotaxis may use slightly different F-actin network structures, since contact guidance is thought to be governed by F-actin fiber structures, but durotaxis is not. Engineering approaches will be taken to design in vitro environments that allow for independent tuning of contact guidance and durotaxis in both 2D and 3D environments. Furthermore, the effect of F-actin branching, bundling and contraction in allowing cells to prefer aligned fibers of collagen or gradients of stiffness will be tested. This will uncover shared or competing molecular pathways involved when these two directional migration cues are present in isolation and together. Understanding how cells migrate in response to multiple cues has broad impact on several biomedical fields including tissue engineering and disease therapeutics. Determining how cells respond to multiple cues in vitro will allow us to predict cell responses in wound healing, development, cancer invasion and immune response leading to drug candidates as in cancer or strategies to enhance wound healing and immune response. This goal of this supplement is to purchase a microscope system that will expand our capabilities for live-cell imaging of cell migration and cytoskeletal dynamics. We currently have two older Nikon microscopes that have some limitations. First, the microscope that allows for fluorescence imaging has several issues including a broken filter wheel turret and malfunctioning mirror that automatically flips from Total Internal Reflection Fluorescence (TIRF) mode to epifluorescence mode. This limits the live cell fluorescence imaging we can do. Second, our Photometrics HQ2 CCD that was on that microscope was damaged after a mercury arc lamp bulb rupture. We have since purchased a Photometrics Moment camera, which is a good camera for fixed images, but its sensitivity is much less than the HQ2, diminishing our ability to capture cytoskeletal dynamics in live cells. Third, we do not have ability to access multiple positions during one imaging experiment, because our stage is only a mechanical stage and is not motorized. This tremendously hampers our ability to collect data in a high throughput manner. Finally, while we have successfully used heated stages and closed chambers for imaging live cells, this approach limits the type of media you can use and the length of imaging time. We would like to purchase an environmental control chamber to regulate humidity, temperature and CO2 percentage to allow for control over these very important cell culture conditions and to give us flexibility to image cells over our current window of eight hours. In addition to migration, the multi-positional acquisition and environmental control will allow us to better screen clones of formin and other cytoskeletal CRISPR knock-outs that we are developing. These reasons coupled with the fact that both our microscopes are over twelve years result in relatively high cost for upgrading an old system. Our ability to image cell migration and cytoskeletal dynamics in a high throughput manner and in a more natural environment will support the successful completion of the project.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Sexually transmitted infection (STI) rates have been rising at an alarming rate globally for the past decade, indicating that current STI prevention paradigms are not working and that new strategies are urgently needed. Recent open-label studies demonstrated that doxycycline 200mg within 72 hours of STI exposure (doxycycline prophylaxis [doxyPEP]) resulted in 47-66% reduction in STIs among sexual minority men (SMM) and transgender women (TW), which has led to the endorsement of doxyPEP as an option for biomedical STI prevention by public health authorities. The goal of this open-label, randomized trial is to assess efficacy of doxycycline prophylaxis (doxyPEP) to reduce incidence of bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs) while also balancing acceptability and resistance to inform public health policy regarding doxyPEP use among people assigned female sex at birth (AFAB).

Inflammatory mediators present in the periphery must be encoded and signaled up to the brain through sensory neurons, but how this neural representation happens is unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative – public health relevance  Perturbation of inositol metabolism is associated with pathologies as diverse as psychiatric and neurological illnesses, myopathies, cancer, and diabetes. The proposed studies will lead to the first molecular model of regulation of inositol synthesis in mammalian cells and demonstrate how inositol deprivation affects mitochondrial function and the cellular stress response. The identification of specific pathways that are perturbed as a result of inositol deprivation will provide insights into the tumor-suppressive effects of upregulating inositol synthesis and may suggest candidates for new mood stabilizing inositol-depleting drugs for the treatment of bipolar disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative  Preoperative exercise therapy (PET) is a highly applicable non-pharmacological-based therapy and has successfully reduced postoperative complications and conferred better recovery from major liver surgery. This Supplement project will utilize the new multi-lane metabolic & telemetric treadmill system tp determine the mechanisms by which PET modulates anti-inflammatory trained immunity in hepatic resident macrophages (Kupffer cells) via activating the cholinergic anti-inflammatory pathway to prevent liver ischemia/reperfusion injury. PHR: Narrative The computational methodologies we develop will be applicable to a broad set of metalloenzymes and proteins of biomedical relevance. In particular, we target fundamental mechanistic problems in enzymes that catalyze nucleic acids synthesis/modification and lipid metabolism, since mutations in these enzymes are implicated in numerous human diseases such as cancer, insulin resistance and diabetes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The discovery of BRAF as a major driver of human cancers led to a substantial clinical success of current BRAF therapies, however, the incomplete understanding of various biological processes that RAF kinases participate has hindered the development of more effective BRAF drugs. We propose to integrate chemical, biochemical, and biophysical tools together with mass spectrometry and cell imaging to address the molecular mechanisms of RAF activation and regulation in normal and disease conditions, specifically cancer. Our findings will provide fundamental insights into how RAF kinases operate at the molecular level and will have an impact on the treatment of BRAF-driven cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: ProjectNarrative- Parent Award This innovative proposal will address financial wellbeing, an often overlooked but important factor impacting reentry for justice-involved people with mental health challenges, who are disproportionately Black and Latinx. This project will change community level determinants by integrating financial capability supports (one-on-one coaching and access to financial tools and services) into existing services, and training bank and credit union staff to reduce discrimination. It will also support collaborative community efforts working towards upstream policy and legal reforms to reduce the incidence of those financial challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells allocate substantial resources towards monitoring their energy level, and appropriately adjust energy generation rates based on the metabolic demand and nutrients status to maintain homeostasis. This proposal aims to understand how cellular metabolic state regulates mitochondrial function and dynamics, and how it contributes to bioenergetics in the cells. These studies will produce important insights into the biochemical pathways that underlie neuronal functions, cell migration in cancer and wound healing, nervous system development, nutritional and mitochondrial disorders, and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Dynamic rearrangements of the actin cytoskeleton are essential to all eukaryotic cells. Defects in actin regula- tion are associated with various diseases, ranging from immunodeficiency and neurodevelopmental disorders to cancer metastasis and pathogen infection. The proposed research will determine the fundamental mecha- nisms of central actin regulators known as the Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome Protein (WASP) family proteins, which will lay the foundation for understanding how actin remodeling is dysregulated in diseases and can be treated therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The parent research program seeks to elucidate cell type and tissue specific molecular mechanisms that drive the progression of disease in patients with viral illnesses and to subsequently identify new targets for therapeutic invention. This grant supplement is for the acquisition of the CFX Opus 384 Real-Time PCR System that will enable precise quantitative measurements and ultra-sensitive quantitation of nucleic acid levels to study cellular processes. Accurate measurement of cellular processes, including quantitation of specific levels of cellular RNA and DNA, will provide unbridled insight into biologic function. We assert that our ability to study fundamental biologic processes, to aid in completion of our research objectives, will be greatly enhanced by the routine use of this PCR system to validate results from other scientific approaches that will be employed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Growth factors are biochemical signals that regulate diverse cellular functions including proliferation, differentia- tion, or metabolic activity. This proposal seeks to develop new reagents and methods to selectively activate or suppress the activity of these signals with spatial and temporal control by tailoring their interactions at the sur- faces of cells. Once established, the tools will enable new biological discoveries and cell-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The focus of this supplement is the purchase of a preparative-scale supercritical fluid chromatography (SFC) instrument. This will greatly enhance the development of Ni-catalyzed synthetic methods, the focus of the parent NIH award, by allowing the isolation of products that are currently inseparable and increasing the number of substrates that can be evaluated. Overall, the project aligns with the NIH's mission to improve human health because it will provide crucial instrumentation to aid in the development of more efficient methods for discovering and synthesizing pharmaceuticals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black emerging adults (ages 18-28 years) have the highest risks of insufficient sleep and cardiovascular disease, but little is known about how and why these disparities exist. Our project will examine associations between measures of insufficient sleep and race-related stress with measures of arterial stiffness and central hemodynamics (well-known risk factors for cardiovascular disease) in Black emerging adults. By focusing on emerging adulthood – when many individuals establish and solidify lifelong sleep and health behaviors – this project will take an essential first step towards understanding the role of sleep and race-related stress in shaping cardiovascular disease risk in Black adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ovarian cancer and pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) are two of the most lethal cancers and notoriously resistant to standard therapies. We have developed a dual-domain therapeutic, S2/IAPinh, that selectively delivers a drug cargo into cancer cells and induces enhanced tumor cell death. Recent experimental evidence suggests that S2/IAPinh, while far more effective than IAPinh alone, is insufficient to eradicate the tumors as a monotherapy. Here, we will explore a number of new avenues for successful combination cancer therapies.

PHR: Contact PD/PI: Freeman, Brian C PROJECT NARRATIVE  Homeostasis relies on precise and dynamic action by nuclear pathways including RNA transcription, DNA repair, and genome organization. While cooperative interactions between proteins and cofactors helps ensure selectivity, the events mediating the rapid action are less well understood. We believe molecular chaperones, especially the Hsp90 system, foster a highly dynamic nuclear environment that is critical for timely and effective DNA-associated pathways. Page 7 Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Small RNAs are critical regulators of gene expression and genome organization, pathways that are highly conserved across eukaryotic phylogeny. The goal of this project is to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of RNA silencing so we can better understand its role in human development and disease. In particular, a critical function of small RNAs is transposon silencing, which, if unregulated represents a major threat to genome integrity and is associated with infertility, birth defects, cancer, and other diseases.
