IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The parent program for this request (R35GM119518) seeks to understand proton-gated coincidence detection by G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), the largest and most therapeutically targeted class of human transmembrane receptors. A new program focus is the allosteric modulation of GPCR activity and pH sensitivity by coincident lipids using leading-edge mass spectrometry methodologies and instrumentation. The requested ThermoFisher SPD140P1 speed vacuum concentrator will enable us to extract the intact lipidome without oxidizing or degrading the lipids we seek to quantify.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop fundamental understanding of proton-coupled electron transfers and oxygen-atom transfer chemical reactions that are relevant to biology. For many years this work has relied on rapid-scanning diode array spectrophotometers, but our two old instruments of this type have stopped working and are no longer repairable. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Phospholipids such as phosphatidylethanolamine are not only fundamental building blocks of cellular and organellar autonomy but additionally have diverse essential biological functions. This proposal focuses on an evolutionarily conserved mitochondrial protein that produces phosphatidylethanolamine, is essential for vertebrate life, and for which there are presently many unresolved questions. As such, results derived from this project will further define the role of mitochondrial phospholipid metabolism in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: Project Narrative Defects in genes involved in replication stress response often lead to neurodevelopmental disorders and predisposition to cancer. The Coats Plus disease, caused by dysfunction of genes involved in combating replication stress, is a rare genetic disease characterized by developmental failure of multiple vital organs including brain, eye and GI tract. The proposed research aims to reveal a new signaling pathway regulating the cellular response to replication stress and is expected to yield new mechanistic insights into how cells protect genome stability during perturbed replication and how genome instability leads to disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE As part of the parent RO1 Grant propose to establish a Collaborative Program involving the basic research and development of the discorhabdin class of marine iminoquinone alkaloids as highly potent and selective controls for a diversity of diseases. Due to the lack of availability of the natural products through isolation from the Arctic sponges, studies have been designed to develop innovative natural product synthesis methodologies to facilitate their assessment in biological models and develop these highly unique alkaloid natural products as potential therapeutics. Aleutianamine possesses ideal features for the development of innovative synthesis methodologies and because the molecule is small, strained and may effectively penetrate unique tissue types and serve broadly as a model for effective disease management for a variety of diseases for which viable treatment options do not currently exist thus as part of this supplement we are proposing to acquire equipment to establish a state-of-the-art metabolomics and small molecules facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal investigates how mRNAs with early stop codons are repressed. The proposal focuses on the biochemistry and requirements for effectors of the mRNA cleavage step, and the role that ribosomes and the protein UPF1 have in mRNA targeting. Results from this work will illuminate mechanisms of translation and mRNA degradation for a class of genetic mutations (early stop codons) present in a substantial fraction (~11%) of disease-causing alleles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The inductive and morphogenetic processes that establish the vertebrate body plan during gastrulation must be coordinated in space and time to ensure normal development. We are investigating the molecular mechanisms through which the key regulators of gastrulation, including Gpr125 adhesion G Protein- Coupled Receptor, Wnt/Planar Cell Polarity and Dachsous, interact to coordinate gastrulation movements with embryo patterning. We will also take an unbiased genetic approach to identify new essential regulators of gastrulation. As mutations in the components of these pathways cause miscarriages, birth defects and diseases, our studies can advance their understanding, diagnosis and facilitate development of therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 40% of descendants from East Asia possess a genetic variant severely limiting their ability to metabolize reactive aldehydes. In addition, several other genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway also occur in Asians which may impact organ injury, particularly during surgery. This project will develop tools in the basic science laboratory to better understand how genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway may impact organ damage and translate these strategies to monitor and reduce organ damage in humans undergoing surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells maintain sophisticated mechanisms that ensure replicated chromosomes are accurately transmitted to daughter cells during division. When these mechanisms fail, cancer and other diseases are the result. The studies described in this grant examine an unsuspected and unexplored set of mechanisms that operate during the final stages of cell division (anaphase/telophase) to ensure accurate chromosome transmission.

PHR: Project Narrative Chronic rhinosinusitis is burden disease regulators enable  a disease of the sinonasa l airways that causes significant morbidity and economic but for which the etiology is unknown. In this proposal, we seek to define causative mechanisms for this through defining alterations in the structure and function of the nasal submucosal glands, as well as key of glandular development and remodeling in both mice and humans. Outcomes from this study will the design of therapeutics for the treatment and cure of this chronic and debilitating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Defects in embryonic patterning result in a variety of common birth defects (heart, orofacial, limb, etc) affecting nearly 3% of children born in the US. The genetic causes of these defects have been difficult to determine and a growing body of research points to defective gene regulation during embryonic development. This proposal seeks to understand how common and rare variation in regulatory sequences contribute to congenital heart defects and identify genes that they control during human heart organogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Some genetic diseases result not because cells make a defective protein component, but rather because they don’t make enough of the component. We have identified a widely applicable, targeted approach to induce cells to increase the protein output from a single ‘good’ copy of a gene. We aim to define all such clinically relevant targets, and to apply our existing knowledge to a mouse model of specific, incurable, fatal disease called pulmonary arterial hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This Diversity Supplement aims to characterize the developmental neurotoxicity (DNT) of lower-chlorinated polychlorinated biphenyls (LC-PCBs) and to assess how the route of exposure (dietary vs. inhalation) influences neurotoxic outcomes in weanling pups of rat dams exposed to PCB 28 during gestation and lactation. These studies are relevant to public health because they will provide data critically needed to assess the risk these emerging environmental contaminants pose to the developing brain and they will provide insights regarding strategies for mitigating this risk in vulnerable human populations. Moreover, this supplement will enhance the diversity of the scientific community that have the training needed to conduct rigorous scientific research focused on understanding how environmental stressors impact living systems in order to develop strategies for enhancing health and reducing the burden of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Notch signaling pathway has been implicated in a wide range of biological and pathological processes. Using the Drosophila ovarian model, the proposed studies will lead to improved understanding of the diverse effects and regulatory mechanisms of Notch signaling during development and tissue homeostasis. The findings from the proposed studies will help designing new therapeutic strategies for diseases related to aberrant Notch signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The overlying goal of the research program is to understand how timing of cell activities - patterning, signaling, and movement - is regulated in the Drosophila early embryo as development proceeds. In particular, the proposed experiments will investigate how initiation of zygotic gene expression is controlled; and how this results in the activation of cell signaling, including through FGFs, which is instrumental for the support of cell movements at gastrulation to transform the blastoderm embryo into multiple layers with distinct tissue types. This work has the potential to provide insight into how diverse cellular functions are coordinated to support normal embryonic development in higher animals, as the regulatory mechanisms are likely conserved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: TNF (tumor necrosis factor) is a critical innate immune response gene that has a profound impact on a number of autoimmune and infectious diseases outcomes. We have discovered long-range regulatory elements, which control expression of TNF in a cell-type specific manner. Understanding how these elements control TNF gene expression will provide fundamental knowledge about the regulation of TNF and potentially other genes and we expect will lead to novel and specific therapeutic strategies for autoimmune and infectious disease where TNF causes immune pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PARENT PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all cellular processes are influenced by small RNAs and their dysregulation has been implicated in fertility defects and disease. This study uses genetics and genomics to advance our understanding of how small RNAs control gene expression in the germline. The results will uncover new roles for small RNAs and mechanisms underlying small RNA function that preserve fertility and health from one generation to the next.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolism is the process by which food is converted into energy and the molecular building blocks necessary for life. It is highly dynamic and changes rapidly with different conditions, for example after a large meal or vigorous exercise. We can measure a great number of metabolites in chemical extracts or biofluids, but there are few methods to measure metabolites in living systems. This project is to develop a better method to measure metabolism in a living microorganism in different conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project is to investigate the molecular processes that control the association of protein tyrosine kinases with other cellular proteins. Dysregulation of these associations can lead to aberrant function in immunological response, cell proliferation or cell survival, and lead to disease including autoimmune disorders and cancer. The value of the research is to provide knowledge that can be used to either fuel future efforts to understand disease through biosensors or develop effective drugs against autoimmune disease or metastatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deciphering the complex coordination of transcription factor binding to cis-regulatory elements along DNA is fundamental to understand transcriptional regulation. Deep learning has demonstrated great promise at modeling functional genomics data, but it remains difficult to understand how they come to their decisions. This project will develop new model interpretability methods to decipher the motifs and their syntax learned by genomic DNNs, providing a suite of timely computational tools for the biomedical community that will have direct applications to fundamental problems in basic biological science as well as to the understanding and treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Metalloredox reactions lie at the heart of many key biological processes, from the one electron Fe2+/Fe3+ redox cycle in ferroptosis-associated neurodegenerative diseases and bacterial infection to the multi-electron enzymatic transformations that power biological respiration and the global nitrogen and sulfur cycles, but the structure-function relationships underpinning these phenomena are key gaps in our knowledge that hamper our ability to address significant health challenges. To fill these gaps, we propose to engineer i) novel metal ion sensors for the spatiotemporal imaging of metal ion redox states in biological systems, ii) protein-based structural and functional mimics of complex metalloenzymes responsible for multi-electron reactions, and iii) DNA-cleaving DNAzymes for smaller and more robust alternatives to restriction enzymes and CRISPR/Cas. Achieving these goals will not only advance our knowledge of redox processes in metalloproteins and biological systems, but also expand the toolbox for designing metalloenzymes, real-time diagnostic imaging of mobile metal ions, and customizable recombinant DNA cloning and high-fidelity genome editing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate diagnosis and assessment of brain metastases in patients with systemic cancers has important implications for patient prognosis and treatment strategy. The proposed two-way magnetic resonance tuning nanoprobes and complementary subtraction imaging technology with ultra-high tumor-to-normal tissue ratios will provide neuroradiology practice with a highly capable, accurate and consistent approach for detecting and evaluating early brain metastases. This new imaging technology has great potential to be translated in clinic to improve survival and reduce the mortality rate in patients with brain metastases in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Many characters of interest in biomedicine evolved long ago and are fixed in a particular species, distinguishing it from unaffected relatives; finding the genes underlying any such ancient trait has been a central challenge in the field. We have developed a method, RH-seq, for genetic dissection of interspecies trait variation, and applied it in invertebrate models. We now propose to study how species-defining alleles confer their effects, alone and together, in a yeast model system, and we propose to port our approaches for interspecies genetics to mouse cells, with a focus on cellular senescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Ribonucleases are enzymes that act on RNAs to process them to their mature, functional form, or to degrade them when they are no longer needed by the cell. A newly discovered ribonuclease in the model microorganism, Bacillus subtilis, is the prototype for a large family of similar proteins that are found in many bacterial organisms. Elucidating the structure and function of this ribonuclease could lead to the design of antibiotics that inhibit this enzyme and thereby reduce bacterial virulence. Project Narrative has not changed since original application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: NARRATIVE: In response to NOT-GM-24-021, we apply for a supplement to our ongoing NIGMS award 5R01GM148970- 02, “DMS/NIGMS 1: Topological Study on Histological Images and Spatial Transcriptomics”. We propose to extend the parent award by integrating the developed methods with state-of-the-art deep learning methodology, in order to produce more powerful topology- and gene-informed feature representation for spatial transcriptomics data. The method will use topological features and gene features as guidance for contrastive learning and teacher-student consistency learning so that histology image patches are mapped into a powerful topology- and gene-informed features. We expect such features will demonstrate strong prediction power in downstream tasks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop new types of fluorescent proteins, reporters and optogenetic tools for imaging, detection and light-regulation of molecular processes and interactions in mammalian cells, tissues and model animals. These probes will emit or be activated in the near-infrared spectral range where tissue transparency is the highest and will use the heme-derived compound biliverdin, naturally available in mammalian tissues, as the chromophore. The planned genetically encoded near-infrared optical probes will allow non-invasive visualization, sensing and light-control of the biochemistry and physiology of cells, organs and whole organisms in normal and pathological conditions, as well as spectral multiplexing with optical reagents of the visible range.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will enhance our capability to invent therapeutics and subsequently prepare these medicines on large-scale. Inspired by Nature’s catalyst, we develop ideal, environmentally friendly, and powerful ways to transform simple building blocks (aldehydes, alkenes, and alkynes) into architectures relevant to medicine. Our expertise in molecular design and synthesis will also be applied to address challenges at the interface of chemical theory, fluorescent microscopy, and drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will use high-throughput mutagenesis to map which amino acids in the protein sequence are essential for function and which subset of these are involved in communicating the coupling of DNA binding and ATP hydrolysis in a DNA polymerase clamp loader, a member of the family of complex molecular machines called AAA+ ATPases. We will also use statistical models trained on genome sequences of clamp loaders from diverse organisms to infer the essential constraints on and between amino acids in clamp loaders and test these inferences in a biological context. The aims of this project represent a unified body of work to use new assay systems to understanding clamp loader and AAA+ mechanism, and to test the potential for engineering complex macromolecular machines using our sequence-based design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Significant gaps exist in our understanding of how a suboptimal in utero environment impacts aging processes and trajectories. We have developed a unique cohort of baboons exposed in utero to maternal overnutrition in order to determine how this suboptimal environment during fetal developmental impacts aging in adult offspring. The requested bridge funds will cover animal per diems of the cohort that are central to our U19 program, which is essential for the U19 renewal resubmission, with maintained support essential to guarantee that these animals are not assigned to other studies at the Southwest National Primate Research Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Thomas, Susan Napier PROJECT NARRATIVE The lymphatic vasculature provides crucial functions for the maintenance of homeostasis in a variety of tissues and organs by providing the primary route through which immune cells, large proteins, lipids, and interstitial fluid are returned to the blood circulation. This proposed work seeks to utilize drug delivery strategies to 1) enhance lymphatic pumping via pharmacologic modulation of ion channels within the lymphatic muscle of the intact vasculature and 2) reduce the local inflammation through targeted immunomodulator delivery locally and to the lymph node downstream of the site of lymphedema. Findings from this work will lead to a new class of therapeutic strategies for regional enhancement of lymphatic pump function and reducing inflammation in lymphedema. Project Narrative Page 7

PHR: Project Narrative Blood pressure is lower in females than it is in males. We discovered that a receptor called OLFR558 is responsible for this sex difference. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on functional and mechanistic studies of a transport protein – OATP1B1 that is involved in the uptake of various endogenous molecules and drugs into hepatocytes, which is the first step in the process of drug processing in the liver. Due to the promiscuity of OATP1B1, various co-administered drugs could compete with each other, resulting in elevated plasma levels of the drugs, and risking adverse side effects. Also, some cancers overexpress OATP1B1 and it is the conduit through which anti-cancer medications or hormones that promote the growth of the cancers enter the cells. Thus, deciphering the structure and mechanism of OATP1B1 would advance our understanding of these processes, and aid in drug design that minimizes drug-drug interactions, which is relevant to the NIH’s mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Relevance to public health: Zinc is an essential nutrient that is critical for human health, since zinc deficiency and excess both cause a wide range of health problems. This research will determine how animals protect themselves against excess zinc by storing zinc in lysosomes, and how lysosomes are remodeled to accommodate zinc storage. These studies address novel aspects of the basic biology of lysosomes, which may be informative for lysosomal storage diseases in humans. Insights into mechanisms of zinc homeostasis may suggest new strategies for treating diseases caused by abnormal zinc metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Phosphoinositides (PIPs) are minor components of the eukaryotic membrane but major regulators of cellular functions. One of the cellular processes regulated by PIPs is autophagy, a process essential for a broad range of cellular functions and tissue development, and dysregulated in many human diseases. The proposed studies based on our recent discoveries will uncover novel mechanisms of PIP regulation of autophagy and potentially reveal new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Experimental insight into the mechanism of organic reactions is critical for the rational design of new and improved methodologies for the synthesis of medicinally relevant organic molecules. This proposal addresses this integral need by utilizing experimental and computational approaches to understand reaction mechanisms in two emerging areas of catalysis where new reaction discovery has far outpaced mechanistic understanding – (a) the conversion of abundant carbon-hydrogen bonds to valuable new carbon- carbon bonds commonly known as C-H functionalization; and (b) methodologies that combine nickel and photocatalysts to forge valuable new carbon-carbon or carbon-heteroatom bonds from inexpensive precursors.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanistic Studies at the Frontiers of Catalysis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States faces a critical challenge with climate change and worsening mental and behavioral health outcomes, with over 4 million deaths from suicide, assault, and psychoactive drug use in the last four decades, constituting 5% of all deaths. Disparities persist across sociodemographic group; climate-related stressors, particularly tropical cyclones, significantly influence mental health, potentially leading to anxiety, PTSD, intimate partner violence, and drug use behaviors. This project aims to characterize long-term trends and disparities in these deaths, assess the short-term impact of tropical cyclones, and evaluate the long-term effects of recurrent tropical cyclone exposure, leveraging robust data and advanced statistical methods to inform public health strategies and prioritize mental health resources for vulnerable communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: This project uses powerful biochemistry, pharmacology, and structural biology techniques to reveal how calcitonin family peptide hormones bind to their receptors on the surface of cells and develop novel tools for studying the receptors. The hormones regulate bone remodeling, vascular tone, blood glucose, and food intake and the receptors are drug targets for diseases including osteoporosis, migraine headache, cardiovascular disorders, and diabetes and obesity. Our studies will facilitate the development of therapeutics targeting these receptors and reveal concepts that are broadly relevant for several areas of human health and disease because the receptors are members of the large GPCR family that regulates most aspects of physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative High levels of cellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) are associated with macromolecular damage and the pathology of a wide-range of neurogenerative disorders and aging. At physiological levels, ROS play a central role in signaling through post-translational modifications, which serve to limit or cope with the potential damage associated with cellular ROS. Our work focuses on the identification and mechanistic characterization of ROS-based signaling pathways that help to manage ROS within healthy cells, to ultimately determine what changes in redox signaling are associated with the loss in ROS homeostasis associated with disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Molecular and Cellular Mechanisms of Copper-Dependent Nutrient Signaling and Metabolism PROJECT NARRATIVE The transition metal copper (Cu), which is acquired as a dietary nutrient, contributes to the balance between cell proliferation and cell death that is essential for life. An emerging paradigm in nutrient sensing and protein regulation, termed metalloallostery, whereby protein activity is controlled by Cu at non-catalytic sites has expanded the contribution of Cu to signaling events and enabled therapeutic exploitation of Cu-dependent disease associated cellular processes. This proposal will build on this new and clinically relevant signaling paradigm by delineating molecular and cellular mechanisms that underlie Cu-dependent adaptations to nutrient scarcity that are critical for sustaining energy balance for survival under physiological conditions and in diseases settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the success of cancer immunotherapy as a therapeutic modality, the majority of cancer patients do not benefit from this treatment. Studies of the mechanisms of response and resistance to immune checkpoint inhibitors in the tumors and blood of treated cancer patients and in murine models will provide insights that will guide the design of new combinatorial therapies. By understanding the precise immune cells that can be induced to kill tumor cells, we ultimately seek to translate our findings to develop more effective immunotherapies tailored to drive these cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research program is to develop computational methods that enhance the role of metabolomics in systems biology approaches for biomarker discovery. Specifically, statistical, network-based, and deep learning methods will be developed for ranking putative metabolite IDs and selection of metabolite biomarker candidates. The performance of the proposed methods for metabolite identification and biomarker selection will be evaluated by comparing them with other tools and through experimental methods including: (1) comparing the fragmentation patterns of unknown analytes against those from reference compounds; and (2) targeted quantitative analysis of selected analytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this Equipment Supplement is to purchase a benchtop fluorescence activated cell sorter to accelerate the objectives of the parent Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award (MIRA). The goal of the MIRA is to elucidate the role olfactory receptors (ORs) expressed outside the olfactory tissue play in human health and assess their potential as therapeutic targets. Olfactory receptors are a subtype of transmembrane proteins called G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), which are an important therapeutic target. As part of the proposed research, we also work towards understanding how GPCR signaling pathways talk to one another and the consequences of this crosstalk for human health, with the goal of enabling the development of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sociality is an essential component of animal behavior, and its deficits are closely associated with mental illnesses in humans, such as autism spectrum disorder. We previously discovered that the enzyme topoisomerase II alpha (Top2a) senses environmental toxicants and regulate social behavior through an epigenetic mechanism, but how does this pathway affect different cell types of the brain and what are the downstream targets of this pathway remain poorly understood. This diversity supplement aims to support an eligible postdoctoral researcher to answer these questions using cutting edge single-cell multimodal omics (transcriptomics and epigenomics) approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative GPCR-mediated signaling pathways play a key role in all physiological systems as well as pathophysiological conditions including cancer, immune disorders, cardiovascular diseases, metabolic disorders (e.g. obesity, diabetes), pain and addiction. Over 30% of all prescription drugs on the market act via these receptors. The structural biology study of the human GPCR family will result in developing a deeper and thorough understanding of molecular mechanisms of ligand recognition and receptor function, which should translate into development of more efficient therapeutics with diminished side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Functional metagenomic screening of stool samples for novel bacterial steroidogenic enzymes necessitates a dedicated analytical instrument to allow the throughput our project requires. This instrument should be able to separate steroid isomers and determine mass and generate daughter ions that serve as “fingerprints” to assist in identification. ThermoFisher Vanquish Flex UHPLC coupled with VWD & IR, and TSQ Fortis Plus electrospray ionization (ESI) Triple Quadrupole MS will provide the platform we need to complete the parent project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative from the Parent Award Cell-adhesion receptors are key molecules for cellular communication and have emerging functions in numerous cellular processes. The research proposed in this application will yield key insights into fundamental molecular mechanisms that underlie the function of two poorly understood families of cell-adhesion receptors in multicellular organisms (namely the 33 adhesion G Protein-Coupled Receptors (aGPCRs) and the four teneurins). This research will provide critical knowledge into the molecular mechanisms of intercellular communication, and since many aGPCRs and teneurins are found mutated in neurological disorders and cancers, this research is expected to provide crucial clues for the development of novel strategies to understand and treat these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The Integrated Stress Response (ISR) signaling pathway helps cells adapt to various conditions of stress, and abnormal ISR signaling is associated with various metabolic and neurodegenerative diseases. This pathway simultaneously activates gene transcription and suppresses general mRNA translation. Here, we propose to determine how stress-responsive transcripts bypass mRNA translation blocks associated with ISR, and determine their significance in stress adaptation and disease manifestation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The supplement proposed the addition of wound care services provided by a trained nurse to a novel mobile, integrated PrEP intervention (Check It) that delivers on-site PrEP, peer navigation, and point of care drug checking. Check It aims to both increasing engagement of people who inject drugs (PWID) in the PrEP continuum and to reduce overdose. Adding wound care services is urgently needed given the prevalence among this population, driven by xylazine’s presence in the drug supply. Xylazine causes wounds that are significantly associated with elevated HIV risk among this vulnerable population. Check It is being evaluated by a longitudinal study (SCOPE) of PWID (N=500) that is collecting baseline and 18-month follow up data in four high drug-use areas zone where Check It will provide services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Alliance NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) Research Base conducts research in cancer prevention, cancer symptom control, and cancer care delivery with a special emphasis on minority, underserved, and older patients and with a strong commitment to building collegial relationships with NCORP Community sites and Minority/Underserved Community sites. The Alliance NCORP seeks to continue its mission into the next grant cycle of generating practice-changing research that directly and favorably impacts the lives of cancer patients and those at risk for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  RNA editing of transposable elements within cellular RNAs by the ADAR1 enzyme helps the cell distinguish between self and non-self RNAs. The Z-RNA binding domain of ADAR1 plays a role in that process, which remains uncharacterized. Our goal is to structurally, dynamically and geographically (across transcriptomes) characterize the formation of Z-RNA and their recognition by ADAR1, with repercussions on better understanding cancer and certain auto- immune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The delivery of survivorship care for young adults (ages 18-39) with cancer is often fragmented and poorly coordinated, resulting in suboptimal care and leaving these young adult survivors with persistent unmet needs. This supplement will leverage a fully enrolled clinical trial evaluating a psychosocial intervention to improve quality of life outcomes for young adults with cancer to examine how early survivorship care aligns with the National Standards for Cancer Survivorship Care and identify barriers and facilitators to obtaining high-quality care. Results will inform future interventions tailored to the needs of young adults with cancer to enhance survivorship care and quality of life outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Neural tube defects (spina bifida and anencephaly, for example) constitute the second-most common class of birth defects, resulting in significant suffering and monetary costs: ~$1 billion total in hospitalization costs for all US patients annually. This proposal seeks to understand mechanisms of apical constriction, a change in cell shape that contributes to successful neural tube closure, using C. elegans as a model for efficient investigation of cellular and molecular mechanisms. The long-term goal of the work is to understand fundamental mechanisms that can lay a foundation for future diagnosis and prevention of neural tube defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE RNA decay is critical for proper cellular functions and homeostasis. In this proposal, we exploit novel RNA sequencing methods to develop a mechanistic understanding of a conserved biological mechanism of co- translational mRNA decay known as “ribothrypsis”. Deciphering the biology of ribothrypsis will enhance our understanding of how gene dysregulation underlies human diseases, paving the way to the development of new RNA-based diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The research proposes to use dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) to improve the sensitivity in magic angle spinning NMR experiments which will lead to molecular structures with higher precision. In particular, we propose to apply high frequency DNP to familial amyloid systems whose structure we will determine and to high resolution multidimensional 17O experiments. We will develop instrumentation for the experiments, and new time domain methods for more rapid data acquisition the research will have a profound impact on structural biology, medical imaging and solution NMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calcium-mediated signaling through inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate receptors (IP3Rs) is essential for the regulation of numerous physiological processes. Deregulation of IP3Rs leads to pathological changes in calcium signaling and is implicated in the pathogenesis of diverse diseases including cancer, neurodegenerative, autoimmune, and metabolic diseases. The goal of the proposed study is to elucidate the molecular mechanism of IP3R activity and regulation paving the road for development of novel therapeutic agents to control IP3R activity in the diseased state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Project narrative Because K+ selective ion channels are essential regulators of cell excitability, their dysfunction underlies a myriad of human pathological conditions that make them excellent targets for drugs to treat very diverse diseases, such as: LQT syndrome, arrhythmia, epilepsy, autoimmune diseases and diabetes. It follows that understanding the function-structure correlations of K+ channels at atomic resolution will pave the road to develop highly-specific therapeutic drugs to correct channelopathies. The central tenet of this grant application is how the structure determine the function of ion channel and how this relationship is influenced by the cell membrane lipid composition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Approximately 65% of Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients experience neuropsychiatric symptoms (NPS), which are associated with accelerated disease progression, greater functional impairment, higher caregiver burden, and earlier institutionalization. Current treatments for these NPS have limited efficacy and high rates of adverse side effects, highlighting the urgent need for safe, effective treatments. To nominate potential therapeutic targets, we propose to investigate the genetic and molecular basis of NPS in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator: Wu, Xiaohua Investigating DNA double-strand break repair mechanisms in mammalian cells Project Narrative  Gross chromosomal rearrangement (GCR) is a hallmark of cancer cells, and DNA double- strand breaks (DSBs) are a major source of GCR. Given that microhomology sequences are often present at chromosomal rearrangement junctions in cancer, and repetitive sequences constitute about half of the human genome, it is important to understand the mechanisms underlying microhomology-mediated end joining and recombination at repetitive sequences. Our research in this proposal will create new knowledge and insight on DSB repair mechanisms in mammalian cells and shed light on how genome instability is induced upon DNA damage and during the oncogenic process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with Alzheimer’s Disease, related dementias, and diabetes have a notably higher risk of hypoglycemia and adverse events, including hospitalization and death. This project’s goal is to increase awareness of hypoglycemic risks and shared decisions about treatment options among patients with ADRD-DM, caregivers, and primary care clinicians. To that end, I will design an assistive information technology leveraging continuous glucose monitoring and evaluate its impact on care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PUBLIC NARRATIVE Ribosomes are large cellular complexes that synthesize proteins. In addition, ribosomes regulate bacterial stress responses, and human neurodevelopment and synaptic plasticity. Dysregulation of these processes leads to disease. Understanding how ribosomes control gene expression requires high-resolution characterization of ribosome movements and interactions. We will use biochemical and cryo-EM methods to address the mechanisms of translation regulation, which may pave the way to development of therapeutics against bacterial and genetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) All cells in an organism share the same DNA but express different genes including variations of gene sequence at the level of RNA (isoforms) in a highly controlled manner that allows complex multicellular organisms to develop. Why RNA isoforms exist and how they are regulated and function is a foundational and unsolved problem in biology with broad implications for predicting and treating diseases. This proposal will continue experimental and computational research towards discovering new aspects of how and why RNA isoforms exist and how they can be used to predict and provide therapeutic targets for treating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) The essential task of synthesizing all the proteins encoded in an organism’s DNA is executed solely by the ribosome and its associated translation machinery (TM). Using a powerful combination of fluorophore-labeled biological components and experimental approaches unique to the applicant’s and their collaborators’ laboratories, this proposal aims to elucidate aspects of the process through which the TM executes and controls protein synthesis that have thus far remained difficult or impossible to investigate. Because the bacterial TM is the target of many clinically relevant small-molecule antibiotics and dysregulation of the human TM plays a causal role in several human diseases, including numerous viral infections and cancers, the results of these studies are expected to identify new targets and strategies for the development of next-generation antibiotics and small- molecule therapeutics for treating viral infections, cancers, and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Genome rewiring events, through translocations, deletions, and even massive chromosomal rearrangements, contribute to genome instability associated with many human diseases, including a significant portion of cancers and inherited or spontaneous diseases. Furthermore, many classes of noncoding RNAs participate in genome remodeling pathways or the maintenance of genome integrity, and their loss or dysfunction can increase the frequency of genome rearrangements, resulting in either deletion of tumor-suppressing genes, formation of chimeric genes, or over-expression of genes that promote tumor stability. The extreme degree of natural genome editing events in Oxytricha make it unparalleled as a model system to study genome stability, and similar mechanisms that may contribute to genome instability and cancer in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narratives Centrosome and cilia dysfunction is prevalent in a wide range of diseases collectively called ciliopathy, including e.g. Bardet-Biedl syndrome, Joubert syndrome, Meckel-Gruber syndrome, polycystic kidney disease, and primary ciliary dyskinesia. However, how these cellular organelles form error-free from protein components scattered in the cell and what their physiological roles in most tissues remain elusive. A thorough understanding of the molecular pathways vertebrate cells employ to form and maintain the centrosome-cilium complex will allow for the development of therapeutic manipulations for some of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Genomic studies show that 25% of pancreatic cancers harbor mutations in key genes (BRCA1/2, PALB2, and ATM) critical in homologous recombination (HR), an important type of DNA repair. These HR-deficient pancreatic cancers have a more aggressive disease course. Here we propose that polymerase theta (POLQ), a key enzyme that regulates an alternative pathway of DNA repair, is a new and highly effective therapeutic target in HR-deficient pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Eukaryotic circadian clocks impact nearly every aspect of physiology behavior. Their dysfunction contributes to cancer, as well as to mental illness (e.g., depression) and to metabolic diseases (e.g., diabetes). While we know a great deal about the details of molecular timekeeping within pacemaker cells, we know relatively little about how clock information is used. Circadian output generates a series of signals representing phase markers, according to which diverse downstream tissues and circuits bias their daily temporal activities. We will study the generation of circadian phase in Drosophila at the levels of behavior, neurophysiology, neuroendocrinology and intracellular signaling pathways. The detailed mechanisms thus revealed will help deﬁne how clock information underlies normal physiology and also pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Antibodies are invaluable in basic biomedical research and biotechnology, but lack chemical features that facilitate enzyme inhibition, covalent target engagement, and other function-disrupting bioactivities. This program seeks to advance the yeast-based biosynthesis and high throughput screening of “chemically expanded” antibodies. Our investigations will lead to inhibitors for studying how cells move, interact with their surroundings, and signal with one another while also revealing crucial principles of protein biosynthesis and enzyme inhibitor discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In human cells, genomic DNAs are associated with histones and form chromatin structure. Precise organization of chromatin structure is critical during cellular development and reprogramming, and their misregulation leads to various human diseases including cancer. This grant aims to identify the molecular mechanisms underlying chromatin reorganization using a cellular reprogramming model in breast cancer cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intermediate progenitor cells arise from different lung stem cell populations following mammalian lung injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters utilize many mechanisms to ensure efficient nutrient uptake while regulating toxins. Regulatory domains are not conserved in all ABC importers, indicating more variability in ABC importers beyond the current Type I/II classification scheme (Rice, Park et al., 2014). The proposed research will define the mechanism in which transporters can shut off transport based on environmental cues, which is a critical, but often overlooked, aspect to understanding basic nutrient uptake and survival mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Plugging & Pulling-in: tuning peptides for TolC to overcome antibiotic resistance Narrative Antibiotic resistance is an increasingly dire global health challenge. Antibiotic efflux pumps push antibiotics out of bacterial cells so that antibiotics cannot reach their targets. We plan to identify features of peptides that bind efflux pumps to either 1) plug the pumps to potentiate antibiotics or 2) pull through the pumps for drug delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative In the human body, rhythms of metabolism play an essential role in maintaining normal function. Disrupting these rhythms can contribute to many types of disease, including diabetes, cancer, and aging. However, the effect that metabolic rhythms have on cells is still not fully understood. This study will investigate how changing metabolic rhythms can activate or deactivate certain genes, helping us to understand the connection between these rhythms and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal outlines plans for the development of new methods and general strategies for chemical synthesis of complex, bioactive organic compounds. The results from this endeavor will produce new synthesis “tools” that will enable medicinal chemists in academia, government labs, and the pharmaceutical industry to more easily access intricate molecules that are needed for biomedical studies and for the development of pharmaceutical drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Francois Jacob, the pioneering molecular geneticist, said that "The dream of every cell is to become two cells". In humans, the 6.2 billion DNA letters that encode the information for building and maintaining our bodies are organized into 46 chromosomes that must be copied and then precisely distributed to produce two identical daughter cells; errors in the distribution of chromosomes cause birth defects and contribute to the ability of cancers to develop and evade treatment. The goals of this project are to address how cells achieve the Jacobian dream, preserving the integrity of their genomes through the process of division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative - NO CHANGES RNA silencing is a natural process by which small RNAs “silence” genes (or turn genes off), and is required for fertility, brain development, and prevention of cancer. This project aims to understand how small RNAs control gene expression in humans. The proposed research will lead to a better understanding of human gene regulation and contribute to advances in harnessing RNA silencing for the treatment of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disrupted organ size control mechanisms underlie a multitude of birth defects, deficient tissue repair, and cancer. The proposed research studies cellular and molecular processes that perfectly restore size and scale during an astonishing example of innate vertebrate organ regeneration. As such, the project will uncover conceptual and specific mechanisms that may be disrupted in human disease while also guiding novel regenerative medicine approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal centers on the development of novel chiral catalysts and new approaches to achieve the enantioselective sp3 C–H activation of readily-available carboxylic acids, ketones and amines. These reactions will provide new strategies for constructing α-, β- and γ-stereocenters; broadly useful in asymmetric syntheses of chiral bioactive compounds and drug molecules. In a collaborative effort, these new synthetic technologies will be applied to the discovery of promising new drug candidates for the treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a noncommunicable disease responsible for being the 3rd leading cause of death globally, highlighting the need for interventions to address this issue. Pulmonary Rehabilitation is one proven intervention that has improved the trajectory of patient health outcomes; however, it is also currently severely underutilized. In this study, we aim to identify and implement evidence-based care components of a COPD discharge care bundle, including referrals to pulmonary rehabilitation for patients in a large hospital healthcare system to improve patient health outcomes and increase utilization rates of pulmonary rehabilitation services.

PHR: NARRATIVE This R21 proposal addresses a critical gap in HIV prevention by assessing acceptable and preferred strategies to optimize long-acting injectable (LAI) PrEP implementation for sexual minority men (SMM) who use methamphetamine (meth). The goal will be achieved by: 1) identifying modifiable care options for LAI PrEP use through qualitative interviews with SMM who use meth and healthcare providers, and 2) determining preferred choices for LAI PrEP care delivery using a large Discrete Choice Experiment (DCE) with a diverse group of SMM who use meth.

This equipment will benefit our research by expanding our directed evolution toolbox to next generation techniques that rely on continuous hypermutation in continuous culture. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poverty and opioid addiction are interrelated and chronic problems which have not been addressed adequately. This Stage III application seeks to develop and evaluate a Therapeutic Workplace that community treatment programs can implement and that arranges low-cost abstinence-contingent wage supplements to maintain drug abstinence and employment. If low-cost abstinence-contingent wage supplements in the community Therapeutic Workplace maintain drug abstinence and employment and decrease poverty, community drug-abuse treatment clinics could apply this intervention widely as a long-term maintenance treatment for unemployed adults with opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The modern rise in myopia has received a lot of attention and is of a major concern because myopic individuals with abnormally elongated eye are at risk of developing irreversible blinding diseases including retinal detachment, macular degeneration, and glaucoma. Thus, there is an urgent unmet public health need for interventions aimed at controlling abnormal growth of the eye and thereby, preventing or slowing progression of myopia. We will utilize myopic animal models to determine factors that control eye's growth, which will guide us to identify new therapeutic targets to manage myopia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – 2024 Equipment Supplement  The element iron plays an enormous role in biology, and we plan to study how iron contributes to catalysis (in hydrogenases) and to pH and small molecule sensing (in NEET proteins). Using very bright x-ray beams from synchrotron radiation sources, and bright infrared beams from NdYAG and quantum cascade lasers, we will study the vibrations of iron in the above systems, and this will provide structural information about how these proteins work. Information and insights gained from this project will help us better understand the biological chemistry of iron, so that we can learn from Nature to create a more efficient and healthier society and perhaps alleviate the damage from cancer and other diseases that occurs when some of these enzymes fail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium falciparum malaria remains a major public health problem globally, and new approaches to malaria control and prevention are urgently needed. In this proposal we will comprehensively determine the function of two newly-discovered human red blood cell host factors for malaria, testing the hypothesis that they facilitate parasite invasion through distinct yet synergistic pathways that are critical for the parasite’s life cycle. This project will advance our fundamental understanding of red blood cell-parasite interactions, and lay the groundwork for the development of host- directed therapies for malaria.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Narrative Within VA, among Veterans who have hypertension or diabetes, racial/ethnic minority Veterans are less likely than white Veterans to have these conditions under control. Some of the factors that can lead to poor control of these conditions may be related to the type of health care that the person receives, whereas other factors may be outside of the control of the health care system. Health care sites can sometimes deliver care in a way that will result in more patients achieving good control of their hypertension and diabetes. Our aims are to identify health care sites where there are fewer differences by race/ethnicity and by socio-economic status in the percentage of patients with good control of hypertension and diabetes, and to understand what some of the characteristics of patients, and their health care settings are that are associated with better control of these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorders is the most common, heritable, childhood-onset neuropsychiatric disorder. Understanding the genes and molecules critical for normal brain development will provide insight into the etiology of autism and related developmental brain disorders. These proposed studies will identify important genes for brain development and elucidate the functional and mechanistic role of specific genes in cortical development and physiology that can be targeted for the treatment of autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The majority of patients with pancreatic cancer will experience progressive and profound loss of adipose tissue and skeletal muscle. This condition, known as cachexia, increases treatment toxicity, reduces function, and causes some 25-30% of cancer deaths. Feeding is insufficient to prevent weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer because the tumor orchestrates changes in whole body metabolism and inflammation. Here we seek to use specimens from patients with pancreatic cancer to interrogate the cross-talk between tumor, adipose tissue, and skeletal muscle in order to validate pathways discovered using mouse models. Using a “mouse hospital” of mouse cohorts implanted in the pancreas with a number of patient-derived tumor lines and treatment with standard chemotherapy regimens, we will also test a novel anti-cachexia therapy. These studies will provide essential clinical correlative, mechanistic, and pre-clinical data for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE E-cigarettes (e-cigs) are an increasingly attractive alternative to tobacco cigarettes, especially among younger users; however, little is known about the human health effects arising from chronic exposure to these aerosols. This study will determine the metal and aldehyde mixture composition of e-cig aerosols as a function of e-cig operating power by collecting e-cig aerosols from a device operated at three different powers (30, 40 and 50 W) and determine whether operating power is a critical determinant of brain metal accumulation, neurobehavioral toxicity and neuropathology in mice chronically exposed to e-cig aerosol. This study will also evaluate whether sex and genetic susceptibility to Parkinson’s Disease modify the neurotoxicity observed in the mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Babesia parasites are the causative agents of human babesiosis, a malaria-like illness endemic in the US and distributed worldwide. This proposal builds upon two recent discoveries in the Ben Mamoun Lab, which showed that Babesia parasites produce and export unique nanovesicles into the host environment, and that immunization with these vesicles protects from subsequent challenge with a lethal parasite isolate. The proposed studies aim to characterize the composition of these vesicles, understand how they confer immune protection and use this knowledge to develop an effective vaccine for human babesiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have shown that the pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis – the cause of tuberculosis – can adapt to antibiotics and the host environment by regulating the error rate of protein synthesis. However, how it achieves this without undergoing catastrophically high rates of error are not known. We will use biochemical, structural and kinetic approaches to understand this process, which in turn will enable development of targeted anti- virulence strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Animal- and vector-transmitted viruses are major human health threats, and the primary source of emerging viruses. However, current strategies to reduce or prevent these sources of transmission are inadequate. The goal of this proposal is to generate recombinant antiviral proteins with enhanced antiviral activities, define more biologically relevant promoters to express antiviral genes in mosquitoes, and to test their effectiveness against model viruses in cultured cells and transgenic mosquitoes, ultimately resulting in a new, modular strategy to reduce or prevent transmission of a broad range of virus families.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATVE This Association of Food and Drug Officials (AFDO) project entitled Funding System to Support Milk and Shellfish Regulatory Programs, Years 4-8 is intended to facilitate long- term improvements to the national food safety system by assisting state and territorial (ST) milk and shellfish regulatory programs by: • Communicating effectively, in coordination with all relevant partners, regarding the available  FDA funding opportunities that support milk and shellfish programs, assuring that all eligible  jurisdictions are equally aware of the opportunities; and • Providing FDA subaward funding to qualified milk and shellfish regulatory agencies in a fair  and equitable manner, enabling them to attend FDA-approved training courses and/or  acquire necessary equipment that will improve public health outcomes. These goals will significantly advance a National Integrated Food Safety System and effectively fulfill the partnership requirements of the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The cross-species emergence of SARS-CoV-2 from wild, Rhinolophus spp. bats to human hosts highlights the extreme public health, economic, and societal consequences that can result from zoonotic spillover. This proposal leverages tools from mathematical modeling, field biology, and molecular immunology to decipher the mechanisms underpinning the circulation of bat-borne viruses at a population-level, understand the processes which shape their pathology within-host, and eradicate them from reservoir populations to prevent future threats of zoonotic emergence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RNA silencing regulates essentially every biological process in eukaryotes, and their dysregulations causes numerous diseases and physiological disorders in human and in plants. The proposed study is to determine how several newly identified components such as RNA helicases, catalases, U1-70K, and BICE1 contribute to the production of small RNAs for RNA silencing in Arabidopsis. The studies on the new regulatory mechanisms in RNA silencing in the model organism Arabidopsis may enable us to manipulate these components for a better therapeutic strategy to cure physiological disorders that arise from dysfunctions of RNA processing in biotechnology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will apply transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation, a non-invasive brain stimulation method that modulates a system in the brain that is initially affected by Alzheimer's disease pathology and enhances memory performance, and thus may hold the key to successfully delay this disease in its earliest stages. We will assess the duration and extent of improvements in cognitive performance, and will identify individual, brain physiology and Alzheimer's disease-related factors that contribute to its success in older individuals without clinical impairment, including those at risk for Alzheimer's disease. This project has important public health implications as it gathers critical information to identify the target population, and to inform designs of future clinical trials aimed at prevention of Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the availability of guidelines for cancer survivorship, including the newly released National Standards for Cancer Survivorship Care, receipt and overall quality of survivorship care is inconsistent across survivors and treating facilities, with gaps in our knowledge of best practices for delivering tailored survivorship care to meet the unique needs of adolescent and young adult (AYAs) cancer survivors. Within this proposal, our team will conduct a mixed-methods study of AYA cancer survivors (ages 15-39 years at diagnosis) diagnosed between 2014-2019, using cancer registry data linked with electronic health record (EHR) data and patient surveys, and supplemented by focus groups and key informant interviews with stakeholders. Our primary goal is to understand the current landscape of how national survivorship care standards are implemented, to identify barriers driving underutilization of AYA survivorship care, and to develop priorities for enhanced survivorship care that directly address patient-driven approaches for reducing these barriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The last step in cell division, abscission, relies on a transient structure called the midbody, which resides inside the intercellular bridge between newly forming daughter cells. It consists of overlapping spindle midzone microtubules which are coated with electron dense material called the midbody matrix. Long conceptualized as a structural remnant subject to degradation following cytokinesis, emerging data suggest that midbody remnants (MBsomes) play instructive post-mitotic roles in establishing cell fate, proliferation state, tissue polarity, cilia formation, neuron function, and oncogenesis. However, very little is known about the functional significance of the electron dense material. My lab has uncovered a surprising novel function for this electron dense material in that it is a site of RNA storage and is a novel actively translating RNP granule with a uniquely complex life cycle comprised of both membrane-less and membrane-bound phases, that we are calling the MB-granule (for Midbody-granule). Our current research goals are to understand how the midbody behaves as a novel form of intercellular communication, to define distinct therapeutic targets for midbody-mediated human diseases that range from cancer to neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative  Textural aspects of food, termed mouthfeel, are important flavor qualities that can determine whether food is eaten or discarded, and thus, are essential factors for dietary health. Currently, little is known about the basic neuronal mechanisms underlying mouthfeel or the processes by which this flavor modality modifies taste. This work provides a comprehensive identification of mammalian mechanosensory neurons of the tongue and identifies mechanotransduction channels that underlie mouthfeel, with the long-term goal of understanding how mechanosensation impacts flavor perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Facial disfigurement due to the loss of soft tissue is debilitating, and current therapies are limited because of tissue rejection and lack of suitable tissue. We propose to bioengineer craniofacial muscle tissue by using the subject’s own cells combined with innovative 3-D printing technologies and specialized bioreactors. This research has potential to advance our knowledge of muscle engineering applications, and develop novel and precise therapies to manage volumetric muscle tissue loss of the craniofacial region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  While there is a growing body of evidence suggesting that music training benefits brain development, the evidence is not conclusive and rigorously designed RCT neuroimaging studies are needed to provide a definitive answer to whether and which brain circuits are enhanced by music training and how. The scientific goal of this project is to study the effects of a community-based music training program on neurodevelopment among Hispanic children from low-income communities. Implementing cost-effective, community-focused sustainable, and novel strategies for ethnic minority children will help offset the burden associated with negative health outcomes such as obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Altered trajectories of amygdala development are highly linked to a host of mental health disorders, such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and the long term consequences of early life stress. Using the mouse as a model, the goal of our proposed studies is to understand the dynamic changes in circuit connectivity, neuronal responsivity and behavioral function of a novel population of amygdala neurons that mature coincident with adolescence.

PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE This training program is specifically designed to train a new cadre of researchers and leaders to address major but as yet under-studied public health problems engendered by conditions prevalent in urban and rural informal human settlements (slums) of low and middle-income countries (LMIC). Selected candidates will undergo field training on site in LMICs to develop new global health research skills framed within our project research theme of health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Vision in mosquitoes plays a critical but understudied role in their attraction to hosts. This project will determine the visual features (colors, size, motion) that mosquitoes find attractive and characterize how odor modulates visual responses. This work will also test new visual lures and identify potential molecular targets that compromise the visual and olfactory behaviors to hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells elicit numerous behaviors to maintain the structure and function of tissues during both normal homeostasis and stress. The proposed study leverages the robustness of the Drosophila intestinal epithelium to investigate the principles underlying complex cell behaviors, which contribute to the maintenance of epithelial structure and function. Thus, the proposed study will promote our knowledge of how to keep epithelia healthy and prevent diseases associated with abnormalities in epithelial homeostasis.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL

In this supplementary application, we propose a two-year training program for Dr. Rebecca Molinini, a promising future leader with a doctoral degree in Physical Therapy and a PhD in Rehabilitation and Movement Sciences who is committed to research in mind-body therapies for enhancing the parent-child relationship as part of the rehabilitation process for preterm infants. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – from parent grant Recent discoveries that allow us to look beyond the one-dimensional sequence of DNA and understand the large-scale organization principals of its three-dimensional folding have been limited when it comes to characterizing the role of fine-scale genetic variations of the DNA code in controlling important cellular processes such as gene expression. This work will employ state-of-the-art molecular biology techniques and develop novel computational methods to define the role of such genetic variants in changing three-dimensional connections made by the promoters of genes in the human genome. This systematic and unbiased genome- wide study will have important implications in changing the way we study the disease relevance of genetic variation by revealing genotype dependence of long-range chromatin interactions between genes and their distal control switches at a scale that has not been achieved to date.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance to Public Health This project examines how cognitive abilities impact the recovery of language in individuals during the acute to chronic stages of stroke. Assessing these abilities over time while collecting neural information will enable us identify patterns of co-occurrence to gain predictive power about what types of brain damage and behavior lead to chronic communicative loss. As a result, we will be able to provide a clear path to improved diagnosis and treatment of communicative difficulties following right hemisphere stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: To combat diseases, it is essential to study the function of biomolecules to understand the underlying disease mechanisms. Multi-frequency Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopy, which is a powerful method to study functional dynamics of proteins, lacks sufficient sensitivity and resolution to carry out studies at physiological concentrations and longer time scales. The proposed research will develop computational methods to improve signal resolution in ESR spectroscopy, enabling better understanding of disease mechanisms for more effective therapies, thus benefiting the public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will complement the larger project and will train an early career researcher in implementation science methodology, training and intervention development, and grantsmanship in order for her to gain research independence. The parent project, and by extension, the proposed project, aims to transform mental health care by addressing both supply and demand side barriers through provision of accessible and evidence-based care delivered by racially and culturally congruent providers; enabling care to be delivered regardless of a formal diagnosis; and empowering majority-minority, mostly first-generation college-attending students to acquire the skills to respond and become change agents for their communities. The proposed project will not only act as an immersive career development and training experience for the applicant, but will create an intervention for trauma-focused care in an emergency medical setting that has important implications for further dissemination and widespread understanding of the organizational and contextual factors which act as barriers to implementation of evidence-based interventions and can serve as a blueprint for broader scope and reach of mental health care to address the mental health needs of racial and ethnic minority groups in low resourced communities who experience disparities in access and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: DETAILED DESCRIPTION Migraine is a common, painful and disabling disorder; depressive symptoms are often comorbid with in people with migraine and increase suffering. The goal of this project is to evaluate the fidelity, feasibility, and acceptability of remote-delivered (telephone and video) mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) for migraine disability and depressive symptoms. We will use pre-specified decision rules to determine study design for a future phase III clinical trial of remote-delivered MBCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Common viral respiratory infections, such as influenza and SARS-CoV-2, contribute to chronic lung disease. Following viral infection, airway repair mechanisms lead to differentiation of unexpected airway cell types within the lung, Microfold (M) and basal-like cells. This proposal will investigate the function of rare airway cell types during post-viral injury repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed “Research Supplement to Promote Diversity in Health-Related Research” builds on the parent grant (R01-MD015165: Multilevel Physical Activity Intervention for Low Income Public Housing Residents) to test a multi-level intervention aimed at increasing physical activity among public housing residents. This supplement will support the career goals of Dr. Brennan Rhodes-Bratton, a social epidemiologist focused on chronic disease prevention in minoritized communities. Using data from the Community Walks clinical trial, Dr. Rhodes-Bratton aims to examine the impact of gentrification and health habitus on moderate-intensity physical activity among public housing residents in Boston, Massachusetts, employing an explanatory sequential design with semi-structured interviews to interpret quantitative data findings; results will be used to determine strategies for improving chronic disease prevention interventions among minoritized groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Interstitial cystitis/ bladder pain syndrome (IC/BPS) is one of the most debilitating chronic pelvic pain (CPP) conditions that negatively impacts the quality of life and sexual activities in 2.7% to 6.5% of women in the US. Botulinum neurotoxin (BoNT) has received growing interest in managing IC/BPS, but it can cause dose- dependent adverse effects and is expensive. This research represents the first effort develop a personalized, precision BoNT injection approach guided by intra-vaginal high-density surface EMG to optimize the treatment outcome in IC/BPS management.
