IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of new life-saving medicines requires access to new chemical structures with unprecedented structures. We are interested in designing new reactions that harness the energy of light to generate highly reactive intermediates that engage in reactions that cannot be accomplished using standard non-photochemical strategies. The focus of our research is the design of catalysts that can control the outcomes of these high-energy reactions in predictable ways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanistic concepts from model organisms are used to translate ideas for therapeutics, vaccine design, managing infectious diseases and immune pathologies into humans. Mice are one of the most widely used preclinical models of human immunity, and the studies in our proposal will aid in predicting how structural variation between the genomes of model organisms and the human genome contribute to humans acquiring (or losing) cell-type and stimulation-dependent gene expression patterns and functions in immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antimetabolite chemotherapies are being repurposed to treat immunopathologies, however, significant side- effects occur in patients because antimetabolites alter metabolism in many cell types, not just the pathogenic cell populations. To predict the effects of antimetabolite or nutrient interventions in therapeutic settings, we need to understand the conserved and cell-type specific mechanisms by which metabolites influence cellular programming potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Access to and receipt of high-quality survivorship care is of paramount importance for survivors of young adult (YA) cancers, who experience long-term risks across multiple health domains and have many life-years to live. This supplement will assess alignment between the new National Standards for Survivorship Care and a survivorship care program that serves diverse YAs; access to and utilization of survivorship care among diverse YAs; and identify multi-level gaps for future development. Findings of this study will illuminate opportunity areas for YA cancer survivorship care delivery in alignment with the new National Standards, and, thereby, inform efforts to develop and implement high-quality survivorship programs that serve and engage diverse YA survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative (Parent Award) The United States is in the midst of a nationwide opioid epidemic; terpenes hold promise as novel pharmacotherapeutic strategies to reduce reliance on opioids for pain management. The proposed double-blind, placebo-controlled studies will be the first to rigorously assess the dose- dependent analgesic effects of ecologically-relevant doses of two terpenes with robust preclinical promise, myrcene and ßcaryophyllene, and determine their THC- and opioid-sparing effects. Findings from these studies will be essential to developing these terpenes as innovative therapeutics to treat pain to aid in the effort to decrease dependence on opioids as analgesics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastomas (GBMs) or grade IV gliomas are aggressive brain tumors affecting about 18,000 Americans every year with a median survival of only 12-15 months. We have found new evidence that the transcription co-factors, YAP/TAZ are integral components of DNA damage repair on neurogenic enhancers, regions that are selectively vulnerable to double stranded breaks. In this proposal, we will use a combination of classic molecular biology assays and state-of-the-art epigenomic technologies to understand the mechanistic underpinnings of therapy resistance in GBM and target the YAP/TAZ pathway using novel pharmacological inhibitors to overcome therapy resistance in GBM.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Informatics, Decision-Enhancement, and Analytic Sciences (IDEAS) Center of Innovation will conduct research to advance scientific discovery, implement novel interventions, promote cross-center collaboration, increase research capacity, and engage operational partners to improve Veteran health. Our research will focus on the public health threat of antibiotic resistance, on mitigating health risks in Veterans during periods of vulnerability, and on improving medication safety as the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) transitions to a new electronic health record. Across all of these areas, we study methods to promote the adoption of research findings into clinical practice. In the process, we train the next generation of outstanding VA health services researchers. Veteran and stakeholder engagement is a topmost priority for our Center. All of our research is highly collaborative and integrated with clinical programs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The mission of the Center for Care Delivery and Outcomes Research (CCDOR) is to develop and evaluate interventions and implementation strategies that improve health care delivery, Veteran engagement in health care, and Veterans' health and functioning in their communities. CCDOR's vision is to elevate the quality, consistency and equity of health care and outcomes for all Veterans through innovative health services and implementation research. CCDOR is a vibrant health services research center of 26 core investigators leading research in Trauma Recovery (Priority 1) and Chronic Pain and Opioid Harms Reduction (Priority 2), as well as conducting and promoting research in additional areas including cancer prevention and control, health aging, and other timely topics. CCDOR has deep and strong partnerships with VA Program Offices, including the Office of Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, the National Center for PTSD, and National Pain Management. These and other partnerships ensure the value and impact of Center research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Veterans Health Administration (VA) provides care for individuals who are more likely to be racial and ethnic minorities, older, and poorer than the general population. Although VA provides a health care safety net, disparities in health and health care exist for many vulnerable Veteran populations and are associated with increased risks of disability, illness, and death. In addition to individual, provider, and health system factors, disparities may originate outside of the health care system and involve personal behaviors and social and community influences. As a health system committed to delivering high-quality, equitable care to all Veterans, VA must identify vulnerable populations, understand the root causes of disparities, and assess interventions to eliminate them. The Center for Health Equity Research and Promotion's mission is to advance the quality and equity of health and health care for vulnerable Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Access and Delivery Research and Evaluation (CADRE) is seeking to renew its Center of Innovation (COIN) funding to advance research and improve access for Veterans. We aim to build upon our existing expertise, established operational partnerships, and long-term research objectives through prioritizing five overarching goals that align with our focused areas of research and emerging priorities. GOAL 1: Improve access to high quality care for rural Veterans through innovative applications of telehealth in specialty care, community care, and dual use. GOAL 2: Develop and evaluate interventions targeting the multidrug-resistant organism crisis. GOAL 3: Expand efforts in developing innovative health services research in three additional areas: (1) women’s health, (2) epidemic opioid use and substance use disorders, and (3) cardiovascular outcomes. GOAL 4: Continue the Center’s success in supporting mentored career development. GOAL 5: Promote Veteran engagement with recognition that Veterans are experts on Veteran experience.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The Houston Health Services Research & Development (HSR&D) Center for Innovations in Quality, Effectiveness and Safety (IQuESt) has been continuously funded by HSR&D since 1990, providing strong scientific leadership and institutional infrastructure dedicated to a model of embedded health system research. We have a nearly 20-year tradition of conducting research in partnership with the health care delivery system and responding to its needs, making us pioneers in the execution of the learning health care system model in VHA. The IQuESt mission, “Improving health and well-being through innovations in health care delivery”, conveys our commitment to transformative and innovative research that is aligned with VHA national priorities. IQuESt is ideally poised to contribute to making care more accessible, safer, and more patient-centered with innovative research, rapid implementation of evidence, novel methodologies, solid partnerships, stakeholder engagement, career development of scientists, and infrastructure to promote the learning health care system in VHA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation for Complex Chronic Healthcare (CINCCH) is a HSR&D COIN based at Hines VA Hospital. CINCCH's mission is to conduct research to optimize coordination and contextualization of healthcare delivery and improve outcomes for Veterans with high priority neurologic conditions, disseminate and implement best evidence, and train future researchers. We utilize innovative direct observation methods to collect data that compliments other forms of data to assess quality and patient experiences. CINCCH collaborates with several VA Operations Partners and is affiliated with three universities in the Chicago area. In addition, we have established a Veterans Engagement Panel that provides feedback on grant proposals and dissemination activities. Our COIN's vision is to create the evidence and implement the findings to support and guide VA in providing the best care in the right place at the right time.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This application proposes the continuation of a Center of Innovation (COIN), called the Pain Research, Informatics, Multimorbidities, and Education (PRIME) Center. The COIN builds on the successes of our existing PRIME Center at VA Connecticut Healthcare System. The goals of the PRIME Center are to conduct research to improve care for all Veterans with a specific focus on pain management and women's health. The Center also fosters innovative research in emerging areas like suicide prevention and CHOICE care. Through a Veteran Engagement Group, the Center strives to be Veteran-centric. Investigators provide research mentoring to train the next generation of VA health services researchers. To achieve its goals, the PRIME Center is supported by partnerships with VHA Patient Care Services and Operations leaders, especially the Pain Management Program and Women's Health Services, as well as a large number of cross-COIN and other VHA medical center collaborations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Given Veterans' increasing choices about where and how they receive care, successful coordination of care will require improving effective communication among a variety of individuals and entities, as well as improved management and use of health information. This project supports the Center for Health Information and Communication, of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Research & Development Service. The Center's mission is to improve Veterans' health care through innovative research on health information, technology, and communication. The Center's vision is to improve Veterans' health through innovative applications of health information and health information systems that serve the population-based and interpersonal needs of patients and health professionals. The Center will generate knowledge about the impact of the Department's investment in health information technology, and will determine how systems-based and interpersonal communication of health information can improve delivery and outcomes of care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Mental Healthcare & Outcomes Research (CeMHOR) is an HSR&D Center of Innovation whose mission is to optimize health and well-being of Veterans through innovative research to improve access to and engagement in evidence-based care for mental health and substance use disorders and prevent suicide. CeMHOR accomplishes its mission by partnering directly with Veterans, clinical leaders, and front-line providers to develop feasible and effective interventions to address top VA and national priorities. CeMHOR expertise in implementation science leads to widespread uptake of these interventions. CeMHOR investigators are also experts in rural health and community engagement. CeMHOR research will apply this expertise to include Veterans who are not receiving VA care, as well as those who use VA services but do not fully engage in needed care. In addition to two focus areas, mental health care access/engagement and suicide prevention, investigators conduct research to address opioid misuse and abuse and advance implementation science.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation (COIN) for Veteran-Centered and Value-Driven Care has had outstanding productivity and impact on Veteran healthcare and well-being through the application of the National Academy of Medicine's learning health system. In the past 3 years, our 47 investigators generated ~$47 million in operating revenue, published 583 manuscripts, and led 113 projects across our research, implementation science, operational projects/program evaluations and training programs. Our dual-site Center will continue to address our two focus areas: 1) promote Veteran-centered care to improve patient experiences across VA healthcare and community settings and 2) advanced value-driven care by providing Veterans the highest quality care at the lowest financial burden. Building on our prior success, we will continue to partner with operational leaders and our Veteran Engagement Board to innovate new research, implementation science, and operational programs as well as train the next generation of outstanding research leaders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goal of the Durham Center of Innovation to Accelerate Discovery and Practice Transformation (ADAPT) is to enhance the Veterans Health Administration's (VHA) ability to continually improve health care and optimize Veteran wellbeing and independence. ADAPT will lead innovative research on promoting and sustaining healthy lifestyles, improving access through virtual care, and optimizing Veteran function and independence. Working closely with VA and non-VA partners, ADAPT investigators will apply and advance state-of-the-art methods, translate research findings into meaningful practice change, and train the next generation of VA researchers. ADAPT will play a vital role in helping VHA meet the challenges of providing timely, coordinated, consistently high-quality care to more than 9 million Veterans each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial infarction (MI) can lead to heart failure (HF), which negatively impacts the quality of life of millions of Americans. This study will use a novel computational stability analysis to investigate the mechanisms that lead to post-MI HF by examining how biomechanical stimuli can impair cardiac function through growth and remodeling. Results will identify HF risk factors and promote the development of diagnostics and therapeutics to detect and ultimately prevent HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defective hematopoiesis is a hallmark of blood diseases, many of which are enriched with Dnmt3a mutations and are associated with an enhanced inflammatory milieu. This project will generate an improved understanding of the mechanism(s) by which Dnmt3a mutations endow a fitness advantage to hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) during chronic inflammation, which remodels bone marrow composition and reinforces further selections of the mutant HSCs for disease progression. Results generated from this study will likely lead to therapeutic opportunities that allow early interventions of DNMT3A-mutant clonal hematopoiesis-associated blood diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Statement: Obesity and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) devastate millions of Americans and place a tremendous burden on our healthcare system. Necessities of modern society put immense pressure on human physiology by forcing incongruity between endogenous circadian rhythms and environmental cycles, which worsens a range of health issues including obesity associated maladies and AD. This project aims to identify the neuronal circuits and the molecular players that control circadian rhythms and therefore identify therapeutic targets to circumvent these pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pneumonia is the leading cause of infection-related deaths worldwide, necessitating a greater understanding of the mechanisms that regulate immune defense and tissue recovery in the lung post-infection. Lectin-like oxidized low-density receptor-1 (LOX-1) is a C-type lectin scavenger receptor that has a unique function in the lung, whereby it is protective against edematous lung injury and inflammation through alterations in leukocyte response that suggests a more pro-resolving phenotype. Whether and how LOX-1 promotes resolution of infection in the lung via resident and recruited leukocytes is not known and is the subject of the proposed studies, where effects of LOX-1 signaling will be investigated at the transcriptional (K99), metabolic (R00) and phenotypic level (K99/R00).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is an independent risk factor for future cardiovascular events, often preceded by microvascular endothelial dysfunction. Endothelial function has been demonstrated to be regulated by autophagy, but there is little understanding of the mechanistic role of autophagy within the T2DM microvasculature. The overall goal of this application is to determine the fundamental mechanisms contributing to microvascular dysfunction in T2DM, we hypothesize that impaired autophagic flux mechanistically contributes to microvascular dysfunction through alterations in Transcription Factor EB in T2DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Smoke-free public housing policies have been mandated by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). However, our work suggests these policies are considered to be so unfair by residents that compliance is severely undermined, with potentially negative unintended consequences. Our goal is to verify how these policies can be harmful and propose adaptations to increase their effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Exposure to elevated manganese (Mn) induces incurable neurotoxicity in humans that manifests as parkinsonism in adults, and motor and executive function deficits in children. This study will determine the role of Mn excretion in regulating the risks and outcomes of Mn neurotoxicity. Proposed work will also determine whether increasing Mn excretion is a therapeutically-viable strategy for the management of Mn-induced neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Markey Cancer Center is the only NCI-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center in the state of Kentucky, and its catchment area includes all 120 counties in Kentucky. The mission of Markey Cancer Center is to reduce cancer burden, which necessitates translating scientific discoveries into innovative, personalized care and providing the highest quality care to cancer survivors. This administrative supplement aims to assess alignment between survivorship care at Markey Cancer Center and the National Standards for Cancer Survivorship Care, identify determinants of survivorship care access for survivors and their caregivers, and identify implementation strategies to improve quality, effectiveness, adoption, and reach of survivorship care at Markey.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This project is directly relevant to public health concerns related to the effects of prenatal alcohol exposure on child health and development. This study aims to improve the screening of FASD by deploying web-based tools that aid in clinical evaluation. Two main tools will be used, the FASD-Tree and the Brief Assessment of Individual Neurobehavior – online version (BRAIN-online). Both tools use web-based technology for collecting data and provide the clinician with information about the individual’s physical, behavioral, and cognitive attributes. Data from these novel tools will be combined with traditional and advanced physical measurements collected through other CIFASD projects and will enhance clinical decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Even after completing cancer treatment, cancer survivors have increased health risks compared with the general population, necessitating ongoing care through survivorship programs. This project will assess Dartmouth Cancer Center’s survivorship services against a new set of national standards for survivorship programs to identify areas where Dartmouth Cancer Center’s program can be enhanced to meet rural survivors’ needs and engage them in care through digital tools and other innovative solutions. The project will produce a set of recommendations for quality improvement initiatives to support lasting impacts on survivorship care delivery and outcomes for survivors in rural areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: EXPOSURE: Project Narrative Although engagement in long-term follow-up survivor care is critical to the lifelong health of the growing childhood cancer survivor (CCS) population, >25% of CCS are not accessing survivor care nationally. Understanding the factors impacting the landscape of pediatric survivor care (e.g., institutional uptake of standards, population reach, patient engagement) may reduce gaps in care delivery for CCS. The objectives of this supplement to the Winship Cancer Institute's NCI-designated P30 Cancer Center grant are to examine: 1) the alignment of the care offered to pediatric CCS with the National Standards for Survivorship Care, 2) the long-term utilization of pediatric survivor services, and 3) patient- and family-level factors related to long-term engagement in survivor care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist Comprehensive Cancer Center (AHWFBCCC) catchment area includes 4.8 million residents, about one-third racial/ethnic minority, and a significant rural footprint. The proposed work will evaluate the extent to which survivorship care programs in this multidimensional health care system align with recently developed National Standards for Survivorship Care through a mixed-methods action planning process that considers different contexts in depth and will inform future implementation of optimized survivorship care. Establishing a systematic process for assessing and improving accessible survivorship care with a balance of common unified services and variations tailored to local demands will position AHWFBCCC to contribute to a broader understanding of what survivorship care models are optimally effective in diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will comprehensively evaluate and refine a tool, named the Suspected Potential Overdose Tracker (SPOT), that uses data routinely collected during death investigations to identify accidental drug overdose as the cause and manner of death in near real-time. Near real-time data on overdose deaths will allow for data- driven decision making, the identification of gaps in public health and public safety overdose response preparedness, and opportunities to evaluate overdose prevention interventions, programs, and policies.

PHR: Public exposure to radiation due to large-scale radiation incidents is a rising global concern, but there are no FDA-approved therapeutics for radiation injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES LMNA-related dilated cardiomyopathy (LMNA-DCM) is one of the most prevalent forms of inherited heart disease. This study will investigate the molecular mechanisms of DCM by examining how crosstalk signaling among cardiomyocytes, endothelial cells, and cardiac fibroblasts via secreted proteins may contribute to the pathogenesis of LMNA-DCM. The proposed studies will provide insight into disease mechanisms and inform the development of new therapies that target intercellular signaling pathways in DCM.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: FOA Number: RFA-FD-23-001 FOA Title: Clinical Studies of Orphan Products Addressing Unmet Needs of Rare Diseases (R01) Clinical Trials Required Proposal Title: SELVA: A Multicenter, Phase 3 Baseline-Controlled Study Evaluating the Safety and Efficacy of PTX- 022 in the Treatment of Microcystic Lymphatic Malformations Institute: FDA Office of Orphan Products Development Study Section: N/A Project Narrative This application proposes to develop a novel pathologically targeted therapy for a rare genetic disease called microcystic lymphatic malformations (microcystic LM). Microcystic LM is caused by mutations in the PI3K/mTOR signaling pathway, resulting in abnormal lymphatic vessel formations that result in cutaneous lesions. Palvella Therapeutics plans to treat microcystic LM with PTX-022, a topical gel that targets the root cause of microcystic LMs, by downregulating excessive mTOR signaling at the site of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to investigate the level of alignment between the survivorship services provided by a comprehensive cancer center and the National Standards for Survivorship Care. Additionally, it will analyze the utilization rates of the Survivorship Clinic among a sample of adolescent and young adult cancer survivors who were initially eligible to take part in a randomized trial involving a mobile app and website designed to reduce distress and enhance adherence to healthcare in the parent grant. Lastly, qualitative interviews will be conducted with a subset of AYA participants to explore their experiences and the barriers and facilitators they encountered in accessing survivorship-focused care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative RADOR-KY (Rapid Actionable Data for Opioid Response in Kentucky) is a statewide population-based surveillance system with a key feature of forecasting opioid-related overdose mortality and morbidity, so that public health resources can be deployed timely to the areas and populations that need them most to save lives. The system currently integrates 11 sources of data, but these do not include social media. This supplement proposes to investigate the value of two sources of (in principle, real-time) social media data (Reddit, Twitter/X) to improve the performance of forecasting algorithms, potentially providing a model for real-time opioid overdose epidemic surveillance.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric acquired aplastic anemia is a life-threatening condition with frequently unknown origin caused by autoreactive T cell destruction of hematopoietic stem cells and inability to produce red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets. Treatment for aplastic anemia can be with immune suppression therapy or intensified with upfront bone marrow transplant. This proposal aims to provide algorithms to identify pediatric patients with newly diagnosed aplastic anemia that will respond favorably to IST, thereby improving cures while minimizing toxicity for this potentially fatal disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Phase 2a/2b Study Emapalumab: A Window of Opportunity in Pediatric Aplastic Anemia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to utilize group model building with clinicians, patients, and families to develop the first qualitative model of childhood cancer survivorship care. The model will identify and analyze barriers within the care process to improve accessibility and adherence to guidelines in non-specialized clinics. The outcomes will identify optimal targets for improving survivorship care, thereby enhancing health equity and improving care delivery for the growing survivor population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child malnutrition has numerous devastating consequences, including impaired synthesis of bile acids (BAs), which help absorb dietary nutrients and regulate metabolism. The goal of this proposal is to understand how malnutrition suppresses BA synthesis. Results from these studies will help us develop new therapies to restore BA levels, improve outcomes of therapeutic feeding to treat malnutrition, and increase survival among children suffering from malnutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Neuropathic pain is a serious and long-term neurotoxic side effect of chemotherapy affecting more than 68% of cancer patients, and is currently without treatment. Our studies on sensory neuronal maintenance have found NMNAT proteins to be among the most robust and versatile neuroprotective factors known and have the potential to mitigate sensory dysfunction. The proposed studies will discover ways to enhance sensory neurons' self-protection abilities by efficiently regulating NMNAT expression via microRNA and neutral compounds, thus aid in the design of therapeutic treatments for neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed project examines the extent to which the Buffet Cancer Center Survivorship Program aligns with recently developed National Standards for Survivorship Care by evaluating the organizational policies and processes for delivering survivorship care. Document reviews and interviews will be conducted to assess the alignment of current policies and procedures with the National Standards, as well as EHR analyses to determine survivorship program utilization and examine referral rates and the number of survivors lost to follow-up across cancer types. Using the National Standards for Survivorship Care as a guiding framework, this study seeks to inform policy, practice, and future research efforts aimed at improving the long- term care and outcomes of cancer survivors in the United States.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Association of State Departments of Agriculture (NASDA) project entitled A Coordinated National Approach to Supporting, Promoting, and Implementing FDA's Produce Safety Rule and the Produce Regulatory Program Standards will continue building on three important objectives established under previous cooperative agreements:   Supporting the efforts of federal, state, and territorial government agencies in building a  Produce Safety Integrated Food Safety System;   Supporting and expanding established systems for sharing, promoting, and collaborating  on best practices, operating documents, procedures, and other tools to foster a consistent  national produce safety program; and   Supporting the maintenance and advancement of the Produce Regulatory Program  Standards (PRPS). These three objectives will support FDA's goal of developing, implementing, and improving a nationally consistent support system which facilitates the implementation of state and territorial produce safety regulatory programs that are modernized and aligned with the standards set forth in the FDA's rule: Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption (commonly referred to as the Produce Safety Rule).

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative: This application requests funds to support the efforts of Targeted Therapy Technologies, LLC (3T) to build on the strong preliminary results of Episcleral Topotecan (Chemoplaque) Phase I studies treating eyes with refractory retinoblastoma, indicating 89% sustained Complete Response (all CRs out > 2 years) with the RP2D (1.2 mg) with the only toxicity being ocular inflammation (scleritis) that resolves after removal. Further, there was no systemic toxicity or detectable exposure in blood. In the refractory setting, as a single treatment (no cycles or multiple treatments) the Chemoplaque treated refractory solid tumor, vitreous and subretinal seeds. We are unaware of other interventions that can robustly treat all three lesions—let alone as a single treatment in a refractory setting. We propose a Phase I-II study to expand toxicity and effectiveness data of Episcleral Topotecan (Chemoplaque). In this study, EUAs will be at 0, 4, 8, and 12 weeks (see protocol in appendix) reducing the frequency to standard of care as efficacy and safety have been established. Assessment of retinoblastoma tumor burden is problematic. Unlike other cancers, both eyes of the child may have multiple tumors, with multiple primary treatment options and multiple subsequent treatments, challenging the difficulties of Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors (RECIST).1 Rather than tumor size, retinoblastoma cancer activity is best evaluated by experts using many tools. We built for the first Topotecan Chemoplaque study, the SWIMMERRB display of all therapies to a study eye before and after the Topotecan Chemoplaque intervention, which visually shows Progression-free Survival and details the multiple treatments before the intervention and after for recurrences. We consider any cancer therapy to the study eye after removal of Topotecan Chemoplaque to be evidence of recurrence. Through consensus building conferences primarily with patients and those with lived experience in retinoblastoma, we will seek numerical values to represent invasiveness/lifelong impact of each therapy. Application of the values to the various Topotecan Chemoplaque study long term outcomes, may validate the SWIMMERRB as a unique RECIST tool1. Such a SWIMMERRB tool may enable retinoblastoma clinical trials to have a standardized, validated output and assist families in treatment choices. The Chemoplaque in refractory settings required single (one) placement with sustained 6-week treatment (without need for multiple cycles or multiple treatments) treating refractory solid tumor, subretinal, and vitreous seeds with potential to significantly reduce patient burden in this micro-orphan childhood retinoblastoma cancer. With its simple placement and absence of any systemic toxicity (or detectable exposure in blood), this may be especially relevant in developing countries. 1. Berry JL, Munier FL, Gallie BL, et al. Response criteria for intraocular retinoblastoma: RB-RECIST. Pediatr  Blood Cancer. May 2021;68(5):e28964. doi:10.1002/pbc.28964 Project Narrat
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Retinoblastoma Phase II Expanded Access Clinical Trial

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy are a leading cause of maternal mortality and morbidity in the United States. The highest prevalence and most severe cases are in Black women, who also have the highest pregnancy-related mortality at 41/100,000 compared to 16.7/ 100,000 births in the general population. This study will examine whether the association between maternal race/ethnicity and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy is partially mediated by psychosocial stress in pregnancy, contributing to the knowledge of preventable causes of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy and informing the development of interventions by elucidating possible causal pathways to reduce racial/ethnic pregnancy health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE To overcome existing barriers to histopathology services critical for cancer care in Africa, this project aims to leverage an existing artificial intelligence (AI)/machine learning-based computational pipeline to develop and validate image analysis algorithms for colorectal cancer (CRC) diagnosis and prognosis in an existing Kenyan cohort. This project will lay the groundwork for an AI-enabled decision support tool for pathologists, or other clinicians involved in cancer care (i.e., radiation oncologist, oncologist), to facilitate prompt and accurate diagnosis, prognosis, risk stratification, and thus therapeutic selection for CRC. Because the computational pipeline leverages open-source software and can be implemented as a turn-key solution intended for web- based cloud deployment, it is well-suited for clinical delivery, capacity building and integration into educational programs, and for future expansion to other emergent or prevalent cancers (i.e., breast, cervical, prostate) in Africa as part of the DS-I Africa Consortium.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs

PHR: The Houston Health Services Research & Development (HSR&D) Center for Innovations in Quality, Effectiveness and Safety (IQuESt) has been continuously funded by HSR&D since 1990, providing strong scientific leadership and institutional infrastructure dedicated to a model of embedded health system research. We have a nearly 20-year tradition of conducting research in partnership with the health care delivery system and responding to its needs, making us pioneers in the execution of the learning health care system model in VHA. The IQuESt mission, “Improving health and well-being through innovations in health care delivery”, conveys our commitment to transformative and innovative research that is aligned with VHA national priorities. IQuESt is ideally poised to contribute to making care more accessible, safer, and more patient-centered with innovative research, rapid implementation of evidence, novel methodologies, solid partnerships, stakeholder engagement, career development of scientists, and infrastructure to promote the learning health care system in VHA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation for Complex Chronic Healthcare (CINCCH) is a HSR&D COIN based at Hines VA Hospital. CINCCH's mission is to conduct research to optimize coordination and contextualization of healthcare delivery and improve outcomes for Veterans with high priority neurologic conditions, disseminate and implement best evidence, and train future researchers. We utilize innovative direct observation methods to collect data that compliments other forms of data to assess quality and patient experiences. CINCCH collaborates with several VA Operations Partners and is affiliated with three universities in the Chicago area. In addition, we have established a Veterans Engagement Panel that provides feedback on grant proposals and dissemination activities. Our COIN's vision is to create the evidence and implement the findings to support and guide VA in providing the best care in the right place at the right time.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation (COIN) for Veteran-Centered and Value-Driven Care has had outstanding productivity and impact on Veteran healthcare and well-being through the application of the National Academy of Medicine's learning health system. In the past 3 years, our 47 investigators generated ~$47 million in operating revenue, published 583 manuscripts, and led 113 projects across our research, implementation science, operational projects/program evaluations and training programs. Our dual-site Center will continue to address our two focus areas: 1) promote Veteran-centered care to improve patient experiences across VA healthcare and community settings and 2) advanced value-driven care by providing Veterans the highest quality care at the lowest financial burden. Building on our prior success, we will continue to partner with operational leaders and our Veteran Engagement Board to innovate new research, implementation science, and operational programs as well as train the next generation of outstanding research leaders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This application proposes the continuation of a Center of Innovation (COIN), called the Pain Research, Informatics, Multimorbidities, and Education (PRIME) Center. The COIN builds on the successes of our existing PRIME Center at VA Connecticut Healthcare System. The goals of the PRIME Center are to conduct research to improve care for all Veterans with a specific focus on pain management and women's health. The Center also fosters innovative research in emerging areas like suicide prevention and CHOICE care. Through a Veteran Engagement Group, the Center strives to be Veteran-centric. Investigators provide research mentoring to train the next generation of VA health services researchers. To achieve its goals, the PRIME Center is supported by partnerships with VHA Patient Care Services and Operations leaders, especially the Pain Management Program and Women's Health Services, as well as a large number of cross-COIN and other VHA medical center collaborations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Access and Delivery Research and Evaluation (CADRE) is seeking to renew its Center of Innovation (COIN) funding to advance research and improve access for Veterans. We aim to build upon our existing expertise, established operational partnerships, and long-term research objectives through prioritizing five overarching goals that align with our focused areas of research and emerging priorities. GOAL 1: Improve access to high quality care for rural Veterans through innovative applications of telehealth in specialty care, community care, and dual use. GOAL 2: Develop and evaluate interventions targeting the multidrug-resistant organism crisis. GOAL 3: Expand efforts in developing innovative health services research in three additional areas: (1) women’s health, (2) epidemic opioid use and substance use disorders, and (3) cardiovascular outcomes. GOAL 4: Continue the Center’s success in supporting mentored career development. GOAL 5: Promote Veteran engagement with recognition that Veterans are experts on Veteran experience.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goal of the Durham Center of Innovation to Accelerate Discovery and Practice Transformation (ADAPT) is to enhance the Veterans Health Administration's (VHA) ability to continually improve health care and optimize Veteran wellbeing and independence. ADAPT will lead innovative research on promoting and sustaining healthy lifestyles, improving access through virtual care, and optimizing Veteran function and independence. Working closely with VA and non-VA partners, ADAPT investigators will apply and advance state-of-the-art methods, translate research findings into meaningful practice change, and train the next generation of VA researchers. ADAPT will play a vital role in helping VHA meet the challenges of providing timely, coordinated, consistently high-quality care to more than 9 million Veterans each year.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Veterans Health Administration (VA) provides care for individuals who are more likely to be racial and ethnic minorities, older, and poorer than the general population. Although VA provides a health care safety net, disparities in health and health care exist for many vulnerable Veteran populations and are associated with increased risks of disability, illness, and death. In addition to individual, provider, and health system factors, disparities may originate outside of the health care system and involve personal behaviors and social and community influences. As a health system committed to delivering high-quality, equitable care to all Veterans, VA must identify vulnerable populations, understand the root causes of disparities, and assess interventions to eliminate them. The Center for Health Equity Research and Promotion's mission is to advance the quality and equity of health and health care for vulnerable Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Given Veterans' increasing choices about where and how they receive care, successful coordination of care will require improving effective communication among a variety of individuals and entities, as well as improved management and use of health information. This project supports the Center for Health Information and Communication, of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Research & Development Service. The Center's mission is to improve Veterans' health care through innovative research on health information, technology, and communication. The Center's vision is to improve Veterans' health through innovative applications of health information and health information systems that serve the population-based and interpersonal needs of patients and health professionals. The Center will generate knowledge about the impact of the Department's investment in health information technology, and will determine how systems-based and interpersonal communication of health information can improve delivery and outcomes of care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Mental Healthcare & Outcomes Research (CeMHOR) is an HSR&D Center of Innovation whose mission is to optimize health and well-being of Veterans through innovative research to improve access to and engagement in evidence-based care for mental health and substance use disorders and prevent suicide. CeMHOR accomplishes its mission by partnering directly with Veterans, clinical leaders, and front-line providers to develop feasible and effective interventions to address top VA and national priorities. CeMHOR expertise in implementation science leads to widespread uptake of these interventions. CeMHOR investigators are also experts in rural health and community engagement. CeMHOR research will apply this expertise to include Veterans who are not receiving VA care, as well as those who use VA services but do not fully engage in needed care. In addition to two focus areas, mental health care access/engagement and suicide prevention, investigators conduct research to address opioid misuse and abuse and advance implementation science.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The mission of the Center for Care Delivery and Outcomes Research (CCDOR) is to develop and evaluate interventions and implementation strategies that improve health care delivery, Veteran engagement in health care, and Veterans' health and functioning in their communities. CCDOR's vision is to elevate the quality, consistency and equity of health care and outcomes for all Veterans through innovative health services and implementation research. CCDOR is a vibrant health services research center of 26 core investigators leading research in Trauma Recovery (Priority 1) and Chronic Pain and Opioid Harms Reduction (Priority 2), as well as conducting and promoting research in additional areas including cancer prevention and control, health aging, and other timely topics. CCDOR has deep and strong partnerships with VA Program Offices, including the Office of Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, the National Center for PTSD, and National Pain Management. These and other partnerships ensure the value and impact of Center research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Healthcare Organization and Implementation Research has a mission to conduct organizationally-partnered, and Veteran-partnered research in order to develop, implement, and evaluate evidence-based and innovative practices that improve Veterans Health Administration (VA) healthcare. Our priority goals are: (1) to advance the field of HSR by sustaining, developing, and growing our existing, scientific focus areas, and growing our evolving and emerging scientific areas; (2) to enrich VA's cadre of world-class HSR investigators, by supporting training and education across the career spectrum; and (3) to grow and support innovation in order to maintain VA at the cutting edge of HSR and adapt to meet VA's ever- changing needs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The VA HSR&D Center for the Study of Healthcare Innovation, Implementation & Policy (CSHIIP) has had a fundamental role in the ongoing transformation of VA health care, through critical examination of multilevel determinants of variations in VA care, development and testing of innovative healthcare delivery models that improve the effectiveness and value of VA care, and impact on VA practice and policy through implementation and spread of evidence-based practice. Our work is anchored in a longstanding history of high-impact research through career development, support, and engagement of a multidisciplinary cadre of investigators, leveraging extensive partnerships that have infused our mission, vision, and values with a deep understanding of VA priorities. These partnerships and priorities have guided our strategic planning, enabling us to build a portfolio of highly responsive research in key focused (primary care, women’s health, high-risk/high-need groups) and emerging areas (complementary/integrative health, specialty care, and emergency management).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Informatics, Decision-Enhancement, and Analytic Sciences (IDEAS) Center of Innovation will conduct research to advance scientific discovery, implement novel interventions, promote cross-center collaboration, increase research capacity, and engage operational partners to improve Veteran health. Our research will focus on the public health threat of antibiotic resistance, on mitigating health risks in Veterans during periods of vulnerability, and on improving medication safety as the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) transitions to a new electronic health record. Across all of these areas, we study methods to promote the adoption of research findings into clinical practice. In the process, we train the next generation of outstanding VA health services researchers. Veteran and stakeholder engagement is a topmost priority for our Center. All of our research is highly collaborative and integrated with clinical programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Defects in cranial neural crest development lead to a variety of craniofacial diseases and malformations affecting the face, e.g. Treacher Collins syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome, and cleft palate to name a few. In this project, I will investigate the regulation and mechanism of function of the secreted protein Draxin, which will significantly enhance our understanding of the regulation of cranial neural crest delamination and migration, providing new scientific avenues for translational research applications in the treatment of craniofacial defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospital acquired bacterial and fungal infections are a major threat to critically ill patients. Innate immunocytes retain memory of prior pathogen exposure, which primes them to elicit a robust antimicrobial response upon re- exposure to additional pathogens. The goal of this project is to advance our understanding of innate immunological memory at the molecular level so that it can be harnessed to protect against hospital acquired bacterial and fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Antibody-Secreting Cells (ASC), including Plasma Cells, are the cells responsible for the production of protective antibodies in response to infections and vaccinations. However, rogue ASC that produce undesired antibodies against human tissues are also responsible for myriad antibody-mediated diseases including autoimmune diseases, allergy and transplant rejection. In this project, we will study the different types of ASC that provide protection and induce disease to understand their nature and regulatory programs. The information gained will improve our ability to design safer and more effective treatments multiple antibody-mediated diseases and modulatory strategies to optimize protective vaccine responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The criminalization of certain drugs in the United States shapes access to preventive and harm reduction services and drives stigma for people who use drugs. Through a supplement for the Harm Reduction Research Network Coordination Center, we propose to establish a roadmap for future research to understand the intersection between harm reduction and the criminal legal systems that limit access to critical services for people who use drugs and enhance understanding of the effectiveness and associated implementation facilitators of and barriers to harm reduction strategies to address the ongoing opioid crisis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Language impairments that result from right hemisphere brain damage (RHD) are poorly understood and the parent K23 award focuses on the nature of RHD communication differences and their neuroanatomic correlates. Funds from this administrative supplement will support additional study staff to complete data analyses through the supplement period. Thus, this supplemental support will ensure the timely completion of the K23 parent project and promote the continuity of PI Dr. Jamila Minga’s plans to build an independent research program developing sensitive diagnostic tools and therapeutic approaches for RHD survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma is a leading cause of death worldwide, with hemorrhage constituting the most common cause of preventable death after injury. One third of hemorrhaging patients develop trauma induced coagulopathy, characterized by abnormal coagulation and inflammation, and require urgent transfusion to decrease the likelihood of organ failure and mortality. Conventional coagulation tests are informative, but most are not adequate for acute hemorrhage control due to long result turnaround times (40 minutes). We will develop a trauma coagulation panel and detection system for four common analytes that will provide clinically actionable data in under 10 minutes at the point-of-care to inform transfusion requirements, reduce iatrogenic blood loss from recurrent coagulation monitoring, and improve clinical workflow in busy trauma settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Kennedy’s disease is a progressive genetic neurodegenerative disease caused by an abnormal androgen receptor (AR) protein. There is currently no effective treatment available to slow, stop, or reverse the disease. Based on promising preclinical results obtained under funded Phase 1 STTR and Phase 2 SBIR grants, Oncternal proposes to further perform the scope of our Phase 2 SBIR using this technical assistance to include bioanalysis method development to begin readiness for GLP in vivo toxicology studies. This method development will continue the development studies with our androgen receptor antagonist and degrader ONCT-505, to destroy the AR protein as a potential therapeutic for Kennedy’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Exposure to high doses of ionizing radiation within a relatively short period of time can cause acute radiation syndrome (ARS), a severe form of radiation injury that can occur at events such as a “dirty bomb” terrorist attack or nuclear power plant leakage. ARS survivors may develop delayed effects of radiation exposure (DEARE) and there are no therapeutic agents available to prevent or alleviate DEARE. Our proposal will define the functional immuno-radiobiology of the regenerative immune system after whole body irradiation in mice. Since the tissue targets of radiation injury are well studied, we can also correlate whether T-cell immune senescence and dysfunction of myeloid population contributes to DEARE. These studies will provide a blueprint for developing optimized immuno-conditioning regimens for immunization protocols in radiation survivors that can be extended to immunocompromised and elderly population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a pressing need for new therapies for obesity and type 2 diabetes, either alone or to complement current treatments. This proposal will establish the molecular mechanisms underlying control of glucose homeostasis by a newly discovered adipokine. Our project is anticipated to lead to a better understanding of how glucose is regulated by insulin-independent pathways, ultimately leading to facilitate the translation to human clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity is a major risk factor for a number of chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer, yet the cause of this is not fully understood. Our preliminary data indicate that the inhibition of hypothalamic Rho-kinase expression leads to a significant increase in appetite, causing obesity. The goal of the study is to understand the new function of Rho-kinase in energy metabolism in the context of obesity, and the proposed experiments could lead to the identification of a potential target for new obesity-associated metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proper temporal and spatial regulation of chromatin is key in human development and health, and dysregulation leads to diseases such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease, and developmental, neurological, and immunological disorders. The proposed research project will further our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that alter the structure and accessibility of chromatin. These studies will contribute to fundamental knowledge about mechanisms of gene regulation and how dysregulation leads to disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a small scale pilot clinical trial to evaluate technology specific improvements for the use of spinal cord epidural stimulation to function in individuals with spinal cord injury. We will develop technology that will interact with currently available stimulators, to facilitate the implementation and integration of training programs for the recovery of locomotion and bladder function in individuals with acute spinal cord injury and promote safe long-term use of the technology in the home and community. This study will start addressing some technology gaps by developing a flexible communication platform specific for spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: We will use invasive electrical stimulation in neurosurgical patient volunteers to manipulate phrase-structure building neural activity in language areas of the brain while subjects are trying to comprehend a sentence. By observing the resulting effect on behavior and neural activity recorded elsewhere in the brain, we hope to better understand how the brain comprehends grammatical relations in sentences, and use this to develop better treatments for language disorder patients who have grammatical difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Opioid drug abuse is associated with worsening of neurocognitive deficits and other neurodegenerative effects seen with HIV infection. This grant proposes to use two in vivo models to examine the complex interplay of opiate-HIV-antiretroviral drug exposure on the central accumulation of drugs (antiretrovirals and morphine), blood-brain barrier function, and neuroimmune function in these mice. Gaining a better understanding of this dynamic interplay, with specific focus on antiretroviral brain concentrations, will improve the current therapeutic approaches for the opiate-using HIV population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE Population-level data on the sexual and reproductive health (SRH) needs and experiences of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex (TNBI) people in the U.S. are virtually non-existent. To further the cross-cutting goal identified by NICHD’s Strategic Plan 2020--of addressing health disparities for sexual and gender minorities-- this study will collect rigorous, foundational, epidemiological data on SRH risk factors and outcomes among a large, diverse sample of TNBI people from across the United States; data that are essential to designing effective public health interventions informing evidence-based healthcare, and improving health outcomes. Further, this study will test and evaluate innovations in study design and survey methodology that will improve recruitment, retention, and data quality in studies of marginalized populations across disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how cell fates are specified in the embryo is a long standing goal of developmental biology. Here we explore a previously unappreciated epithelial to mesenchymal transition in the posterior endoderm, one of the three germ layers that comprise the early embryo, wherein cells invade the neighboring tailbud mesenchyme and potentially contribute to neuromesodermal fates. Understanding signals that regulate this process, the identity of these cells and their progeny, and their potential to differentiate along a remarkably wide range of lineages may have potentially far reaching implications for the study of induced pluripotency, cell reprogramming, and directed differentiation, as well as the pathogenesis of cancer, which commonly originates in endodermally derived tissues, and propagates via epithelial to mesenchymal transition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tyrosine phosphatases are important regulators of information transfer in cells and can play causal role in human diseases when mutated and/or dysregulated. The development of effective tyrosine phosphatase-targeted therapies requires a clearer picture of the distinct biological roles of the 100 human tyrosine phosphatases and a deeper understanding of how these proteins are regulated. The research proposed here entails the development of new approaches to study tyrosine phosphatase structure and function, and these methods will help clarify the mechanisms by which tyrosine phosphatase activity contributes to both normal and aberrant cellular processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The incidence of prostate cancer, the most common malignancy and the second leading cause of cancer- related mortality in men in the United States, increases substantially over 50 years of age and in parallel, the prevalence of hip replacement surgery also increases in that age group. Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (mpMRI) plays an important role in the diagnosis and disease management of prostate cancer, however, mpMRI is challenging in men with hip implants due to severe image distortions and signal loss. In this study, we will establish a robust mpMRI using our novel acquisition and reconstruction strategy that can be widely implemented across all MR scanners for better management of prostate cancer patients with hip implants and subsequently improve their quality of life and overall survival.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation (COIN) for Veteran-Centered and Value-Driven Care has had outstanding productivity and impact on Veteran healthcare and well-being through the application of the National Academy of Medicine's learning health system. In the past 3 years, our 47 investigators generated ~$47 million in operating revenue, published 583 manuscripts, and led 113 projects across our research, implementation science, operational projects/program evaluations and training programs. Our dual-site Center will continue to address our two focus areas: 1) promote Veteran-centered care to improve patient experiences across VA healthcare and community settings and 2) advanced value-driven care by providing Veterans the highest quality care at the lowest financial burden. Building on our prior success, we will continue to partner with operational leaders and our Veteran Engagement Board to innovate new research, implementation science, and operational programs as well as train the next generation of outstanding research leaders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goal of the Durham Center of Innovation to Accelerate Discovery and Practice Transformation (ADAPT) is to enhance the Veterans Health Administration's (VHA) ability to continually improve health care and optimize Veteran wellbeing and independence. ADAPT will lead innovative research on promoting and sustaining healthy lifestyles, improving access through virtual care, and optimizing Veteran function and independence. Working closely with VA and non-VA partners, ADAPT investigators will apply and advance state-of-the-art methods, translate research findings into meaningful practice change, and train the next generation of VA researchers. ADAPT will play a vital role in helping VHA meet the challenges of providing timely, coordinated, consistently high-quality care to more than 9 million Veterans each year.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center of Innovation for Complex Chronic Healthcare (CINCCH) is a HSR&D COIN based at Hines VA Hospital. CINCCH's mission is to conduct research to optimize coordination and contextualization of healthcare delivery and improve outcomes for Veterans with high priority neurologic conditions, disseminate and implement best evidence, and train future researchers. We utilize innovative direct observation methods to collect data that compliments other forms of data to assess quality and patient experiences. CINCCH collaborates with several VA Operations Partners and is affiliated with three universities in the Chicago area. In addition, we have established a Veterans Engagement Panel that provides feedback on grant proposals and dissemination activities. Our COIN's vision is to create the evidence and implement the findings to support and guide VA in providing the best care in the right place at the right time.

PHR: The Center for Access and Delivery Research and Evaluation (CADRE) is seeking to renew its Center of Innovation (COIN) funding to advance research and improve access for Veterans. We aim to build upon our existing expertise, established operational partnerships, and long-term research objectives through prioritizing five overarching goals that align with our focused areas of research and emerging priorities. GOAL 1: Improve access to high quality care for rural Veterans through innovative applications of telehealth in specialty care, community care, and dual use. GOAL 2: Develop and evaluate interventions targeting the multidrug-resistant organism crisis. GOAL 3: Expand efforts in developing innovative health services research in three additional areas: (1) women’s health, (2) epidemic opioid use and substance use disorders, and (3) cardiovascular outcomes. GOAL 4: Continue the Center’s success in supporting mentored career development. GOAL 5: Promote Veteran engagement with recognition that Veterans are experts on Veteran experience.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The Houston Health Services Research & Development (HSR&D) Center for Innovations in Quality, Effectiveness and Safety (IQuESt) has been continuously funded by HSR&D since 1990, providing strong scientific leadership and institutional infrastructure dedicated to a model of embedded health system research. We have a nearly 20-year tradition of conducting research in partnership with the health care delivery system and responding to its needs, making us pioneers in the execution of the learning health care system model in VHA. The IQuESt mission, “Improving health and well-being through innovations in health care delivery”, conveys our commitment to transformative and innovative research that is aligned with VHA national priorities. IQuESt is ideally poised to contribute to making care more accessible, safer, and more patient-centered with innovative research, rapid implementation of evidence, novel methodologies, solid partnerships, stakeholder engagement, career development of scientists, and infrastructure to promote the learning health care system in VHA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Healthcare Organization and Implementation Research has a mission to conduct organizationally-partnered, and Veteran-partnered research in order to develop, implement, and evaluate evidence-based and innovative practices that improve Veterans Health Administration (VA) healthcare. Our priority goals are: (1) to advance the field of HSR by sustaining, developing, and growing our existing, scientific focus areas, and growing our evolving and emerging scientific areas; (2) to enrich VA's cadre of world-class HSR investigators, by supporting training and education across the career spectrum; and (3) to grow and support innovation in order to maintain VA at the cutting edge of HSR and adapt to meet VA's ever- changing needs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Veterans Health Administration (VA) provides care for individuals who are more likely to be racial and ethnic minorities, older, and poorer than the general population. Although VA provides a health care safety net, disparities in health and health care exist for many vulnerable Veteran populations and are associated with increased risks of disability, illness, and death. In addition to individual, provider, and health system factors, disparities may originate outside of the health care system and involve personal behaviors and social and community influences. As a health system committed to delivering high-quality, equitable care to all Veterans, VA must identify vulnerable populations, understand the root causes of disparities, and assess interventions to eliminate them. The Center for Health Equity Research and Promotion's mission is to advance the quality and equity of health and health care for vulnerable Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Informatics, Decision-Enhancement, and Analytic Sciences (IDEAS) Center of Innovation will conduct research to advance scientific discovery, implement novel interventions, promote cross-center collaboration, increase research capacity, and engage operational partners to improve Veteran health. Our research will focus on the public health threat of antibiotic resistance, on mitigating health risks in Veterans during periods of vulnerability, and on improving medication safety as the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) transitions to a new electronic health record. Across all of these areas, we study methods to promote the adoption of research findings into clinical practice. In the process, we train the next generation of outstanding VA health services researchers. Veteran and stakeholder engagement is a topmost priority for our Center. All of our research is highly collaborative and integrated with clinical programs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Given Veterans' increasing choices about where and how they receive care, successful coordination of care will require improving effective communication among a variety of individuals and entities, as well as improved management and use of health information. This project supports the Center for Health Information and Communication, of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Research & Development Service. The Center's mission is to improve Veterans' health care through innovative research on health information, technology, and communication. The Center's vision is to improve Veterans' health through innovative applications of health information and health information systems that serve the population-based and interpersonal needs of patients and health professionals. The Center will generate knowledge about the impact of the Department's investment in health information technology, and will determine how systems-based and interpersonal communication of health information can improve delivery and outcomes of care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The VA HSR&D Center for the Study of Healthcare Innovation, Implementation & Policy (CSHIIP) has had a fundamental role in the ongoing transformation of VA health care, through critical examination of multilevel determinants of variations in VA care, development and testing of innovative healthcare delivery models that improve the effectiveness and value of VA care, and impact on VA practice and policy through implementation and spread of evidence-based practice. Our work is anchored in a longstanding history of high-impact research through career development, support, and engagement of a multidisciplinary cadre of investigators, leveraging extensive partnerships that have infused our mission, vision, and values with a deep understanding of VA priorities. These partnerships and priorities have guided our strategic planning, enabling us to build a portfolio of highly responsive research in key focused (primary care, women’s health, high-risk/high-need groups) and emerging areas (complementary/integrative health, specialty care, and emergency management).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This application proposes the continuation of a Center of Innovation (COIN), called the Pain Research, Informatics, Multimorbidities, and Education (PRIME) Center. The COIN builds on the successes of our existing PRIME Center at VA Connecticut Healthcare System. The goals of the PRIME Center are to conduct research to improve care for all Veterans with a specific focus on pain management and women's health. The Center also fosters innovative research in emerging areas like suicide prevention and CHOICE care. Through a Veteran Engagement Group, the Center strives to be Veteran-centric. Investigators provide research mentoring to train the next generation of VA health services researchers. To achieve its goals, the PRIME Center is supported by partnerships with VHA Patient Care Services and Operations leaders, especially the Pain Management Program and Women's Health Services, as well as a large number of cross-COIN and other VHA medical center collaborations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The mission of the Center for Care Delivery and Outcomes Research (CCDOR) is to develop and evaluate interventions and implementation strategies that improve health care delivery, Veteran engagement in health care, and Veterans' health and functioning in their communities. CCDOR's vision is to elevate the quality, consistency and equity of health care and outcomes for all Veterans through innovative health services and implementation research. CCDOR is a vibrant health services research center of 26 core investigators leading research in Trauma Recovery (Priority 1) and Chronic Pain and Opioid Harms Reduction (Priority 2), as well as conducting and promoting research in additional areas including cancer prevention and control, health aging, and other timely topics. CCDOR has deep and strong partnerships with VA Program Offices, including the Office of Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, the National Center for PTSD, and National Pain Management. These and other partnerships ensure the value and impact of Center research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently no clear understanding of why an enterovirus like coxsackievirus, that typically targets the gut, would cause myocarditis leading to heart failure. This project will examine whether the ability of coxsackievirus to replicate in the mitochondria of cardiac cells leads to sex differences in myocardial inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Depression and poverty are linked together in an intractable syndemic affectig millions of people around the world. Poverty is a major cause of depression, while depression significantly reduces economic productivity. Integrated intervention approaches that seek to interrupt the cycle of poverty and depression have not been tested. This application describes ASHA: an integrated intervention that combines depression treatment with economic strengthening for depressed, low income women in rural Bangladesh. If the research is successful, we will work with government and NGO partners to initiate new collaborations between mental health researcher’s/policy makers and development groups seeking to increase economic productivity and wellbeing in Bangladesh and other countries of the global south.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our studies of the elimination of morphologically complex cells will provide important fundamental insights on programmed cell death and clearance, which are essential facets of proper development and homeostasis. These studies are relevant to public health in several respects: our findings may help devise targeted therapies against both tumor formation and immune dysfunction as well as in understanding brain development, injury and disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The Cleveland Kidney, Urology and Hematology Research (KUHR) Training Network has designed a one and a half daylong meeting to train the next generation of KUHR professionals. The proposed KUHR meeting seeks to support the development of these emerging investigator leaders who will gain the expertise to provide innovative solutions to the fields of Kidney, Urology and Hematology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is the most severe form of major depressive disorder (MDD), and responsible for a disproportionate portion of its morbidity. We will use a novel approach to resting state fMRI, known as precision functional mapping (PFM), to develop patient-specific biomarkers of TRD and the depressed state. Better understanding of trait and state features of depression may lead to improved diagnosis and treatment of this disabling condition.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations of the mitochondrial DNA-encoded ATPase 6 (MTATP6) gene lead to impaired mitochondrial ATP synthesis, which results in a variety of neurological mitochondrial diseases. Allotopic expression of MTATP6 is a plausible gene therapy approach for restoring mitochondrial dysfunction caused by MTATP6 mutations, while to date it has only been tested in vitro due to the lack of an animal model. The proposed study aims to generate the first MTATP6 targeting mouse model using a novel base editing technology, and develop an adeno- associated virus (AAV)-based gene therapy strategy for MTATP6 patients.
