IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Family violence imposes substantial and long-lasting burdens on children, particularly those in heavily policed and incarcerated communities. But little is known about how objective and subjective experiences of institutional contact in such communities may affect family violence incidence, disclosure, help-seeking, or consequences. The proposed project will advance the study of children’s exposure to family violence in the contemporary United States by collecting primary qualitative and survey data and applying inductive and latent variable methods for formative analysis. psychometric validation, and hypothesis testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Malaria, caused by Plasmodium species, is an unresolved global health burden without an effective vaccine. Development of potent and translatable vaccines against malaria has been hampered by our incomplete understanding of the mechanisms by which the immune system can be trained to control Plasmodium infections. The goal of this research is to dissect mechanisms of CD8 T cell-mediated protection against liver-stage malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk and severity of disease associated with environmental and endogenous exposures can vary greatly depending on the unique genetic makeup of an individual. The large number of possible genetic and environment combinations limits our ability to identify these interactions despite their potential to inform strategies for disease prevention and therapeutic intervention. I propose to develop high-throughput methods that overlay genetic and environmental perturbations to systematically identify these gene-by-environment interactions as well as pinpoint the specific cell types responsible for the response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: There is a great shortage in the United States of qualified pediatrician-scientists, including pediatric endocrinologists, with a growing unmet need for better treatments of pediatric endocrine diseases like obesity and diabetes. These diseases pose a great threat to the future health of our nation's children (illustrated most recently by the increased risk conferred by obesity in the recent COVID-19 pandemic), and are a major source of health disparities. We hope that our training program, with strong mentors and educational opportunities, will address this need by guiding and supporting the early careers of a highly motivated and diverse group of pediatric endocrinology trainees, and inspiring them to become leaders in academic pediatric endocrinology and biomedical research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Developmental Endocrinology;Endocrinology;Research
PROJECT_TITLE: RESEARCH IN DEVELOPMENTAL ENDOCRINOLOGY AND METABOLISM

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative To advance healthcare quality improvement and clinical research by integrating clinical data across institutions in a privacy-preserving manner, we will develop a decentralized framework to compute with comprehensive clinical variables and with numerous records, to discover and alleviate data manipulation during the learning process, and to conduct controlled experiments and design/test a web portal with physician-researchers, on real cross-institutional COVID-19 data. This project is innovative as it proposes a new integration methodology for vertical/horizontal modeling, a novel data manipulation resisting methods, and a hardened prototype for a practical blockchain application. We expect powerful and sustainable impact for care providers, clinical researchers, and patients, and can eventually accelerate the development of methods/technologies to increase willingness of institutions to participate in such a collaboration for improving the effectiveness of healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC) welcomes the opportunity to continue partnering with the National Institutes of Health (NIH) National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS) to advance our shared goal of enhancing the diversity of the biomedical research workforce. Through this supplement funding request, the AAMC will be able to continue to develop and deliver a multichannel educational program for cohorts of NIH- awarded K99/R00 scholars from diverse backgrounds, for example from groups underrepresented in research, that provides a full suite of career development tools and supports as they transition from postdoctoral appointments into academic research faculty positions. Receiving supplemental funds will allow the AAMC to proceed with richly and robustly engaging the scholars in a curriculum throughout all award years that includes virtual skills-building workshop and in-person networking and learning event participation, engagement activities with their local institutional and AAMC-identified mentors, and leadership and professional development conference attendance with field experts and peers nationwide.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The VA HSR&D Center for the Study of Healthcare Innovation, Implementation & Policy (CSHIIP) has had a fundamental role in the ongoing transformation of VA health care, through critical examination of multilevel determinants of variations in VA care, development and testing of innovative healthcare delivery models that improve the effectiveness and value of VA care, and impact on VA practice and policy through implementation and spread of evidence-based practice. Our work is anchored in a longstanding history of high-impact research through career development, support, and engagement of a multidisciplinary cadre of investigators, leveraging extensive partnerships that have infused our mission, vision, and values with a deep understanding of VA priorities. These partnerships and priorities have guided our strategic planning, enabling us to build a portfolio of highly responsive research in key focused (primary care, women’s health, high-risk/high-need groups) and emerging areas (complementary/integrative health, specialty care, and emergency management).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Mental Healthcare & Outcomes Research (CeMHOR) is an HSR&D Center of Innovation whose mission is to optimize health and well-being of Veterans through innovative research to improve access to and engagement in evidence-based care for mental health and substance use disorders and prevent suicide. CeMHOR accomplishes its mission by partnering directly with Veterans, clinical leaders, and front-line providers to develop feasible and effective interventions to address top VA and national priorities. CeMHOR expertise in implementation science leads to widespread uptake of these interventions. CeMHOR investigators are also experts in rural health and community engagement. CeMHOR research will apply this expertise to include Veterans who are not receiving VA care, as well as those who use VA services but do not fully engage in needed care. In addition to two focus areas, mental health care access/engagement and suicide prevention, investigators conduct research to address opioid misuse and abuse and advance implementation science.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Center for Healthcare Organization and Implementation Research has a mission to conduct organizationally-partnered, and Veteran-partnered research in order to develop, implement, and evaluate evidence-based and innovative practices that improve Veterans Health Administration (VA) healthcare. Our priority goals are: (1) to advance the field of HSR by sustaining, developing, and growing our existing, scientific focus areas, and growing our evolving and emerging scientific areas; (2) to enrich VA's cadre of world-class HSR investigators, by supporting training and education across the career spectrum; and (3) to grow and support innovation in order to maintain VA at the cutting edge of HSR and adapt to meet VA's ever- changing needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative  Textural aspects of food, termed mouthfeel, are important flavor qualities that can determine whether food is eaten or discarded, and thus, are essential factors for dietary health. Currently, little is known about the basic neuronal mechanisms underlying mouthfeel or the processes by which this flavor modality modifies taste. This work provides a comprehensive identification of mammalian mechanosensory neurons of the tongue and identifies mechanotransduction channels that underlie mouthfeel, with the long-term goal of understanding how mechanosensation impacts flavor perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Social animals depend on vocal communication for survival in many contexts, and the brain must extract information from acoustic features of calls and communicate with circuits for appropriate behavioral responses. Depending on the call meaning, this processing must occur over time scales needed for guiding various behaviors. The research proposed here tests the overall hypothesis that top-down circuits in the auditory system facilitate vocalization-guided behaviors across contexts, using multiple methods for monitoring and manipulating activity in neurons and ensembles to dissect the circuits involved in driving behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will test the hypothesis that objective social isolation and loneliness are linked to neurobehavioral mechanisms involved in social perception and motivation in individuals with and without serious mental illness. It will also investigate the specific dynamic interactions among these phenomena in daily life and how they, as well as the neurobehavioral predictors, are linked to day-to-day functioning. The findings of this project could provide novel targets for therapeutics aimed at improving functioning and overall quality of life in individuals with serious mental illnesses, as well as quantitative phenotypes for use in genetic investigations and early detection efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative of Parent U01 AG071450 The overall goal of this project is to collect and disseminate critical data on cognitive, physical, and sensory functioning and risk for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) in Wave VI of the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health), when participants will be in their mid-40s. These new data, when combined with Add Health’s existing collection of extraordinarily rich multi-level and longitudinal measures and its new Wave VI data, will facilitate the scientific community’s understanding of the interplay of social, economic, behavioral, and biological factors that influence cognitive, physical, and sensory functioning in midlife and lead to ADRD in later life. Moreover, because Add Health is a diverse nationally representative sample, adding these data to Wave VI will greatly increase understanding of cognitive, physical, and sensory functioning within key health disparity populations in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Results from the proposed non-clinical, long-term safety studies of NNI-362 in dogs and rats and the further scale-up of GMP material that is formulated into chewable gel caps will allow for the ongoing clinical development of Phase 2 proof-of-concept trial in mild to moderate Alzheimer’s patients. As proposed in the Specific Aims, long-term administration of NNI-362 (6-months) in male and female rats and dogs is required in order to treat humans for the same length of time, which should be sufficient to observe neuron regeneration in aged Alzheimer’s patients. The completion of Phase1a placebo-controlled trial of NNI-362, appears to demonstrate safety and potential efficacy by reversing an early brain-specific AD progression biomarker (i.e., phosphoTau181) and Neuronascent further hypothesizes that the longer-term administration of NNI-362 over a six-month period will promote neuron regeneration resulting in the reversal of cognitive impairment and functional deficits in mild to moderate AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Cleft palate is the most common pediatric craniofacial anomaly, and up to 40% of children with cleft palate will develop severe limitations in speech intelligibility and acceptability due to velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI). This research will compare the effectiveness of existing surgical procedures for VPI, establishing which procedures are most effective at improving speech and determining the risks of each procedure. The results will directly contribute to NIDCR’s mission to improve the health of children with craniofacial anomalies by enabling surgeons to select the most effective, least harmful surgical procedure for each child with VPI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative At the conclusion of this application, we will have developed and tested a mobile-based culturally adapted intervention that is aimed at improving the surgical experience of Latinx families and children undergoing outpatient surgery. We strongly believe that this innovative culturally adapted mobile-based intervention will better prepare Latinx children for surgery, reduce pain, anxiety and opioid requirements and improve the clinical course and family experience (better satisfaction scores). Once tested, we plan to disseminate this culturally adapted mobile-based intervention to all surgical facilities providing services to Latinx children and their families in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Public Health Relevance Of the 3.5 million Americans who suffer from kidney stones each year, 230,000 have large stone volumes that require either invasive surgery, or long-duration endoscopy which incurs high complication rates. To remove stones faster, we propose a new device that transforms almost instantaneously from an endoscope to a steer- able catheter with a large open lumen for suctioning out stone fragments. Success in this research will re- duce operation times, improve stone-free rates, and make many more patients candidates for minimally invasive ureteroscopy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sex differences in outcomes following viral infections are well-described and may reflect sexual dimorphism in NK cell composition and effector function. This proposal will define how an X chromosome-linked epigenetic regulator, UTX, controls natural killer (NK) cell effector responses to viral infection and is responsible for NK cell sex differences. A deeper understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms of NK cell sex differences will lead to new insights into NK cell function and strategies for optimizing anti-viral immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Medication errors or adverse events are a major public health problem causing thousands of deaths annually. This proposal aims to build wearable cameras with real-time computer vision algorithms to identify medications when initially selected by an anesthesiology provider during drug preparation or before injection to potentially prevent accidentally giving the wrong drug. Drug dose will also be determined and recorded in an electronic health record, potentially increasing record accuracy and decreasing manual tasks for anesthesiologists so they can focus on direct patient care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will develop and validate stakeholder-informed quality measures to improve clinical care and outcomes for opioid-exposed infants. These quality measures will serve as pilot data for a pragmatic clinical trial to determine if clinician exposure to measures improves infant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hip fracture risk is six- to eight-fold higher in adults with type 1 diabetes and occurs at a relatively young age. Bone mineral density alone does not explain the higher fracture risk in this population. However, little is known about bone quality in adults with type 1 diabetes. This study proposes to explore bone quality and strength at the hip in adults with long-standing type 1 diabetes compared to age-, gender-, and body mass index-matched controls without diabetes over a period of 3 years. Characterizing bone phenotype and understanding the effect of glycemic control on bone health will help us understand the mechanisms of bone fragility; and thus plan future interventions to improve bone health in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to smell is necessary for long-term physical and behavioral health in humans. Epidemiological studies suggest that older adults with impaired olfactory perception have a 4-fold increase in mortality within 5 years, and an increasing number of studies detect significant correlation between olfactory deficits and the future onset of neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheimer’s. The proposed research is motivated not only by the desire to solve a fascinating molecular mystery that constitutes the keystone of olfaction, but also by the need to obtain insight to a sensory modality critical for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Due to intersectional stigma based on race, sexual orientation, and HIV-status, Black men who have sex with men (BMSM) and live with HIV (LWH) face multiple barriers to antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence that increase the risk of virological failure, chronic inflammation, morbidity and mortality, and HIV transmission to HIV-negative sexual partners. Culturally-sensitive, evidence-based interventions (EBIs) for BMSM/LWH to address these barriers and improve ART adherence are still lacking. Through the proposed project, the candidate will design and pilot test a technology-enhanced, culturally-sensitive EBI for BMSM/LWH to address intersectional stigma-related barriers to ART adherence, to ultimately promote viral suppression and reduce chronic inflammation levels.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Characterized by an inability to create insulin, Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a debilitating disease that can cause long-term damage to or even failure of various organs, leading to irreparable injuries such as blindness, amputation, stroke, and eventually death. These research funds would provide safety reporting, data management, and randomization support for studies investigating treatments for T1D in the Immune Tolerance Network (ITN).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Underserved, racial and ethnic minority communities are experiencing higher rates of COVID-19 cases and associated mortality compared to whites due to long standing social and structural inequities that also drive disparities in chronic diseases such as stroke, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and hypertension. Patients with underlying chronic diseases who are recovering from COVID-19 depend on the support of family caregivers who are being exposed to the same pandemic and racial stressors, exposure that can affect the health and quality of life of both partners. The primary goal of this study is to test the efficacy of an adapted, telehealth-enhanced intervention that targets barriers impacting family illness management behaviors of survivor:carepartner dyads for improved quality of life and COVID-19/chronic disease related health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ewing sarcoma is a cancerous bone tumor affecting children and young adults, which still lacks effective therapy and continues to be associated with high rates of mortality. Transcription factor ETV6 is a vulnerability in Ewing sarcoma cells while being largely dispensable in normal tissues, indicating a wide therapeutic index for perturbing ETV6 function in this disease. This proposal is dedicated to characterizing the cancer maintenance function of ETV6 and leveraging this new knowledge to develop beneficial therapies for Ewing sarcoma patients.

PHR: Project Narrative The quickening pace of scientific discovery demands a new generation of physician-scientists who can understand the languages that are spoken both in the research setting and at the bedside. Our plan is to provide rigorous scientific and clinical training in a safe and inclusive environment to train MD-PhD Physician-Scientists. Using this knowledge, these individuals will be ideally positioned to make significant contributions to and improvements in human health, and thereby become the next generation of leaders in biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An effective therapy with reduced risks and side effects for treating venous malformations is greatly needed. We propose to develop an intravenous drug delivery system comprised of very small (“nano”) particles that will convert to a tissue-targeting state when irradiated within venous malformations. By our strategy, the accumulation of drugs at the disease site will be enhanced while off-target drug delivery will be minimized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE  This proposal seeks to understand the role of tonic GABAergic signaling in shaping dendritic excitability within the neocortex. We combine an array of methods to monitor and manipulate neural activity in reduced preparations and in vivo. Results from these studies will identify cellular and circuit mechanisms by which GABAergic transmission promotes healthy brain function and provide important insights into how dysregulation of GABA signaling may contribute to neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is associated with deficits in trust-related decision making, contributing to the growing public health problem of elder fraud. This project will (i) characterize basic neurocognitive processes in learning to trust in aging; and (ii) determine if trust-related decision making can be optimized via neurofeedback training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human antibodies are highly diverse and can recognize a wide range of epitopes to confer protection against different pathogens. The epitope specificity of an antibody is determined by its structure, which is in turn determined by its primary amino acid sequence. This proposal aims to develop a novel experimental platform to characterize antibody-antigen interactions in a high-throughput manner and identify molecular features that can help predict the epitope of an antibody based on its sequence.

PROJECT_TITLE: High-throughput identification of antibody features for sequence-based epitope prediction

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have found that infection with SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 diagnosis are associated with the development and progression of both Type 1 (T1D) and Type 2 Diabetes (T2D). The proposed study will engage 15 sites from the National Patient-Centered Clinical Research Network (PCORnet) and the T1D Exchange to recruit 1600 English- and Spanish-speaking pediatric and adult patients with recently diagnosed T1D or T2D who have had a known COVID-19 infection in the past 90 days or no recent diagnosis of COVID- 19 infection in the past year. The study will follow this population for 2 years and will utilize linked electronic health data from PCORnet sites to understand the impact of COVID-19 on diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Neutrophils are white blood cells that kill the pathogens in infected tissue. We believe that this antibacterial function of neutrophils is activated by mechanical forces these cells experience as they migrate through vascular endothelial junctional barrier into infected tissue. The research will help us understand how the tension sensed by transmigrating neutrophil “educates” neutrophils to fight with tissue pathogens and hopefully lead to better treatments for patients with bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced management of children with type 1 diabetes (T1D) aims to utilize diabetes devices, such as insulin pumps (IP) and continuous glucose monitors (CGM), to optimize glycemic control; however, use of these devices has not resulted in the expected improvements in T1D outcomes. We will identify unmet psychoeducational needs in parents of children using IP and CGM to manage T1D and leverage this information to inform a feasibility and acceptability study assessing an app-delivered psychoeducational intervention intended to improve knowledge and alter behaviors related to diabetes technology use. Successful execution of this project will inform a future randomized controlled trial that will demonstrate the efficacy of an easily distributed psychoeducational tool that will help to realize the full potential of diabetes technologies while also providing Dr. Marks with the training and mentorship needed to transition to an independent physician scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proton-pumping vacuolar ATPase (V-ATPase; V1Vo-ATPase) is a multisubunit enzyme complex that is responsible for vital cellular functions in all eukaryotic organisms and which is linked to several devastating human diseases such as renal tubular acidosis, osteopetrosis, diabetes, neurodegeneration, cancer, and microbial and viral infections. This proposal requests funds for obtaining high-resolution structural information for active holo V-ATPase and its autoinhibited proton channel subcomplex in lipid nanodiscs to study inhibitor binding and for elucidating V-ATPase's unique mode of regulation, for elucidating biochemical properties of specific isoform containing human V-ATPase, and to develop single-domain antibodies directed against yeast and human V-ATPase subunit isoforms as a novel tool for studying V-ATPase's structure and regulatory mechanisms. The long-term goal of the project is to gain a molecular understanding of the enzyme's role in human disease, and to identify novel ways to modulate the activity of disease causing V-ATPase in a subunit isoform and tissue specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section Adolescents may be drivers of local tuberculosis transmission; they are a unique population due to their dynamic cognitive, psychological, and physical changes, and they can spread tuberculosis through their expanding social networks. A more robust understanding of tuberculosis epidemics will be gained through the proposed research by using geographic information and tuberculosis strain types to identify individual-, household- and population-level drivers of tuberculosis spread in adolescents. Our study will elucidate important person, place, and time interactions of tuberculosis in adolescents to inform how to best deploy tailored interventions to reduce tuberculosis spread in communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have developed a non-infectious, self-replicative SARS-CoV-2 replicon system that is a safe and effective tool for antiviral screening and amenable to genetic engineering for studying drug resistance. We have identified a small molecule inhibitor of SARS-CoV-2 antiviral activity, and early medicinal chemistry efforts have optimized this lead. This project aims to further identify and characterize compounds toward the development of novel inhibitors against SARS-CoV-2 with potent, nanomolar antiviral activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Neurodevelopmental disorders, including microcephaly and autism, as well as neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s, and cancer result in significant human suffering and impose significant annual costs on the US health care system and society as a whole. This proposal seeks to understand how diet influences neural stem cell proliferation decisions during development. Neural stem cells are the cells that make all the neurons in the brain. Results garnered from this research will stimulate new discoveries in translational stem cell research in the context of normal development and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Million Marker is the first company to provide tools and services that allow people to understand their personal environmental chemical exposures (i.e. endocrine disrupting chemicals, EDCs) in order to prevent diseases and optimize their health by changing their lifestyle choices. This work aims to develop an affordable and scalable intervention program, with interactive curriculum and individualized support, that can be readily disseminated and commercialized to help customers reduce exposures to EDCs. Completion of this proposal will allow Million Marker to offer EDC testing and intervention to the general public, thus taking steps to address this global health crisis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA medical centers are frequently challenged when attempting to safely transfer VwD when being treated in medical centers, extended care, or long-term care. There are rooms with overhead lifts, and crane lifts are available, but the number of injuries to staff remains high. Solutions are needed that can be re-used sequentially by multiple veterans in a facility and moved from room to room as needed; and that could also be used long-term by VwD in a VA facility or a VwD's home. This project's focus on EPW users is relevant to individuals within the VA's special disability programs which are high priority. The VA Patient Care Mission stresses providing Prosthetic and Sensory Aides (beds and wheelchairs) to improve veterans' health and well-being. This research can potentially improve safety, function, and quality of assist devices for bed/EPW transfers, and the quality of life and community participation for many veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Holoprosencephaly (HPE), a common malformation of the forebrain and midface, has a complex etiology involving genetic and environmental risk factors. Fetal alcohol exposure is one such factor, but its interaction with predisposing genetic variants, the identity of its embryonic target cells, and the developmental pathways it affects are all poorly understood. Using mouse models of HPE, we aim to provide insight into these questions to enhance understanding of gene-environment interaction in causation of birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. Antibodies and binding proteins have found widespread use in all aspects of life sciences research and are increasingly being used as therapeutics. Here we will develop multiplexed techniques to generate novel antibodies and binding proteins against all target antigens within the human and zebrafish proteomes and quickly screen all of the resulting leads for cross-reactivity. Successful completion of this work will provide a treasure trove of sequence-verified, high-specificity antibodies, and binding proteins.

PHR: Cases of and deaths from most chronic diseases are disproportionally higher in communities of color. These health disparities are linked to chronic stress and the proposed research will gather knowledge about anti- racist healing in nature as a tool for stress reduction in BIPOC young adults. The culturally-appropriate, and affirming low-cost interventions that are developed will promote telomere growth to prevent health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Massive observational cohorts with the exposome (ie, multiple environmental factors) and phenome (disease risk factors) are being assembled by countries worldwide. We will equip the biomedical community with data science and machine learning tools for robust data-driven imputation, discovery, interpretation, and re-use of complex exposure-phenotype associations that emerge from big data. Applications of our methods will address several high-priority goals for the National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) including identification of environmental health disparities in heart disease that are critical for precision medicine implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on (i) creation of novel technologies for rigorous and experimentally concise analysis of higher-order RNA structure, (ii) application of these technologies to compelling challenges in understanding how higher-order tertiary structures and regulatory networks govern the functions of pathogenic viruses and coding and non-coding RNAs, and (iii) illumination of principles underlying small-molecule ligandability of RNA. This project will create broadly implementable technologies for analysis of RNA structure and function, and use these to understand biological regulatory networks in novel ways, ultimately driving both basic biological discovery and RNA-targeted drug development.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) classified Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) as “Threat level urgent” and called for “urgent and aggressive action” to address a significant public health crisis in 2013 and 2019. The molecular epidemiology of CDI has changed drastically over the past 10 year and the epidemic strain, restriction endonuclease analysis (REA) group BI, PCR ribotype (RT) 027 has decreased significantly. However, REA group Y, which commonly correlates to RT 014 and 020[Y(RT014/020)], has remained a prominent group strain since the 1980s. Despite the endemic nature of Y(RT014/020), a detailed molecular analysis has never been completed. We propose to determine the prevalence and risk factors associated with the endemic Y(RT014/020) and the epidemic BI/RT027 group strains and perform a rigorous genomic analysis of Y(RT014/020) and BI/RT027 obtaining critical information to assess the endemic nature of Y(RT014/020) to assess our hypothesis that Y(RT014/020) resides within an unknown community reservoir.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it characterizes key technological barriers to equitable care for patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), describing racial/ethnic inequities and rural- urban disparities in access to imaging technologies and to the specialist gatekeepers of these technologies. It identifies how imaging resources should be mobilized to ensure that all patients with AD are able to realize the full benefits of new treatments, and provides guidance to policymakers to support planning and legal and regulatory efforts to mitigate disparities in AD morbidity and mortality.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement NIH has identified “workforce development” as one of its 5 strategic goals for biomedical data science in the coming decades and has called for integrative training in data-science approaches through curricula and mentored research. This proposed R25 program is designed to address the nationwide shortage of Big Data health science researchers in NIAID focus areas. The training program will target junior faculty in health science disciplines at the University of South Carolina and will foster a research environment to encourage individuals from diverse backgrounds, including those from underrepresented groups, to pursue further Big Data health science research in HIV, COVID-19, and other infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Muscle stem cells are required for muscle maintenance and regeneration, especially under disease and aging conditions. This project aims to explore the function and regulation of a novel subset of muscle stem cells that uniquely interact with the immune system to mediate efficient muscle repair. Knowledge from the proposed work will benefit future studies into treatment of degenerative diseases and age-related muscle wasting.

PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE This training program is specifically designed to train a new cadre of researchers and leaders to address major but as yet under-studied public health problems engendered by conditions prevalent in urban and rural informal human settlements (slums) of low and middle-income countries (LMIC). This training is relevant also to developed countries as informal settlements in the form of homeless encampments expand. Selected candidates will undergo field training on site in LMICs to develop new global health research skills framedwithin our project research theme of health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Air pollution is the world’s most important environmental risk factor that contributes more to global morbidity and mortality than tuberculosis, malaria, AIDS, wars and famine combined. In this transformative project, we provide compelling new data on air pollution as a disruptor of endogenous biologic “circadian” rhythms. Through careful studies in animals and humans and large cohorts, we will evaluate the impact of exposure and personalized interventions on heart and metabolic health. Our results will provide compelling new data to prevent the health problems caused by air pollution exposure globally.

PHR: Thailand HIV/AIDS and Infectious Disease Clinical Trials Unit (THAI CTU)  SF 424 (R&R) Other Project Information – Project Narrative The Thailand HIV/AIDS and Infectious Disease Clinical Trials Unit (THAI CTU) is a collaboration between the Chiang Mai University-Research Institute for Health Sciences (CMU-RIHES) in Chiang Mai, Thailand, and the Thai Red Cross AIDS Research Centre (TRC-ARC) in Bangkok, Thailand. The renewed THAI CTU and its four CRSs will participate in developing and conducting clinical trials proposed by the four NIH HIV/AIDS Clinical Trials Networks: HIV/AIDS adult therapeutics; HIV/AIDS maternal, adolescent and pediatric therapeutics; HIV prevention; and HIV vaccines. The collaboration between the NIH HIV/AIDS Clinical Trials Networks and their affiliated CTUs, including the THAI CTU, will lead to development of innovative and effective measures for HIV treatment and prevention, and ultimately to HIV cure and an end to the global HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to identify and study relevant patterns of post-irradiation morbidity and mortality in a controlled, well-defined NHP population, by collaborating and sharing data with qualified investigators. Data sharing and administrative oversight are designed to maximize use of the resource. The program will identify patterns of post-irradiation morbidity; identify characteristics of animals with differing radiation-induced disorders; assess late effects of prior mitigator treatment; and refine the cohort to balance age, sex, dose, and mitigator type.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE This training program is specifically designed to train a new cadre of researchers and leaders to address major but as yet under-studied public health problems engendered by conditions prevalent in urban and rural informal human settlements (slums) of low and middle-income countries (LMIC). This training is relevant also to developed countries as informal settlements in the form of homeless encampments expand. Selected candidates will undergo field training on site in LMICs to develop new global health research skills framed within our project research theme of health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT – OVERALL Failures of the mucus clearance system can produce consequences for the US population in the context of susceptibilities to inhaled infectious agents and environmental toxins. In addition, failure of the mucus clearance system produces a spectrum of muco-obstructive lung diseases, including COPD, asthma, non-CF bronchiectasis, and the rare genetic diseases cystic fibrosis and pulmonary ciliary dyskinesia. There is a great need to elucidate the normal structure and function of mucins to understand their roles in lung health and to develop strategies for the treatment of chronic failures of mucus clearance, i.e., patients with muco-obstructive diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Maahs, David Matthew PROJECT NARRATIVE The prime objective of our National K12 “Diabetes-Docs: Physician-Scientist Career Development Program” (DiabDocs) is to train and foster the development of diverse physician-scientists for productive and impactful diabetes research careers with a specific focus on type 1 diabetes (T1D). Our K12 program is designed to provide: 1) a mentored research experience, 2) research project support, and 3) career development training, including directed attention to diversity, equity and inclusion. We are confident that we will attract the highest caliber of applicants and mentor them toward impactful careers in academic medicine as skilled physician-scientist leaders. Project Narrative Page 9

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Differences in the HIV Rev-Rev Response Element (RRE) regulatory axis allow the virus to adapt to different fitness environments. This project will elucidate how variations in the Rev-RRE system permit the virus to navigate the sexual transmission bottleneck and establish and maintain latency. Improved understanding of these mechanisms has the potential to inform the development of improved prophylaxis to prevent new infections and improved methods of perturbing latency to accomplish a cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE N6,2’-O-dimethyladenosine (m6Am) is an abundant RNA modification located adjacent to the 5’-end of mRNA 7-methylguanosine (m7G) cap structure that can have a major influence on gene expression of the transcriptome regulating immunity and host-virus interactions. This project will define how HIV infections reprogram host epitranscriptomes in the presence and absence of methamphetamine to cause immune dysfunctions. Results of the proposed studies would provide insight into new mechanisms and targets for developing innovative approaches to eradicate or cure HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative Every tumor is biologically unique. Moving from “one-size-fits-all” to personalized medicine in cancer, we need to develop novel platforms to help us improve our understanding of cellular characterizations of individual’s cancer biology and therapeutics. In this project we will develop a personalized ex vivo platform including individual’s cancerous epithelium and the tumor microenvironment. We will show the utility of our system for testing conventional and novel therapeutics. The patient-specific drug response assay technology has the potential to inform the way treatment decisions are made within the context of pancreatic cancer and perhaps other complex solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Nearly 40% of descendants from East Asia possess a genetic variant severely limiting their ability to metabolize reactive aldehydes. In addition, several other genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway also occur in Asians which may impact organ injury, particularly during surgery. This project will develop tools in the basic science laboratory to better understand how genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway may impact organ damage and translate these strategies to monitor and reduce organ damage in humans undergoing surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disease in world, but current symptomatic therapies are of limited value and have unwanted side-effects. Through the use of new genetic tools to manipulate and monitor the function of neurons in the brain regions responsible for PD, we have found that a particular type of neuron plays a pivotal role in both the core motor symptoms of PD and dyskinetic side-effects of the gold standard treatment for PD – levodopa. The proposed studies will build upon this discovery to forge a better understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying PD in the hope that this will lead us to new symptomatic therapies that are more effective and less burdened by side-effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Gene therapy products using adeno-associated-virus (AAV) vector have shown to be promising for treating diseases in humans. However, AAV is widespread in humans with high prevalence of anti-AAV antibodies in human population, and currently, only individuals who do not have anti-AAV antibodies are eligible for AAV gene therapy treatment. This proposal is to develop an effective antibody-degrading protein product to transiently remove the pre-existing anti-AAV antibodies for AAV gene therapy, towards clinical application and commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Parent Award) Sjögren's syndrome is an an autoimmune disease associated with local inflammation and decreased function of lacrimal and salivary glands, as well as systemic inflammation of many other internal organs. Treatment options are limited, possibly because approved treatments do not achieve immunomodulation at both local glandular and systemic sites, both of which sustain disease. Capitalizing on the novel properties of elastin-like polypeptides, we develop distinct strategies to more effectively treat local, glandular and systemic symptoms with immunomodulatory agents, and then explore their efficacy and toxicity in combination, all in murine models of the disease.

PHR: Project Narrative This study will provide high-quality, representative data on the capacity of Elevating Voices, Addressing Depression, Toxic Stress and Equity in Group Prenatal Care (EleVATE GC) to reduce perintal depression, preterm birth, and low birthweight in African-American women. If findings from this study indicate that EleVATE GC is feasible and effective, this model could be implemented nationwide to help achieve mental and obstetric health parity for low-income women of color in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The oncogenic transcription factor MYCN drives a subset of neuroblastoma tumors which is deadly in half the cases despite protracted and intense therapy including polychemotherapy and immunotherapy (anti-GD2 therapy). As MYCN remains undruggable, finding synthetic lethal relationships that may result in new treatments is one of the “holy grails” of pediatric cancer therapy. In this grant proposal, we provide evidence that amplified MYCN orchestrates a complex and intricate re-wiring of the neuroblastoma cell to 1) increase iron metabolism, 2) increase cysteine and selenocysteine biosynthesis to counteract reactive oxygen species created from iron metabolism-related Fenton reactions and 3) increase synthesis of pantothenate kinase 3 (PANK3) to subsequently increase coA levels; the result of which is the creation of a synthetic lethality and therapeutic vulnerability to ferroptosis induction which we aim to explore, clarify and translate to new therapeutic options for this recalcitrant pediatric tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Soft tissues sarcomas (STS) is a broad term for multiple subtypes of cancer that start in soft tissues. There is currently no unifying treatment for STS subtypes beyond surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation. Resolute Science Inc. is developing novel STS therapy by using tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) to process and deliver anti-cancer agents to solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the Center for Innovative NeuroTech Advancement (CINTA) is to rapidly transform emerging technologies into commercially viable, clinically focused solutions for disorders of the nervous system as a hub under the NIH Blueprint MedTech: Incubator Hubs program. CINTA will support the advancement of neurotechnology solutions by adapting and improving upon the proven model that CIMIT developed and implemented for RADx Tech to accelerate promising neurotechnologies that address critical areas of unmet needs in the diagnosis and treatment of nervous system disorders to human-grade prototypes. CINTA plans to find, fund, facilitate, and accelerate 15 projects per year through this program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Over the past 25 years, the search for novel analgesics has had only a few successes and many failures; some of these failures have occurred through an overreliance on screening of compounds in rodent models of pain or physiology that fail to translate to homo sapiens. In this proposal, we take a target agnostic but human centric approach to discover novel natural product fractions with potential to induce analgesia through peripheral nociceptors. Natural product fractions from the National Cancer Institutes Natural Products Repository will be screened for analgesic activity in human “nociceptor” cells using multi-electrode array technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative While current pharmacological treatments with antipsychotics have beneficial effects on the positive symptoms of schizophrenia, they lack efficacy against cognitive symptoms, which are critical predictors of long-term clinical outcomes. We hypothesize that a shift from inhibitory to excitatory GABAA current in the prefrontal cortex of adult animals is a critical pathogenic mechanism shared by multiple genetic models of schizophrenia representing diverse etiologies including copy number variants (16p11.2 duplication), rare variants (TRIO+/-), and common variants (Cacna1C+/-), and that pharmacological correction of this shift rescues cognitive performance in these animals.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many important problems in child health and development may result from a mother’s environment during pregnancy. We are a coalition of scientists in Michigan who plan to 1) continue collecting information from the 1,600 families we have already enrolled in the Environmental influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO) study; and 2) enroll another 540 families from diverse populations. Working together with other study groups who are part of the national ECHO program, we hope to learn what changes might be made during a woman’s pregnancy that could prevent later problems in child health and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Black adolescents and young adults bear a disproportionate burden of both HIV and STI acquisitions, especially in the South. Increased HIV and STI testing is vital to improving overall sexual health for this vulnerable population, however access to HIV and STI testing remains inadequate. We propose to evaluate the implementation of varied HIV and STI testing modalities (i.e., facility based versus at-home testing) and explore the role of syndemics (i.e., mental illness, drug usage, and the social determinants of health) on testing preferences to enhance evidence-based approaches to promote optimal HIV and STI testing options that are feasible and acceptable to HBCU student populations in the South.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a neuropsychiatric condition that causes enormous human suffering and cost to society. Our goal is to rapidly learn more about the genetics of this disorder and how genes and environment might act and interact to alter disease risk. We propose to do this by collecting a new, large, ancestrally-diverse and well-phenotyped sample of OCD cases followed by detailed genomic analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy is the standard-of-care treatment for muscle invasive bladder cancer but 70% of patients do not respond. We discovered a novel mechanism by which puromycin-sensitive aminopeptidase, NPEPPS, is upregulated, and we have strong evidence supporting its interaction with volume- regulated anion channels (VRACs) to block import of cisplatin and other platins into cancer cells. The focus of this proposal is to characterize this novel mechanism and evaluate pharmacological inhibition of NPEPPS in combination with platin drugs in preclinical models with the objective of eventually improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address fundamental questions regarding the cell-of-origin of distinct classes of gastric cancer, we will integrate novel mouse models, organotypic cultures of human and mouse cells using state- of-the-art single cell profiling and spatial transcriptional analyses. We will also explore the related issue of disease development by defining key transcriptional mediators of the progression to gastric cancer and then perform experimental validation. Taken together, our studies will address and resolve longstanding debates over the origins of gastric cancer while also defining possible targets to prevent cancer initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The metastasis of cancerous cells to distant and vital organs is responsible for approximately 90% of cancer mortalities, and it is clear that an important barrier to tumor progression and metastasis is the survival of cancer cells that are detached from the extracellular matrix (ECM). However, our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the survival of ECM-detached cancer cells remains rudimentary. This proposal seeks to examine how a novel pathway involving RIPK1 and the degradation of mitochondria can restrict breast cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ovarian cancer is usually diagnosed at a late stage when survival is only about 10%, rendering this disease the deadliest gynecological malignancy. Disease recurrence is the major cause of mortality and despite a greater understanding of ovarian cancer biology there have been no significant improvements in mortality rates in the last five decades. Investigation of tumor cells that are resistant to chemotherapy and have the capacity to regenerate tumors is crucial for achieving cures for ovarian cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: OVERALL: Mapping the Cancer Complex System from Clinical MR Imaging of GBM The aim of our Mayo/Columbia CSBC Mathematical Oncology Systems Analysis Imaging Center (MOSAIC) is to build a conceptual framework to understand sex-specific glioma tissue state transitions and dynamics and the ways to interpret MRI relative to those changes MOSAIC leverages a large and growing core unique resource of radiographically-localized biopsies in glioma patients. In two projects, we will employ quantitative systems biology to quantify the dynamic glioma tissue state ecosystem and connections to routine clinical imaging. This will allow us to better understand glioma tissue states, their cellular cross-talk and how individual patients’ tissue state landscape will respond to therapy to ultimately drive new clinical trials that improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE The Administrative Core will be the primary touchpoint of the center, facilitating interactions between the two projects and three additional cores. The Administrative Core will also actively cultivate collaborations throughout the consortium with assistance from the Outreach Core, particularly through administering Intra-Center and Cross-Consortium Pilot Projects, hosting workshops and symposiums, and facilitating visiting faculty all while enhancing diverse perspectives on this critical topic. Co-PDs Swanson and Canoll will provide the central leadership in the Administrative Core, while the Center Program Administrator will provide day-to-day business, administrative and scientific management of Center activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Darwinian evolution drives the emergence of resistance to targeted therapy in cancer. We propose to use results from our in vitro evolutionary game assay to parameterize a computer model to allow us to predict 3-dimensional dynamics on clinically relevant timescales. Further, we will extend our assay to function in vivo, allowing the community to test mathematically derived evolutionary therapy hypotheses in preclinical models.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: The Infrastructure Component (IC) of the HuBMAP Integration, Visualization & Engagement  (HIVE) Collaboratory will provide the open data platform for study of multi-scale tissue  organization and function through 3D biomolecular tissue maps in the spatial framework of the  human body. The studies enabled on this platform will facilitate comparisons across individuals,  organs, tissues, and cells to characterize normal function and variation, leading to deeper  understanding of underlying mechanisms of variation or disease, and ultimately pointing to  interventions for disease prevention or treatment.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Uniform processing of many disparate data types reduces friction in integrating disparate data between  modalities, tissues, and data providers, allowing clinicians and public health experts to find biological  and clinically-relevant insights in large biomolecular, spatial, and imaging datasets. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) are an effective treatment in the community and among incarcerated individuals, yet they are offered in very few correctional settings nationwide. The criminal justice (CJ) system offers a unique opportunity to engage individuals in treatment initiation, given the high prevalence of opioid use disorder (OUD) in jails and prisons and the high risk of opioid overdose upon release. The study will compare treatment outcomes between extended-release buprenorphine (XR-B) to treatment-as-usual sublingual buprenorphine (SL-B) in a CJ setting and conduct a mixed-methods process evaluation which will characterize the facilitators of and barriers to the implementation of this novel treatment modality.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), through its Office of Medical Policy, has sought to advance regulatory science, policy, and procedures to address a range of critical public health topics, including drug development, drug approval, bioresearch monitoring, human subject protection, and post market surveillance methods and systems. The Robert J. Margolis, MD, Institute for Health Policy at Duke University (Duke- Margolis) proposes to support the FDA in advancing its medical policy development through rigorous collaborative research and convening activities from design, planning, and execution, through to synthesis, drafting, and communication of findings. This builds on Duke-Margolis and FDA's 15-year track record of partnership and leverages Duke-Margolis's skill as a neutral third-party convener to develop and deliver trusted, high-impact stakeholder engagement and research materials on priority regulatory and public health issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Building on our previous validation studies conducted in highly relevant animal models, the successful completion of the proposed studies will provide at least one novel, highly effective and safe mechanism-based formulation of small molecules for attenuating painful cutaneous blistering/inflammation caused by exposure to chemical warfare arsenical vesicants and, perhaps, other similar agents. These studies are crucial for moving the newly developed formulation to clinic. The outcome of the proposed research is likely to have a significant impact on human health protection in the event of accidental or intentional mass population exposure to vesicant chemicals used in warfare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Those who are blind or visually impaired suffer from an inability to transform visual information into behaviorally relevant representations to guide selection of appropriate actions. This project seeks to derive the algorithms for sensorimotor transformations that can guide technologies to restore visual-motor behaviors through neuroprosthetics. This project also seeks to uncover the underlying mechanisms for these algorithms that provide targets for restoring sensorimotor transformations in neurodegenerative diseases or neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our findings have the potential to describe the neural computations that form the basis for amotivation, a known transdiagnostic factor across several psychiatric and neurological disorders, including depression and schizophrenia. This research can therefore enable endophenotypic assessment of risk for these disorders and severity of motivational impairments in subclinical populations, providing a potential biomarker to aid in diagnosis and treatment outcome research, and facilitating development of and tests of efficacy for therapies aimed at reducing these impairments. This work carries promising future directions for studying motivational impairments in depression, schizophrenia, Alzheimer’s, and Parkinson’s, and to improve well-being and increase productivity in the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Cystic fibrosis is a devastating genetic disease that involves multiple organ systems and leads to premature death; therapeutic advances have extended lifespans and improved quality of life, but patients still suffer from airway infections, in addition to CF-related diabetes, digestive complications, and inflammatory responses. Our Center catalyzes new research in preclinical drug development, gut disease and diabetes and changes in patient microbiomes. We believe that these phenomena are interconnected, and that parallel investigations, coupled by powerful new data-science strategies can find new therapeutic approaches for CF patients by understanding the complex underlying biology.

PHR: Project Narrative The Stanford-SLAC CryoET Specimen Preparation Service Center (SCSC) was established to meet the emerging national need for cryoET as a structural biology tool. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the University of Kentucky (UK) SuRE Resource Center is to build research capacity at SuRE-eligible institutions, recognizing the vital contribution these colleges and universities make to the nation's research enterprise. Through a series of webinars and other training modalities, direct consultation, a competitive seed grant program to create or enhance offices of sponsor projects (OSPs), and biennial conferences, experienced UK faculty and research support staff will assist faculty and OSP staff at SuRE- eligible institutions prepare and submit competitive NIH grants applications, with an emphasis on SuRE and SuRE-First awards. Multiple methods will be used to collect and analyze data to measure the success of this center.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: A substantial majority of Veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) continue to suffer even with the best current medications. New scientific tools are urgently needed to overcome poor understanding of the links between symptoms, brain dysfunction, and the specific effects of medications to develop better and more targeted PTSD treatments. Preliminary research has shown that the stimulant methylphenidate caused robust reduction in PTSD symptoms, but the mechanism of this effect is unknown. This project aims to apply new computational and neuroimaging methods to characterize the mechanism by which methylphenidate improves PTSD in Veterans. It will use these tools to quantitatively measure the effect of methylphenidate in enabling the brain to more flexibly adapt to different environments, thereby reducing the brain’s hyper-reactivity to sensory stimulation. The ultimate goal is to enable individualized treatments for Veterans with PTSD and the development of new, more effective medications for this burdensome disorder.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a debilitating and highly prevalent disorder in both the Veteran and general population. One under-studied, but highly significant consequence of PTSD is a significantly increased risk of developing hypertension and cardiovascular disease. The overarching goal of this research program is to elucidate the mechanistic roles of sympathetic nervous system (SNS) dysregulation in future cardiovascular risk in post-9/11 Veterans with PTSD. Specifically, this project will determine the downstream effects of heightened SNS reactivity on renal vasoconstriction and neurovascular transduction mediated by vascular alpha-1 adrenergic receptor sensitivity using state-of-the-art human physiology techniques. We will also assess the potential therapeutic role of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation in ameliorating SNS overactivation and improving arterial baroreflex sensitivity in PTSD. Given the large numbers of post-9/11 afflicted with PTSD, understanding the mechanisms of SNS overactivity in PTSD is crucial for impacting future cardiovascular risk.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Long-term use of a class of medications known as benzodiazepines raises risk of cognitive problems, falls, addiction, and overdose. One method of helping patients who have been on these medications for extended periods is to provide them with information regarding how to taper off. This study develops such a self-tapering tool for use as a smart phone app and tests whether it works in a sample of 170 Veterans and how much it would cost to make the tool widely accessible.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposed administrative supplement aims to address the complex intersection of HIV stigma, gender disparity, and cultural vulnerabilities faced by women living with HIV/AIDS (WLHA) in Vietnam. Through mentored implementation science research, the project will facilitate selection and adaptation of evidence- based, family-centered interventions to improve health outcomes for WLHA. Additionally, comprehensive hands-on training and mentoring will equip junior researchers in Vietnam with the skills necessary to become future leaders in implementation science, ensuring local capacity to sustain and expand these critical health improvement efforts for WLHA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Kaposi's sarcoma (KS) is the most common cancer in people living with AIDS, and lymphomas are the second most common. The Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV) also called human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is the etiologic agent of KS and some lymphomas. We will develop laboratory models that resemble diseases caused by KSHV, including the immune tumor microenvironment, which will allow us to test new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL An urgent need exists to develop better strategies for the prevention of cancer in high-risk subjects, and in particular, in those who have inherited a predisposition for the disease. In close collaboration with the NCI and other Centers, Fox Chase Cancer Center (FCCC) proposes to utilize multidisciplinary expertise, novel cutting-edge technology, and biospecimens and data from mutation carriers in the FCCC Risk Assessment Program to identify agents that can effectively disrupt the earliest steps in tumor formation. Establishment of FCCC as a member of a highly collaborative Cancer Prevention-Interception Targeted Agent Discovery Program (CAP-IT) is anticipated to accelerate the development of efficacious preventive agents and have a significant impact on reducing the burden of cancer among those at highest risk of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because the goal is to develop novel and highly potent LOX inhibitors to overcome chemotherapy resistance in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC), a highly aggressive subpopulation of breast cancer with worse survival. Once we develop LOX inhibitors with excellent drug-like properties, there is a significant potential to improve the treatment of chemotherapy-resistant TNBC patients with high LOX expression. Thus, the proposed project is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Individual humans and animals can lie anywhere along a continuum of high to low risk-taking propensity. Both extremes of risk-taking propensity are thought to contribute to problematic behavior in several neuropsychiatric conditions, such as pathological anxiety and anorexia nervosa (low risk-taking propensity), and gambling disorder and substance abuse disorder (high risk-taking propensity). This project will develop, optimize, and mechanistically test a novel risky decision-making assay for use in screening for novel therapeutics, and eventual translation to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This administrative supplement proposal is an extension of an existing award (K23 NS125110). Measures of white matter integrity derived from brain MRI are expected to be disease-specific and clinically relevant to clinical (cognitive and motor) endpoints and fluid biomarkers of brain pathology in adults with myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2). This project will inform the development of rigorous trial designs and a subsequent R01 study to evaluate longitudinal changes of white matter integrity and fluid biomarkers of brain pathology as measures of disease progression and therapeutic response in DM2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT 1 | NARRATIVE Breast cancer is a leading cause of death for women in the United States and around the globe. An early event in development of breast cancer is the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) when mammary cells lose their normal structure and function and gain migratory and invasive properties. Project 1 studies will investigate mitotic gene bookmarking—mitotic retention of transcription factors with target genes on chromosomes for transcriptional regulation in progeny cells—as an epigenetic mechanism to maintain normal mammary epithelial cell identity. We will determine whether compromised mitotic bookmarking by the RUNX1 transcription factor results in initiation of EMT and onset of breast cancer. Findings will have far reaching impact on development of new approaches to identify and therapeutically target early events in breast cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  KRAS mutations represent one of the most common molecular etiologies of cancer and confer high mortality rates in a broad range of organ malignancies including lung, colon, and pancreas. Selectively eliminating mutant forms of the protein while retaining normal nonmalignant KRAS protein is extremely challenging for conventional therapeutic strategies. EnFuego Therapeutics has developed a novel, ligand- directed siRNA-based technology capable of suppressing mutant KRAS while sparing wild type transcripts. These compounds also exhibit hallmark characteristics of effective targeted therapies, including serum stability, cancer growth inhibition, and abrogation of oncogenic downstream KRAS signaling. This Fast Track proposal will focus on the optimization of select EnFuego compounds which target G12V mutant KRAS in lung cancer, a mutation that is intractable for other therapeutic strategies and contributes 22% of all KRAS-associated lung cancer cases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The University of Michigan (UM) PAIN Cohort T90/R90 is ideally suited to train the next generation of post-doctoral pain scientists. The program proposes inter-disciplinary mentoring and training of individuals from  disciplines not typically involved in pain research, with a heavy emphasis on training a wide variety of data  scientists as well as trainees from our School of Public Health (including biostatistics and epidemiology) and  College of Engineering (including computer science and biomedical engineering). By using a vast array of  available and willing mentors at UM not formally named on the grant, we will be able to provide each of our  Scholars both a junior and senior mentor, as well as an individual with learned experience, as part of their  mentoring team.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to reveal the mechanisms of how single-stranded RNA bacteriophages (ssRNA phages) PP7 and AP205 package their genomic RNA to be delivered to Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter spp., respectively via the Type IV pili, by combining high-resolution cryo-electron microscopy, in-situ fluorescence microscopy, and multi-scale computational modeling. Unlike double-stranded DNA phages, ssRNA phages do not have pressurized capsids or dedicated DNA delivery machinery, and how ssRNA phages package and deliver RNA into the cell remains a mystery. Knowledge gained from this project will provide an alternative strategy for treating multidrug-resistant bacterial infections by specifically cleaving/stalling Type IV pili.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Although peri-implantitis occurs in 1/10th of all implants, and peri-implant mucositis in 60% of implants, our ability to treat and prevent these diseases is severely hampered by a lack of knowledge of the causative factors and mechanisms of disease. The proposed studies represent the first comprehensive visual and molecular atlas of the peri-implant environment from moment of its formation to the onset of disease. This functional and spatial characterization will bring us closer to understanding the mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of these disease and provide biologically-validated timelines for risk assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most oral cancers are preceded by clinical lesions called oral potentially malignant disorders (OPMDs). The objective of this proposal is to develop a multimodal imaging based OPMD diagnostic platform that integrates Fourier transform infrared spectroscopic imaging with histological imaging and spatial transcriptomics, aided by advanced machine learning and deep learning techniques. This novel platform can potentially allow clinicians to make objective, accurate, and personalized risk assessment for individual OPMD patients and facilitate early oral cancer detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative Pain management is a significant problem in oral cancer patients. Importantly, the mechanisms of oral cancer pain are incompletely understood, and this impedes development of novel analgesics, We propose a novel mechanism of oral cancer pain that will provide knowledge for future research at developing drugs for not only pain management but also cancer treatment. Specifically, the current application proposes to study role of truncated TrkB isoform in mediating pain at the site of tumor development. Given that TrkB contributes to tumor progression, targeting this receptor signaling can prove to be efficacious therapy for cancer-induced pain as well as tumor progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Eighty percent of children with advanced or metastatic sarcoma will die from disease despite aggressive multimodality therapy. In this proposal we aim to define less-toxic and more effective targeted therapeutic approaches in high-risk RAS-driven Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma (ERMS) by using patient-derived xenograft models, omics and novel single-mouse testing approaches. Our focus is inhibition of MAPK signaling as potential therapeutic strategy to treat ERMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accidental exposure to the halogen gas, chlorine (Cl2), causes fatal lung injury characterized by profound airway inflammation, pulmonary edema and acute respiratory failure. Survivors often display persistent reactive airway disease and progressive pulmonary fibrosis. This study will determine if mitochondria DNA damage underlies Cl2 toxicity and whether repairing mitochondrial DNA can reduce morbidity and mortality.
